Nestled in the heart of the picturesque Aveyron region of southern France, the Chateau de Najac stands as a timeless testament to the grandeur of the medieval era. This magnificent fortress, perched atop a rugged hill, overlooks the enchanting village of Najac with an air of regal authority, casting a mesmerizing spell over all who lay eyes upon it. Constructed in the 13th century during the tumultuous times of the Albigensian Crusade, the Chateau de Najac was not just a symbol of power but a guardian of a region rife with conflict. Its formidable stone walls, constructed to withstand sieges, rise majestically from the rocky terrain, each stone echoing centuries of history and power. As you approach the chateau, the very journey to its gates is an adventure through time, as you tread the very path that knights and noble ladies once walked, perhaps en route to or returning from the Crusade. Within the chateau's walls, the ambiance is nothing short of awe-inspiring. A tranquil courtyard, surrounded by well-preserved battlements, transports you back to the days when chivalry reigned supreme. The whispers of the wind and the echoing footsteps serve as a haunting reminder of all who have passed through these hallowed halls. Stepping into the chateau's interiors, you are enveloped by a sense of mystery and antiquity. Stone archways lead you into dimly lit chambers where the tapestries tell stories of valor and love, offering a glimpse into the courtly life of the Middle Ages. The great hall, with its vaulted ceilings and colossal hearth, exudes an aura of grandeur that only the noblest of feasts and gatherings could have filled. But it is from the highest tower of the Chateau de Najac that you are truly transported to another world. Ascend the winding staircase to be greeted by a panoramic vista that sweeps across the Aveyron landscape, just as it did when this fortress was both a stronghold and a refuge during its tumultuous history. In every corner of the Chateau de Najac, you can almost hear the echoes of battles won and lost, and the whispers of lovers who once sought refuge in its walls. This medieval masterpiece is more than a monument; it is a living, breathing testament to human history, offering a profound connection to the past that is both emotive and stirring. A visit to the Chateau de Najac is a journey through time, an encounter with the spirits of chivalry, and an opportunity to lose oneself in the enchanting story of France's medieval heritage.

"The World is Too Much With Us" by William Wordsworth: -> The poem is a sonnet, which means it has 14 lines and follows a specific rhyme scheme and structure. The rhyme scheme is ABBAABBA CDCDCD, which is typical of an Italian or Petrarchan sonnet. The poem is divided into two parts: an octave (the first eight lines) and a sestet (the last six lines). The octave presents the main problem or conflict, while the sestet offers a possible solution or resolution. -> The main problem or conflict that the speaker expresses in the octave is that people are too obsessed with worldly affairs and materialism, and they have lost their connection with nature. The speaker uses words such as "getting and spending", "lay waste our powers", "given our hearts away", and "sordid boon" to show his disdain for the greed and consumerism of modern society. He also uses words such as "little", "see", and "ours" to show how people have become blind and alienated from the beauty and value of nature. -> The possible solution or resolution that the speaker suggests in the sestet is that he would rather be a pagan who worships nature gods than a modern person who ignores nature. The speaker uses words such as "rather", "might", "glimpses", and "less forlorn" to show his preference and desire for a more natural and spiritual life. He also uses words such as "Proteus" and "Triton" to refer to ancient Greek sea gods who represent the power and mystery of nature. -> The poem reflects Wordsworth's views on the negative effects of the Industrial Revolution, which was a period of technological and mechanical innovation that transformed British society in the 18th and 19th centuries. Wordsworth was one of the leading figures of the Romantic movement, which emphasized the importance of emotion, imagination, individualism, and nature in art and literature. Wordsworth believed that nature was a source of inspiration, wisdom, and joy, and that people should respect and cherish it. He also criticized the urbanization, industrialization, and commercialization of society, which he thought corrupted human values and degraded natural environments. -> The poem uses various poetic devices to convey its message and mood. Some of these devices are: - Alliteration: the repetition of consonant sounds at the beginning of words, such as "world", "with", "waste", "winds", etc. - Personification: the attribution of human qualities to non-human things, such as "This Sea that bares her bosom to the moon" or "The winds that will be howling at all hours". - Metaphor: a comparison between two unlike things without using like or as, such as "we have given our hearts away" or "we are out of tune". - Hyperbole: an exaggeration for emphasis or effect, such as "the world is too much with us" or "it moves us not". - Apostrophe: a direct address to someone or something that is absent or imaginary, such as "Great God!" or "Proteus" and "Triton". - Iambic pentameter: a rhythmic pattern of five pairs of unstressed and stressed syllables per line, such as "The WORLD / is TOO / much WITH / us; LATE / and SOON". ______________________________________________________ (Book: 100 Selected Poems https://amzn.to/3SdWrI6:=:https://www.amazon.com/dp/9387779246/ref=tsm_1_fb_lk) #ad #poetry#englishliterature #wordsworth

Big (& Tall) newsâ€¦we have welcomed a baby giraffe to the Oakland Zoo family. Please say hello to Kendi! Yesterday morning, Kijiji giraffe gave birth to her first calf, Kendi (â€œloved oneâ€ in Swahili.) This amazing little female is approximately 150 lbs and 6.5 feet tall. Kijiji has already demonstrated her loving and protective nature by guiding her baby into the giraffe barn. A separate area has been set up by Keepers in the barn for the Kendi and mama giraffe to bond peacefully. Kendi is expected to remain behind the scenes with the mom for approximately two weeks for mama & calf to develop their relationship. â€œWeâ€™re so excited to have a new baby join the herd. With the expertise of our staff, weâ€™re prepared to assist Kijiji as she enters this stage in life as a new motherâ€ â€” Amy Phelps, Zoological Manager Kijiji and Kendi will serve as ambassadors, educating guests about their wild giraffe counterparts. By having giraffes at the Zoo, we hope to bring appreciation and awareness to the giraffe species, including the challenges they face in the wild. Oakland Zoo partners with The Reticulated Giraffe Project in Kenya, a conservation organization dedicated to working with local communities in Africa to help reduce human-wildlife conflict and habitat loss to preserve endangered wild giraffe populations. Weâ€™ll be sure to let you know how Kendi is doing, and when you can come see them in person. ONLY FOR PASTORS!! ğŸš¨ tag a pastor MINISTERIAL STRESS AND BURNOUT Some few days back, a Pastor was preaching in his church and people were really enjoying the sermon. Then suddenly he froze and had to be rushed to the hospital and died! Another Pastor went to a mountain, proposing to fast for 100 days. He started and on the 31st day of the dry fast, he collapsed, started shaking, could not speak and lost the use of his hands and legs. His sugar level was finished and he is still battling with his health till now. A Pastor was preaching vigorously and suddenly fell down from the pulpit and died there. And another Pastor went for a medical test. He is 50 years old, but the test result showed that his heart is that of an 80 year old! All these are not spiritual attacks, but results of stress, overwork and lack of work-life balance by ministers of the gospel. A. Scriptural Foundation â€“ 1 Kings 19:1-4; 2 Kings 13:14-21 Being a minister is a 24/7 job. Being a Pastor is the toughest job in the whole world. And most ministers are workaholic and work-addict, which results in stress and burnout. Stress is a state/condition of tiredness, weariness, pain in the body, exhaustion, lack of sleep, rest, having emotional issues and obesity â€“ yet you canâ€™t stop, because there is much to do! Here are those things that stress ministers:- â–ª Church stagnation. â–ª Financial pressure. â–ª Pressure to perform. â–ª Crowded programmes. â–ª Elephant projects. â–ª Unrealistic expectations. â–ª Emotional worries. â–ª Problematic members. â–ª Troublesome associates. â–ª Church bills/remittances. â–ª Low attendance. â–ª Problems at the home front. â–ª Superiorsâ€™ pressures. â–ª Pulpit manners. Quite sad, that most modern Pastors and ministers are under tremendous stress as a result of these stress-inducing factors. Ministers that juggle all these together will definitely end up stressed and experience burnout. B. The Adverse Effects of Stress And Burnout â€“ 1 Kings 19:1-4; 1 Samuel 13:8-14 Burnout leads to loss of interest, lack of emotion, loss of motivation and possible depression. âœ“ Poor healthâ€‹- stroke, high or low sugar levels. âœ“ Family crisisâ€‹- separation, divorce and wayward children. âœ“ Unresolved conflictâ€‹- anger, hurts and terrible words. âœ“ Poor performance â€‹- emotional depletion. âœ“ Financial loss â€‹- debts, losses and poor decision making. Getting angry, stressed up, hurts and becoming irrational are the outcome of stress and burnout. C. Ministry-Life Balance â€“ Matthew 11:28-30 It is vitally important that ministers are able to strike the much needed balance between ministry and living. If truly His yoke is easy, why are ministers experiencing being heavy laden in ministry? It is as a result of lack of balance on our part! A balance minister must have; â–ª Emotional balance. â–ª Mental balance. â–ª Family balance. â–ª Spiritual balance. â–ª Social balance. â–ª Financial balance. â–ª Physical balance. â–ª Psychological balance. If you are not balanced in these areas, then you canâ€™t minister successfully to others. Here are steps to achieve this balance: 1. Re-order your priorities right: God first, family second, ministry last. 2. Eat healthy foods in measures: living foods not dead foods; and not after 6-7pm. 3. Drink alkaline or living waters. 4. Train others and delegate your work. 5. Spend time with your spouse and children. 6. Have peace with God and possess the peace of God â€“ Isaiah 26:34. 7. Negate toxic feelings, thoughts and words. 8. Take healthy breaks to refresh yourself. 9. Take time to seek and wait upon God. 10. Exercise â€“ walk, ride bicycle or stretch. 11. Take time off â€“ vacations, holidays and rest periods. 12. Learn to sleep 7-8 hours night sleep. Catch a nap in the day time. 13. Rest in the Lord to work through you â€“ not you working for Him. It was Robert Murray Mchene who said, â€œGod gave me a horse and a message, now I have killed the horse and could not deliver the messageâ€. He said that on his death bed! He started ministry at 26 years and died at 29 years of age! What a loss! Pastors hear meâ€¦ if you donâ€™t learn to rest in time, you may have to Rest In Peace very soon!

â€œAs the two regional organizations located astride the major sea gates and vital corridors of the worldâ€™s commerce and communications, it is imperative that we work together to promote peace, security and stability in both our regions,â€ President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. said as he urged fellow leaders from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) to uphold rules-based international order to ensure harmony to the rest of the world. The President made these remarks during the ASEAN-GCC Summit in Riyadh, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia where he expressed the Philippinesâ€™ concern over the recent turmoil in some parts of the world, including the Israel and Gaza conflict. â€œWe hope that all parties will exert their utmost efforts to deescalate the situation, stop all violence and engage in dialogue and diplomacy,â€ he conveyed, emphasizing the need to establish concrete areas of cooperation and complementary working relationships. Moreover, he welcomed the adoption of the ASEAN-GCC Framework of Cooperation 2024-2028 that will serve as guide for both regional blocs under the political-security, economic and socio-cultural pillars, adding that this document will chart the path forward with greater political will. â€œThe Philippines looks forward to advancing our common interests, particularly on energy and food security, enhancement of logistics and supply chains, the digital economy, and the free and secure flow of goods, people and services that currently underpin an interdependent global economy,â€ the Chief Executive affirmed. â€œThe Philippines remains strongly committed to support a meaningful partnership with GCC countries for peace in our regions and the prosperity of our peoples,â€ President Marcos Jr. concluded in his intervention.

Look for the Helpers (Always) â€œWhen I was a boy and I would see scary things in the news, my mother would say to me, â€˜Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.â€ Fred Rogers Our world is a scary place right now for many. The suffering in the Holy Land is sobering, distressing and depressing. It has been a complicated place with complex solutions for a long time. Misunderstanding, discord, injustice, violence, oppression, and hatred seem to be threatening, if not overtaking the more human, humane and spiritual values of justice, understanding, peace, reconciliation, and love. Iâ€™ve traveled there four times, studied in Jerusalem and throughout the land for two months, and led a pilgrimage, with plans to lead many more. Hearing the stories of the people of the land will transform you. Listening will obliterate your prejudices and soften your heart as well as strengthen your will to be part of the solution. Right now, no one seems to be in the mood to listen, to understand, to find a solution other than retribution and doing harm to one's enemy. But such violence is not only contrary to the core values of all religions, it simply makes things worse. What Jesus said is true: â€œThose who live by the sword (insert modern weapon of choice) will die by the sword.â€ Yet, every day more and more innocent victims are harmed, maimed or killed. What should we do, other than pray? Iâ€™d say Mr. Rogersâ€™ advice is more wise than anything Iâ€™ve heard any political leader espouse lately: Look for the helpers. On every trip to the Holy Land, the biggest blessing has been meeting helpers, those folks who are working hard to bring people together and find real solutions to the conflict and discord. Although you wonâ€™t read about many of them in the news, regardless of your source, they are there. And they are still working on the right (and righteous things) against the odds. One helper whose legacy continues today is Henrietta Szold, founder of the Jewish Womenâ€™s Organization Hadassah. You may know that Hadassah Hospital just outside Jerusalem continues to serve as a model of healing and co-existence, â€œmaking broken lives whole and giving hope where there is none.â€ Another helper is Suhaila Tarazi, the Director of the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza. This hospital, Iâ€™m proud to say, is a ministry of my own religious tradition, the Episcopal Diocese of Jerusalem. Itâ€™s a small group of people with extraordinarily large hearts. They have helpers throughout the Middle East working to heal, educate, reconcile, and train â€“ whatever it takes to help people become more whole â€“ just what our loving God intends for ALL people. There are so many more helpers I could point to in the Holy Land â€“ some are Christian, some are Jewish, some are Muslim. Some are ministries of the Episcopal Diocese of Jerusalem but many others are not. The Parentâ€™s Circle is one, in particular, that has inspired me for many years. These helpers give me hope when itâ€™s so easy to have none. Look for the helpers. And when you find them, help them. In helping them, we are helping God, who is very proud of each of them Iâ€™m sure. Did I just sound like Mr. Rogers? If so, then I must be doing something right. William B. â€œFather Billâ€ Miller is an Episcopal priest and writer living in Round Top, Texas. He is the author of three inspirational books. He and his wife Sandy rescue dogs, pastor a church, and lead pilgrimages to the Holy Land. They try to support as many helpers as they can.

RIADE/RIYADH CIMEIRA ASEAN/GCC 20 DE OUTUBRO DE 2023 ASEAN/GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL SUMMIT TIMOR-LESTE PARTICIPATING AS OBSERVER STATE. In my brief remarks referring to the crisis in Gaza, I stated Timor-Leste alignment with the ASEAN FOREIGN MINISTERSâ€™ STATEMENT ON THE RECENT ESCALATION OF ARMED CONFLICT IN THE MIDDLE EAST 20 OCTOBER 2023 1. We, the Member States of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), are gravely concerned over the recent escalation of armed conflicts in the Middle East. We urge for the immediate end of violence to avoid further human casualties and call for the full respect of International Humanitarian Law. We call on all parties to create safe, rapid and unimpeded passage of humanitarian corridors. 2. We strongly condemn the acts of violence which have led to the deaths and injury of civilians, including ASEAN nationals. We reaffirm our support for a negotiated two-State solution that allows both Israelis and Palestinians to live side-by-side in peace and security consistent with relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions. This will be the only viable path to resolving the root cause of the conflict. 3. We further call on all parties to protect and ensure safety and security to all civilians, including ASEAN nationals, and the immediate and unconditional release of all hostages. We re-emphasize our commitment to provide emergency assistance to ASEAN nationals, in accordance with the ASEAN Declaration on the Guidelines on Consular Assistance by ASEAN Member Statesâ€™ Missions in Third Countries to Nationals of Other ASEAN Member State and the Guidelines for the Provision of Emergency Assistance by ASEAN Missions in Third Countries to Nationals of ASEAN Member Countries in Crisis Situations. 4. We urge the international community to support the peace process in order to ensure long lasting peace and stability in the region. 5. We have issued our respective national statements on the escalation of armed conflicts in the Middle East. * * * https://asean.org/asean-foreign-ministers-statement-on-the-recent-escalation-of-armed-conflict-in-the-middle-east/

FOOD FOR THOUGHT- For a small amount of perspective at this moment, imagine you were born in 1900. When you are 14, World War I starts, and ends on your 18th birthday with 22 million people killed. Later in the year, a Spanish Flu epidemic hits the planet and runs until you are 20. Fifty million people die from it in those two years. Yes, 50 million. When you're 29, the Great Depression begins. Unemployment hits 25%, global GDP drops 27%. That runs until you are 33. The country nearly collapses along with the world economy. When you turn 39, World War II starts. You arenâ€™t even over the hill yet. When you're 41, the United States is fully pulled into WWII. Between your 39th and 45th birthday, 75 million people perish in the war and the Holocaust kills six million. At 52, the Korean War starts and five million perish. At 64 the Vietnam War begins, and it doesnâ€™t end for many years. Four million people die in that conflict. Approaching your 62nd birthday you have the Cuban Missile Crisis, a tipping point in the Cold War. Life on our planet, as we know it, could well have ended. Great leaders prevented that from happening. As you turn 75, the Vietnam War finally ends. Think of everyone on the planet born in 1900. How do you survive all of that? A kid in 1985 didnâ€™t think their 85 year old grandparent understood how hard school was. Yet those grandparents (and now great grandparents) survived through everything listed above. Perspective is an amazing art. Letâ€™s try and keep things in perspective. Letâ€™s be smart, help each other out, and we will get through all of this. In the history of the world, there has never been a storm that lasted. This too, shall pass.

Abdii hin kutatiin(Don't give up)
     
'Ani amma achi abdii hin qabu,ani
 maaliifan addunyaa kanarra jiraadha?

Jiraachuu koo manna osoo du'ee wayya'....yaadni jedhu sammuu keetti dhufee beekaa ykn ammoo nama akkas jechuun dubbatu dhageessee beektaa? Eeyyeen namootni baay'ee yeroo garagaraatti haala garagaraa keessa ta'anii miirri akkasii sammuu isaanii keessatti keessumeessuu danda'u.

 Ega ka miirri akkasii kun miira abdii kutannaati.Jireenya keenya keessatti  abdii kutachuun ammoo gara fulduraati tarkaanfachuu nu dhoorkuun waan baay'ee nu dhabsiisa. Hundi keenyaa addunyaa kanarra kan jiraannu abdiidhaani. Kanaaf Abdiin bu'ura jireenyaati jechuu ni dandeenya.

Abdii kutachuun bakka yaadne akka hin geenye nu hanqisa. Namootni abdii kutatan yeroo baay'ee carraan bakka yaada isaanii gahanii xiqqaadha. Namni bakka yaada isaa hin gahin hafe ammoo jireenya isaa keessatti gammachuu dhabuun; muka'uu(depressed), dhiphachuu, sodaa, ofitti amantaa dhabuu(lack of self confidence) akkasumas of ceepheessuu fi of cinquun hanga sammuu isaatti yaada of ajjeessu qabachuu mala...bifa kanaan yaalii of ajjeesuu raawwatanii carraadhan kan hafan baay'eedha.....kan yaadni of ajjeesuu isaanii milka'eefi of ajjeesanis jiru.  

Maarree, barrafama tana yoon qopheessu namootni miira abdii kutanna keessa jiranii ija isaanii akka saaqatan fi rakkoo isaanii kallatti biraatiin akka ilaalanii fi abdii isaanii haromfachuu akka isaa dandeesisu yaaduuni.

Amid the escalating violence in the Israel-Gaza conflict, the blame game on the international stage is intensifying. The recent U.S. veto of a UN resolution calling for a cease-fire illuminated America's stance, with the U.S. Ambassador delineating a clear line of blame towards Hamas for the humanitarian crisis unfolding in Gaza. In a detailed address, the U.S. Ambassador mourned the tragic loss of life from the explosion at the Al-Ahli al-Arabi hospital in Gaza, expressing horror and sadness. Yet, the narrative swiftly pivoted to lay blame when the ambassador stated, 'Let's be clear. Hamas's own actions have brought this on â€” this severe humanitarian crisis in Gaza. Hamas has caused so much needless suffering, death, and destruction.' The U.S. viewpoint reiterating Israel's right to self-defense has drawn criticism from various quarters, pointing to the stark power disparity between Israel and Gaza, and the devastating toll on civilian life the conflict continues to take. The unfolding narrative of blame, critics argue, overshadows the humanitarian imperative to alleviate the suffering of those caught in the crossfire.

The recent conflict in Israel and Palestine is, for me, a stark reminder of the fragility of peaceful social and religious relationships, and how we should strive to keep politics separate from these as much as possible. I do not take the socioreligious harmony we have here for granted, so when I can, I try to do my very small part by participating in various religious festivals and celebrations. So I was honored last week to attend Zhun Ti Tangâ€™s Nine Emperor Godsâ€™ Ceremony, held at #Rivervale, in lieu of my colleague Chua Kheng Wee è”¡åº†å¨ (who was traveling). The proceedings lasted a good few hours, during which I learned about the origins of the various practices, including the lighting of nine lamps (one for each deity), the invitation to visit from the water, and the prop that accompanies the sedan procession. I am neither Taoist nor Buddhist, the two groups that (in Singapore) celebrate the festival. Nevertheless, I believe that the respect we confer on othersâ€™ exercise of their faithâ€”especially when they take the effort to invite you to partake in something so special to themâ€”is more important than the need to strictly adhere to oneâ€™s own religious norms. It is for this reason that, when I visit a wake, I am willing to light incense; I believe, after all, that I am honoring those not only those that have passed, but also those who remain and are in mourning. My thanks to the organizers for the invitation, and I wish them and all devotees a meaningful period of prayer and reflection for the remainder of the festival.

And Jesus said to them, â€œWhose likeness and inscription is this?â€ They said, â€œCaesarâ€™s.â€ Then he said to them, â€œTherefore render to Caesar the things that are Caesarâ€™s, and to God the things that are Godâ€™s.â€ Reflection: Although the Pharisees are primarily a religious group, they are also political nationalists who resent paying taxes to the emperor and oppose all attempts by the Romans to interfere with the Jewish way of life. MASS FOR PEACE IN THE WORLD Sunday 29th October 12 noon, Knock Basilica With so many places in the world currently being devastated by war and destruction, Knock Shrine will offer a special Mass for Peace on Sunday October 29th at 12noon. This Mass will take place in Knock Basilica and will also be streamed live on www.knockshrine.ie/:=:https://www.knockshrine.ie/ watch-live All are welcome to join with us as we pray for an end to all conflict worldwide. Prayer for Peace in Our Time O God, author and giver of peace, in whose image and likeness each of us has been created with a human dignity worthy of respect on earth and destined for eternal glory, Listen to the cry that rises from every corner of this fragile earth, from our human family torn by violent conflict: Give peace in our time, O good and gracious God, that peace which, as your Son Jesus Christ told us and as we have experienced in these days, is a peace which the world cannot give. To world leaders grant the wisdom to see beyond the boundaries of race, religion, and nation to that common humanity that makes us all your children and brothers and sisters to one another. To those who have taken up arms in anger or revenge or even in the cause of justice grant the grace of conversion to the path of peaceful dialogue and constructive collaboration. To the innocent who live in the shadow of war and terror, especially the frightened children, be a shelter and strength, their haven and hope. And to those who have already lost their lives as victims of human cruelty and chemical warfare, open wide your arms and enfold them all in the embrace of your compassion, healing, and everlasting life. Grant this through Jesus Christ, your Son, our Lord. Mary, Mother of all and Queen of peace, pray for us. - Peter J. Scagnelli

Someone knock at the door and Adesewa opened it for Nkechi to enter. â€œHow are you feeling now mama sewa?.â€ She asked sitting on the chair. â€œI am fine oo mama Chinedu, thank you so much for your care and Iâ€™m really grateful.â€ â€œItâ€™s okay (smiling) what are we family for if not to help each other.â€ She said. I brought this medication soup for you and Iâ€™m very sure it will help also.â€ â€œThank you mama Chinedu may God bless you for me.â€ Adebimpe said. â€œAmen ooo ehnâ€™ I even want to tell you something but I donâ€™t want Adesewa to be here.â€ She said and Adebimpe order sewa to excuse them. â€œSo, what is it?.â€ She asked wondering what sheâ€™s about to say. â€œYou see something mama sewa, I have wanted to this ooo but I donâ€™t know how you might react to it.â€ â€œPlease say it. I might learn one or two things from it.â€ Adebimpe answered as she drink the soup she brought. â€œIt Is about this thing that happened to you, because if by looking at things. Mama Rihannat behavior looks so glaring about what might be going on in this house. And you know how she has been behaving with us in this house.â€ She said trying to manipulate her mind to fight with faridah. â€œThank you! I know, I know that sheâ€™s the one behind my predicament. Canâ€™t you see how she feels less concerned about what happened to me? I have been wishing for my quick recovery so that I can deal with her very well. Just leave her ooo â€¦.â€ â€œEhnâ€™ehn!.â€ Nkechi shouted. â€œShe will tell me what I buy from her that she want to ki ll me before my time. She has forgotten God doesnâ€™t prosper the handwork of the enemy, she thinks she can hunt me down Never! I say Never!! Mama Chinedu. I will deal with her ehn infact she will turn to air that canâ€™t be seen again by the time I squeezed the hell out of her! .â€ â€œvery good! I will support you mama sewa! I think that day will be her last day in this house. A senior wife that canâ€™t respect herself instead of fighting her junior to the extent of casting spell ha! Mama sewa thatâ€™s just too much! If is me ehn I will break her into pieces, even if our husband tried to separate us, he will also be dealt with.â€ Nkechi said in annoyance. â€œJust donâ€™t worry, at least Iâ€™m getting better already. Common to show concern, she didnâ€™t . I know she might be plotting another way to get me, but my God is bigger than her. She will see!.â€ Adebimpe said aggressively, that one could even see her veins in line of her vibration. Nkechi told her to calm down but within her she was really happy that she is able to achieve what she wanted. â€œI hope youâ€™re hearing from your boss? Mr charms or is it Charles.â€ Nkechi asked making Adebimpe to laugh. â€œIt is Charles ooo marma Chinedu. Well, he called me this morning but I just lied to him that Iâ€™m already fine .â€ She answered. â€œEhya!.â€ Nkechi said while wondering in her mind on why he would still be calling her when her husband has warned him to abstain from Adebimpe. And the man is nice oooo.â€ She said beaming. â€œYes oo and he has been wonderful, I wonâ€™t lie.â€ Adebimpe said. â€œAnd he is married.â€ Nkechi asked smirking.â€ â€œOf (truncated)

Ik geloof dat â€˜wereldvredeâ€™ een taak is voor ons allemaal. Vrede is mÃ©Ã©r dan de afwezigheid van oorlog. Het is elkaar vinden waar verschil is. Het is liefde durven kiezen boven angst. Ieder mens draagt de kans op vrede in zich. Je kunt elk moment beginnen. Door vrede te sluiten met wie je zelf ten diepste bent. Door vrede te sluiten met je verleden en je systeem, je angsten en je pijn, je vergissingen en je verlangens. Door liefdevol te kijken, naar jezelf en anderen. Geen conflict toe te voegen waar het niet is. Te vergeven waar het wel is. Vrede betekent niet dat we allemaal hetzelfde moeten zijn; het betekent met liefde kijken naar het verschil. Ik geloof dat we dat kunnen. Misschien wel dat we het verplicht zijn aan onze kinderen om het in elk geval te proberen. Als ieder mens in vrede leeft met zichzelf, zal er vanzelf wereldvrede zal zijn. Wees lief voor elkaar. Arjan (ook namens David)

This beautiful memory popped up today. A beautiful capture from our good friend Joshua Able Photographer. For those that don't know her this is Big T from the Lamar Canyon Pack. She was born in April of 2014, her Mother was our Beloved Queen 926F, and her Father 925M, who sacrificed his own life in a conflict with a rival Pack in 2015 to save his mate 926F, Big T, her siblings, and unborn pups that 926F was carrying. Big T is also the Granddaughter of our namesake The "06" Female and her Grandfather was our Silver King 755M. Big T got her nickname because of the big white triangle she had on her chest, just as her sister Little T because her white triangle was little. Some wolves aren't collared so photographers and wolf watchers give wolves nicknames so they can identify them when seen. In 2016 The Lamar Canyon Pack had a bad case of mange, some wolves in the pack with just a little bit, while others in the pack had it worse. Big T was one that had very bad mange, she had dispersed a few times from the Pack, and was never seen again. It's more than likely she died from the mange especially if she was alone, it takes a lot of strength and nutrition to heal from mange and would be hard for her to hunt. But we will never know what really happened to Big T. For me it's harder to not know what has happened to a wolf compared to actually knowing what happened to them. I hope wherever Big T's final resting place was that she is now at Peace. Thank you again Joshua Able, Photographer for this beautiful memory of Big T in Soda Butte Valley. She was a beautiful soul and she will be forever in my heart.. Legends Never Die... Goodnight and Sweet Dreams Everyone, see you all tomorrow in the Valley of Wolves, where Spirits run free and if you listen closely you can hear their Howls echo in the wind...ğŸ’œğŸ’œğŸ’œ ~ Bev and The 06 Legacy Crew #HowlForLife #RelistWolves #RelistWolvesNow #BeAWolfWarrior

It's Wolf Awareness Week and what a special memory to share with you today. Every Wolf has a story and this is the story of a Wolf They Called Uncle Mottled.. When I think of this wolf, it makes my heart smile, he was one of those wolves that made his way into your heart and forever stayed in it. Mottled was from the Prospect Peak Pack, he and his 3 brothers were involved in the death of Lamar Canyon Pack Alpha Male 925M, and came calling on 926F one day. 926F had major decisions to make, she either raises her pups and unborn pups alone or she tries to recruit these males that came calling. 926F faced these Males head on and started wagging her tail to show her friendly side, it worked, she won these males over and accepted them into her Pack. Twin became her Alpha male and Mottled became the Beta. Mottled took his Beta position very seriously. The six eleven month old pups left the pack for some time on a walk about through the park, 926F had per pups with the help of the Males. Five pups were born and became the Legacy Five Pups. Mottled treated those pups as if they were his very own, he played with them, protected them, feed them and sang his songs to them, he became Uncle Mottled. On several occasions Uncle Mottled proved his loyalty to 926F and the pups. When the Mollie Pack came into Lamar territory Uncle Mottled sprung into action to protect the pups, he was chased by the Mollie Alpha Female leading her away from the pups, he got several bites but he was ok and returned to the Pack. Another time the Wolf Project was out in the red helicopter collaring wolves, they saw Uncle Mottled and I can still remember the video I saw at the time, the helicopter was chasing him but Uncle Mottled was having none of that and he ran so fast away from the chopper, he ran toward the pups to make sure they were ok while his brothers Dark Black and the Alpha Twin got collared. Uncle Mottled went into Alpha mode, the Beta's of the Pack will do this until the Alpha Male returns. Uncle Mottled escaped getting collared that day. Uncle Mottled sang many songs and one of his songs was "don't cross the road there's monsters on it", it was a song Uncle Mottled sang a lot, he did not like the roads, the cars or the people. When the rest of the pack would cross the roads and Uncle Mottled wasn't sure about crossing he would sing his song, and Alpha Male Twin would come and get Uncle Mottled and cross the road with him, the pups also learned Uncle Mottled's songs. During 2016 The Lamar Canyon Pack went through many hardships and losses, it was really a rough year. One day the Junction Butte Pack came calling on the Lamar's and all hell broke lose. The Lamar Canyon Pack was separated and Uncle Mottled put his life in jeopardy to save the pups. That was the last time Uncle Mottled was ever seen. The next day the Wolf Project hiked up to where the conflict happened but no sign of Uncle Mottled anywhere. It is presumed that Uncle Mottled died that day sacrificing his life to save the pups he loved so much. I have always thought in my heart that Uncle Mottled was still alive somewhere, they never found his body, he just disappeared and in the Wolf World anything is possible. Uncle Mottled will always have a special place in my heart, he loved his Lamar family so much and they all loved him. At first I didn't know if I would even like these Males considering that they were responsible for 925M's death, but to love wolves and to be a Voice and Advocate for them you have to take the good with the bad, I realized that 925M was trying to protect his family and Uncle Mottled and his brothers were trying to protect their territory, they each did what wolves are suppose to do. Uncle Mottled was a Beautiful Soul and will always be loved and missed. Photo Credit to Laura Tatum-Cowen..Thank you so much Laura Tatum-Cowen for the beautiful capture and memory of Uncle Mottled Happy Friday Everyone ğŸ’œğŸ’œğŸ’œ ~ Bev and The 06 Legacy Crew #HowlForLife #RelistWolves #RelistWolvesNow #BeAWolfWarrior

An estimated 5,000 worshippers gathered at Parry Park Lakemba earlier this afternoon to offer their Jumu'ah prayer for the people of Palestine. The event was put together by the LMA in collaboration with a number of other masjids and religious organisations in light of the recent conflict in Gaza. The LMA took the almost unprecedented step of moving Jumuâ€™ah from our iconic Lakemba Mosque to nearby Parry Park to cater for the anticipated huge crowd and our expectations were well and truly met. Lakemba Mosque Imam Sheikh Yahya Safi (Arabic) and Sheikh Wesam Charkawi (English) delivered the khutbahs and spoke passionately about the oppression being suffered by our Palestinian brothers and sisters at the hands of the tyrants. Their words were eloquently supported by our other speakers Abraham Zoabi, Sheikh Ahmed Abdo and Siddiq Buckley. A sincere thank you to our community for their attendance today and for their exceptional generosity as a substantial amount was raised by our charity arm Feed The World. We give our absolute commitment that all funds raised will go towards this most worthy of causes: our beautiful brothers and sisters in Gaza.

Large-scale art installation at Stowe Gardens near Buckingham. Visitors to Stowe between 19 October and 14 November this year will be able to walk amongst the silhouettes of 200 life-size soldiers in the historic landscape gardens. This moving statement of commemoration, remembrance and honour offers visitors space to reflect and connect within the natural landscape around Octagon Lake. Here are 8 powerful lessons from the book Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know About the People We Don't Know 1.We have a default to truth. This means that we assume that the people we are talking to are honest. This is a good thing in general, but it can make us vulnerable to deception. 2.We are bad at detecting liars. Studies have shown that people are only about 50/50 at detecting whether someone is lying. This is because it is very difficult to tell whether someone is lying based on their body language or facial expressions. 3.We are susceptible to confirmation bias. This means that we tend to seek out and interpret information in a way that confirms our existing beliefs. This can make it difficult to have objective conversations with people who have different beliefs than us. 4.We are prone to misattribution of blame. This means that we tend to blame people for things that are beyond their control. For example, if a police officer shoots an unarmed person, we may blame the police officer for being racist or trigger-happy. However, it is important to remember that people are often acting in ways that they believe are necessary, even if those actions are harmful. 5.We are susceptible to the coupling effect. This means that we tend to judge a person's actions based on our understanding of their character. For example, if we believe that someone is a good person, we are more likely to excuse their bad behavior. 6.We are bad at understanding people from different cultures. This is because we tend to project our own cultural values and assumptions onto others. This can lead to misunderstandings and conflict. 7.We are susceptible to the power of belief. This means that our beliefs can have a powerful impact on our behavior. For example, if we believe that we are going to fail at a task, we are more likely to fail. 8.We need to be humble about our ability to understand strangers. We should always be open to the possibility that we are wrong about someone, and we should be willing to listen to their perspective. These are just a few of the many powerful lessons that can be learned from Malcolm Gladwell's book Talking to Strangers. It is a must-read for anyone who wants to better understand the challenges and opportunities of interacting with strangers. Buffalo Bill Cody and Sitting Bull (TÈŸatÈŸÃ¡Å‹ka Ãyotake). When people think of Buffalo Bill Cody, they often get caught up on two historical fallacies. The first is that Bill Cody was a horrific slaughterer of the American bison, otherwise known as the buffalo. The second is that his participation in the near-extermination event of the buffalo was driven by genocidal urges and federal dollars to deny Native American tribes their primary food source in hopes of eliminating them entirely. I see this interpretation of Cody's buffalo hunting days a lot, but I don't believe it is entirely accurate. William F. Cody hunted bison to feed the westward expansion of the railroad, but only for about 18 months. By the end of 1869, he worked full-time as a scout for the Army at Fort McPherson. During those 18 months, he earned a reputation as a great buffalo hunter, but he didnâ€™t stand on a distant hill with a high-powered rifle and a looking glass, picking off docile creatures with no danger to himself. Bill Cody hunted the same way the Sioux, Cheyenne, and Pawnee did. He rode his horse towards a herd, separated the animal he would harvest, and ran alongside it until he could get the best shot possible. Cody killed a few animals at a time and brought them back to be used to feed the men working on expanding the railroad west. Despite what many think, he was never a hide hunter and never slaughtered buffalo indiscriminately for either the choice cuts (tongue and loin) or their hides. By 1873, when desperate economic times made hide hunting more attractive, Buffalo Bill and Texas Jack had left the prairies of Nebraska and the herds of buffalo that roamed it behind to become successful (and quite wealthy) actors. They would occasionally return west to hunt but were never again a significant factor in the decline of the bison. As part of his job as a scout, Buffalo Bill was involved with several altercations with Miniconjou, Lakota, Brule, Cheyenne, etc. Still, he never set out to murder Native Americans or to eliminate the bison, the staple of their diet, directly. That said, Bill Cody did kill multiple Native American men in conflict, and those incidents, especially his combat with and killing of Yellow Hair, were inflated and magnified in dime novels and on stage. He became a legendary "Indian fighter" more because of the legend than the reality. Cody, like the Native people he fought against, knew that when they went to war someone was going to kill and someone was going to be killed. Each man fought desperately to ensure that he was the former, and though they were enemies, each man held a measure of respect for his adversary. Likewise, Texas Jack was involved in conflicts with Sioux, Cheyenne, and Comanche warriors and developed a reputation as an "Indian fighter" despite having warm relations with the Pawnee tribe, joining them on their summer buffalo hunt in 1872, writing warmly about them in national publications, and being requested personally to join them by Pawnee head chief Pitaresaru (Chief of Men). Texas Jack also involved Cayuse native Donald McKay and his wife and daughter in his show well before Buffalo Bill ever brought Sioux into his Wild West shows. Whatever failing Cody exhibited in his younger life in regard to Native Americans must be contrasted with his later life. His inclusion of Lakota in his Wild West show, including Sitting Bull himself, allowed them to travel, but more importantly, to maintain and display their ceremonial dances and customs at a time when they were prevented by the United States government and Army from holding their religious ceremonies on the reservations. Cody paid the Native men and women in his show the same as he did the white cowboys, treated them fairly, kept families together, and was regarded as a warm friend by a great many of the Lakota that traveled with him. Over time, Buffalo Bill Cody became a stalwart advocate for Native peoples and their rights. In the same way, Codyâ€™s inclusion of the bison in his Wild West shows made sure that spectators at the shows were endeared to the animals. Over time, they became a symbol of not just the Wild West, but of America writ large. Because the hundreds of thousands of people who saw the bison in Buffalo Billâ€™s Wild West now cared about the animals, they supported conservation movements that brought them back from the brink of extinction. The man who earned his name as a buffalo hunter became one of the primary forces in their survival. Cody publicly blamed most of the trouble between white men and Native tribes on the white men. He said that: "In nine cases out of ten where there is trouble between white men and Indians, it will be found that the white man is responsible Indians expect a man to keep his word. They can't understand how a man can lie." Dr. George Kingsley, who hunted with Cody and Omohundro, wrote that â€œ[Buffalo Bill and Texas Jack] have a sympathy and a tenderness toward the Indians infinitely (truncated)

In interpersonal relations, a proxy conflict refers to a situation where two individuals or groups are involved in a conflict that is not directly related to the issue at hand but is instead influenced or fueled by external factors or hidden agendas. In other words, it is a conflict that is fought indirectly through someone else or through unrelated issues. Here's an example to illustrate this concept: Let's say there are two coworkers, Alice and Bob, who have a strained relationship. The root cause of their conflict might be a disagreement over a work-related project. However, rather than addressing the project issue directly, Alice and Bob start using proxy tactics. They may involve other colleagues, spread rumors, or manipulate situations to gain support or undermine each other's reputation. In this case, the conflict between Alice and Bob becomes a proxy conflict because it is being fought through third parties or by diverting attention to unrelated matters. The actual disagreements and tensions are displaced onto others, creating a web of indirect conflicts. Proxy conflicts often arise due to underlying dynamics such as power struggles, personal insecurities, or past grievances. Individuals may use proxy tactics to save face, manipulate perceptions, or avoid direct confrontation. However, these tactics can create further misunderstandings, escalate tensions, and hinder the resolution of the original conflict. Recognizing a proxy conflict is important in order to address the core issues and find constructive ways to resolve the conflict. By identifying the hidden agendas, understanding the underlying emotions, and encouraging open communication, individuals can work towards resolving conflicts more effectively and promoting healthier interpersonal relationships.

Sea of Nightmare: added a check to prevent initiating combat while a crystal break cutscene is playing - Sunken Ruins: moved the stone activation cutscene to trigger after opening the chest rather than after beating the boss, to fix rare occurrences of it not activating when completed before Elysan'darÃ«lle - Adjusted raft collisions in Half-Sunken Tower area - Adjusted collisions in Moraine's office (Zenith Academy) - Added a check to properly reset gravity modules in Forbidden Cavern's room to the right - Fixed a rare softlock which could happen when triggering an encounter with a scripted cutscene intro while a follower isn't done bouncing from a graplou strike - Adjusted collisions on Skybase's pushable blocks - Added detection to prevent the player from getting stuck when using the graplou to move up a slope - Fleshmancer's Lair: added a check to super prevent the teleporter from being used while camping - Adjusted collisions in X'tol's Landing - Adjusted collisions in one of the Molekin houses - Sacrosanct Spires: added a check to prevent triggering the sealed entrance's cutscene while camping - Adjusted collisions in Antsudlo's entrance - Adjusted collisions in Clockwork Castle's clock tower section to prevent an issue when players could get stuck - Fixed null ref that would occur when attempting to browse when the level up screen only shows one option - Adjusted a puzzle in Derelict Factory to remove the player's ability to lock themselves in and remain stuck - Fixed possible softlock in Solstice Shrine #4's puzzle - Added a check to disable interaction with the world map's docks while transitioning to camping to prevent softlocks caused by conflicting transitions - Fleshmancer's Lair: fixed softlock that could occur with the eyeballs puzzle due to physics - Fixed an issue that could occur when collision with an enemy while zipping through a propulsion gate (Antsudlo, Air Skyland) - Trek to center: adjusted triggers to prevent a rare occurrence of bad zoning when jumping down - Updated level loading code to include more null ref checks - Fixed a softlock that could occur when an enemy would play its attack animation while in hurt state - Added a check to prevent duplication of Malkomud and Rockie's sprites when they both get KO'd at the same time - Fixed a softlock that could occur when reentering the Golden Pelican after being teleported out - Infinite Abyss: fixed a softlock in Dweller of Dread's encounter that demanded a very specific setup and sequence of party composition, KO states, and boss attacks - Added a check to prevent softlock when an encounter is triggered while the player is zoning or teleporting - Flooded Graveyard: fixed a crash that could occur when using the graplou specifically on the climb wall in the chapel from the second floor - Fixed an issue where the paincone projectile could get pooled before reaching its target when running the game at very high fps - Updated combat management to prevent targets that have left the encounter from checking against damage zones (i.e. fixing a softlock when defeating Romaya with conflagrate while she's on the bone pillar, who will now instead be properly immune to damage in this situation) - Fixed softlocks that could occur in certain areas depending on party composition - Fixed an inventory glitch regarding Antsudlo's pearls - Fixed an reported issue where Garl would be remain deactivated when swapping party members before reconvening in the Humble Boast's Kitchen - Fixed an issue where Antsuldo could be entered too early, causing an improper state on the big door - Added a check to update save files ensuring they are compatible with latest fixes - Retro actively added Cerulean Expanse story artifact to those who missed it prior to the fix - Reimported text in all languages to include all pending updates

And I think it's a good thing to take the subject a little more general so that everyone can find themselves there. What we must keep in mind is to prioritize the health and lives of civilians because I think it is the most important."

Days after Hamas terrorists massacred 1,400+ Israelis in southern Israel, Alaa, an Israeli-Arab who owns a bicycle shop in Tayibe, donated 50 bicycles to Jewish families evacuated from communities near the Gaza border to Tzur Yitzhak, where Alaa lives. When Hamas supporters in Tayibe found out, they went to Alaa's store at 2 AM, looted it, and burned it to the ground. The perpetrators also tried calling Alaa during the attack to lure him to the store. Alaa isn't sure if he'll reopen his bicycle shop, but if he does, it won't be in Tayibe â€” he's afraid to be there now. An Israeli-led crowdfunding effort has raised more than 650,000 NIS ($160,000) for Alaa so far. This is not a conflict between Arabs and Jews: it's a fight against Iran-backed terrorism.

We are deeply saddened and shocked by the loss of lives at Al Ahli Hospital in Gaza. The civilian casualties resulting from the ongoing Gaza conflict are a matter of serious and continuing concern to us. It is disheartening to witness the suffering and loss that so many innocent individuals and families on both sides are enduring as a consequence of this conflict. We convey our deepest condolences to the families of the victims and offer our heartfelt prayers for the swift recovery of those who were injured. In such challenging times, we must remember our shared responsibility to protect the lives and well-being of civilians. Amidst the escalation of violence, we urge all parties involved to prioritize the safety and security of civilians above all else. It is our sincere hope that the conflict is resolved and peace is established.

Happy 79th Leyte Landing Anniversary! ğŸ‡µğŸ‡­ Today, we celebrate the historical landing of General Douglas MacArthur and the Allied forces in Leyte Gulf, marking the beginning of the campaign to recapture and liberate the Philippines from Japanese occupation on October 20, 1944. This event led to the largest naval battle of World War II, as well as the world's largest naval battle in terms of gross tonnage sunk, and it ultimately resulted in Japan's defeat and surrender after nearly three years of conflict. The war memorial is situated in the municipality of Palo on Leyte Island in Eastern Visayas and stands as one of the region's major tourist attractions. It was officially designated as a national park on July 12, 1977, through Letter of Instructions No. 572 signed by President Ferdinand Marcos. (Source: Wiki)

NATIVE AMERICANS â€“ THE FIRST OWNERS OF AMERICA Native Americans, or the indigenous peoples of the Americas, are the pre-Columbian inhabitants of North and South America and their descendants. Those who live within the boundaries of the present-day United States are composed of numerous, distinct tribes, bands and ethnic groups, many of which survive as intact, sovereign nations. Most authorities agree that the first evidence of people inhabiting North America indicates that they migrated here from Eurasia over 13,000 years ago, most likely crossing along the Bering Land Bridge, which was in existence during the Ice Age. However, some historians believe that people had migrated into the Americas much earlier, up to 40,000 years ago. These early Paleo-Indians spread throughout the Americas, diversifying into many hundreds of culturally distinct nations and tribes. Application of the term â€œIndianâ€ originated with Christopher Columbus, who, in his search for Asia, thought that he had arrived in the East Indies. However, there is considerable evidence in support of successful explorations which led to Norse settlement of Greenland, the Lâ€™Anse aux Meadows settlement in Newfoundland, and potentially others some 500 years prior to Columbus landing in the Bahamas. From the Native American aspect, many tribesâ€™ oral histories indicate they have been living here since their genesis, as described by a wide range of creation myths. By the time European adventurers arrived in the 15th century, scholars estimate that more than 50 million people were already living in the Americas. Of these, some 10 million lived in the region that would later become the United States. As time passed, these migrants and their descendants pushed south and east, adapting as they went. With these new arrivals came centuries of conflict and adjustment between Old and New World societies. Today, Native Americans account for about 1.5 percent of the United States population, many of whom continue to take pride in their ancestral traditions â€” still practicing the music, art, and ceremonies that took place many years ago.

The Holy Spirit is realistic about our failings. He gently points out our mistakes and sins, and helps us to change. At times He may powerfully convict us, but He never condemns us. This realism about the continual struggle of Christians against sin is presented forcefully in the New Testament. In Hebrews 3:13 the writer says: "Exhort one another daily ... lest any of you be hardened through the deceitfulness of sin." Again in Hebrews 12:1 the writer speaks about "the sin which so easily ensnares us." And in verse 4 he says, "You have not yet resisted to bloodshed, striving against sin." Dealing with sin is a life-and-death struggle. It is not shameful to acknowledge that sin is still at work in our lives. On the contrary, our great danger lies in refusing to acknowledge it, which leaves us unprepared to resist temptations when they do come. If the Holy Spirit were to wait until we are perfect to take up His dwelling within us, it would be like a professor saying to his students, "I'll start teaching you when you have passed your exams." His students would respond, "But professor, that's not what we need! We need you to start teaching us now, so we'll learn what we need to pass our exams." It is now that we need the Holy Spirit, so that we may have His help available to us continually to overcome the power of evil and to attain to God's standard of holiness. One particular area of conflict in which we need the Holy Spirit's help is in dealing with demons. The Holy Spirit does not withhold His help if He discerns that there are demons within us. On the contrary, He sees our need more clearly than we do ourselves, and He empowers us to expel them. Because He has compassion on us, He is willing to take up His dwelling within us, and to work with us to establish Christ's victory over all the power of the enemy. Our progress depends on the degree to which we cooperate with the Holy Spirit within us. Let me emphasize once again: The Holy Spirit does not come to indwell us because we are already perfect. He comes to help us so that we may become perfect. Certainly the Holy Spirit will not help us in our struggle with demons if we intend to continue living in sin. But if we recognize our sins and sincerely repent, He will fight with us against the demons that enslave us. With His help we will be able to expel them and be set free. - Derek Prince ( They Shall Expel Demons ) - @JESUS SAVES TV

The escalating tensions in the Gaza Strip is worrying, and incidents in the recent days has shaken us. Itâ€™s the footages of the children that break me, to have their innocence and lives lost in mere moments. No man, woman or child should undergo such a tragedy, no matter what faith you believe in. The Singapore Muslim community has been holding mass prayers for peace in Gaza. The prayers started yesterday and will continue across the various mosques in Singapore over the weekend. Thousands have turned up, young and old. Tonight, I prayed shoulder-to-shoulder with several hundreds more in Masjid Sultan. We prayed for peace, and for this conflict to resolve peacefully. Many have written to me, asking what they can do to help beyond just watching the events unfurl online. This humanitarian crisis has impacted Singaporeans, regardless of race or religion. I'm heartened to know that the Rahmatan Lil Alamin Foundation (RLAF), in collaboration with the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), is organising a fundraising appeal to provide aid in the form of health, relief and shelter for communities affected by the recent developments in Gaza. 'Rahmatan Lil Alamin' means to be a blessing to all. In this same spirit, I call upon fellow Singaporeans of all faiths and races to help raise funds for all in Gaza. Tonight, and the nights that follow, hug your loved ones a little longer. Many families in Gaza have lost their loved ones forever. I stand in solidarity for Peace and Aid for all in Gaza. #PeaceAidforall #Gaza

HALO Sri Lanka was delighted to welcome Anne-Marie Trevelyan MP, Minister of Indo-Pacific, Ben Mellor, Director for India and Indian Ocean Directorate, and Andrew Patrick, British High Commissioner for Sri Lanka, from British High Commission Colombo at our location in Muhamalai. We shared the impact of our mechanical clearance efforts in Muhamalaiâ€”the largest and densest minefield in Sri Lanka. HALO began work here in 2012 and has successfully found and destroyed over 250,000 explosive devices, including almost 75,000 anti-personnel mines. Our visitors met Nadarsa Sugirthan and his family, who were forced to flee their village in 1996 due to fighting. When HALO began clearing the minefield that encompassed Sugirthanâ€™s land, a total of 1,305 explosives were discovered, including 810 anti-personnel mines. In 2020, the Nadarsa family was able to return to their ancestral land after 24 years of displacement. They can now live and work without fear and are building a more secure future together. Jenisha, Sugirthan's wife, works on the land to rear poultry, which serves as an additional source of income for the family by selling eggs and meat. Thank you to Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office for supporting our work to clear mines and explosives, ensuring the safety of local families and enabling people who were displaced by conflict to return home.

BREAKING: 33 MPs call for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza! The Canada-Palestine Parliamentary Friendship, with 33 MPs from multiple political parties, has sent a letter to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau demanding that Canada support an immediate ceasefire to save innocent civilian lives in Gaza. "The longer this conflict goes on, the more innocent civilians will pay with their lives. We demand that Canada join the growing international call for an immediate ceasefire. Canada must act before more innocent children are killed." "We further call on Canada to do all in its power to facilitate the opening of a humanitarian corridor so that badly needed humanitarian aid supplies can reach the innocent Palestinian people." CJPME thanks these MPs for adding their voice. We demand a ceasefire now!

Sa mahigpit na pagpapatupad ng mga awtoridad sa EO 70 o National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict, kusang sumuko si alyas Batman sa mga awotiridad pasado alas-onse ng umaga ng nabanggit na araw. So many times, our loved ones pass unexpectedly, or we donâ€™t get to speak to them before they passed, leaving you with the question: Are they mad at me? The answer is no, not at all; they love you. Please know that if you have had an unresolved conflict or a disagreement with someone that had passed, they hold no grudges, just unconditional love. Iâ€™m half Palestinian. One of my best friends is half Jewish (top left) We both have relatives in the conflict zone. I care about the safety of his family. He cares about the safety of mine. Both of us were born in the United States and grew up with little opportunity to connect with this part of our heritage. I was adopted and only just a few years ago found out my biological father and that whole side of my family is Palestinian. It led to me meeting some of my blood relatives for the very first time. I think this conflict is difficult for both of us in the sense of identity. On one hand, we were not raised in the cultures of our people...and yet in recent years, we have embarked on our own separate journeys to connect with the culture and history of our ancestors. He would take a bullet for me and I would take a bullet for him. But we wonder how things would be if we were raised differently. Would we be able to get along during this time? Maybe in a different world, we might even see each other on opposite sides of a battlefield? The point of this post is not about â€œtaking sidesâ€. I see many people putting a spotlight on the violence and bloodshed that has taken place and continues to take place. I think the point is maybe hope?... hope of co-existing? Itâ€™s so hard to see all this death. There are aunties, uncles and even siblings Iâ€™ve never met yet who I worry I might never get a chance to meet. I wonâ€™t pretend to be an expert on the Middle East. But what I do know is this...when you take away the titles. â€œPalestinianâ€ â€œJewishâ€....thatâ€™s what me and Sam are. Thatâ€™s a truth. But our other truth is that we consider each other brothers...not by blood...but by the love and respect we have for each other as HUMAN BEINGSâ€¦and I just feel like thatâ€™s getting lost in all of this.

Graduation ceremony at Nehale lyaMpingana Barracks celebrates military excellence Staff Reporter THE Army Battle School at Nehale lyaMpingana Barracks was a scene of celebration and achievement on the 13th of October as it hosted a joint graduation ceremony for four significant military courses. These courses, the 11th Company Group Commanders Course, the 14th Platoon Commanders Course, the Platoon Sergeant Course, and the Section Commander's Course, aimed to equip students with essential knowledge in both Conventional Warfare and Low-Intensity Conflict Operations. The ceremony was officiated by Brigadier General Andreas Diyeve, the Deputy Army Commander, and he extended his heartfelt congratulations to the graduates for their outstanding performances throughout the demanding training. General Diyeve emphasized the vital role these programs play in developing a highly trained military force. In his address, the Deputy Army Commander stressed the cornerstone of success for all armed forces: training. He encouraged graduates at all levels and soldiers alike to cultivate a culture of continuous learning. He underlined the significance of prioritizing training to ensure that the defence force remains fully prepared to fulfil its national mandate in accordance with the laws of the Republic of Namibia. General Diyeve noted, "It is, therefore, of paramount importance that all commanders and uniformed personnel prioritize training." Expressing his gratitude, the General acknowledged the Course Officers, Instructors, and all supporting staff for their unwavering dedication and commitment to imparting valuable knowledge and innovations to the members. Their contributions played a pivotal role in the success of the graduates. Notably, the students who completed these courses came from all branches of the Namibian Defence Force (NDF): The Army, Air Force, and Namibian Navy. This joint graduation ceremony symbolized the unity and shared commitment of the entire NDF to empower the next generation of military leaders.

text: Native Americans â€“ The First Owners of America Native Americans, or the indigenous peoples of the Americas, are the pre-Columbian inhabitants of North and South America and their descendants. Those who live within the boundaries of the present-day United States are composed of numerous, distinct tribes, bands and ethnic groups, many of which survive as intact, sovereign nations. Most authorities agree that the first evidence of people inhabiting North America indicates that they migrated here from Eurasia over 13,000 years ago, most likely crossing along the Bering Land Bridge, which was in existence during the Ice Age. However, some historians believe that people had migrated into the Americas much earlier, up to 40,000 years ago. These early Paleo-Indians spread throughout the Americas, diversifying into many hundreds of culturally distinct nations and tribes. Application of the term â€œIndianâ€ originated with Christopher Columbus, who, in his search for Asia, thought that he had arrived in the East Indies. However, there is considerable evidence in support of successful explorations which led to Norse settlement of Greenland, the Lâ€™Anse aux Meadows settlement in Newfoundland, and potentially others some 500 years prior to Columbus landing in the Bahamas. From the Native American aspect, many tribesâ€™ oral histories indicate they have been living here since their genesis, as described by a wide range of creation myths. By the time European adventurers arrived in the 15th century, scholars estimate that more than 50 million people were already living in the Americas. Of these, some 10 million lived in the region that would later become the United States. As time passed, these migrants and their descendants pushed south and east, adapting as they went. With these new arrivals came centuries of conflict and adjustment between Old and New World societies. Today, Native Americans account for about 1.5 percent of the United States population, many of whom continue to take pride in their ancestral traditions â€” still practicing the music, art, and ceremonies that took place many years ago.

My passion on this subject is derived from having visited Auschwitz at 15 and truly internalised the message â€˜never againâ€™. It is starkly clear to me that violence against civilians is never the conflict resolution technique that those in power think it is. Trauma remains in our bodies and hearts for generations, and the trauma in the eyes of every child in Gaza and Israel shatters my heart because I know it will remain with them forever. This is not an issue that should be considered controversial. Please take a moment to imagine that those of us taking a stand are doing so because we care about HUMANS and wish to stand on a side of history that allows us to sleep at night. That said, the messages of support have been even more plentiful. And tend to be from those with far more at stake in the conflict, Palestinians and Israelis alike. So please, if you have a platform and a voice, and the only thing youâ€™re afraid of is losing a few followers, donâ€™t remain quiet. HMCSâ€™ AFTERCARE PROGRAMME VISITS EX-OFFENDERS IN MAPHUNGWANE AND BOYANE Yesterday, the Correctional Servicesâ€™ Rehabilitation, Reintegration and Aftercare programme visited three ex-inmates who were successfully reintegrated into their communities after being released from incarceration. They have since ventured into farming, through the skills they acquired whilst serving time at our centres. They have been praised by their communities as reformed individuals who make positive contributions towards the development of their communities and the economy. The ex-offenders expressed appreciation to the Commissioner General for allowing them to be part of the vocational programme that imparts skills to offenders in farming, building, welding, carpentry, plumbing and painting amongst other trades. HMCSâ€™ vocational programmes are aimed at bridging the skills gap in order to enhance ex-offendersâ€™ prospects of employability as well as making them self-sustainable post-incarceration. The ex-offenders also thanked their families and various people who have helped them to start their business. The Commissioner General LaMakhosini Phindile Dlamini said the introduction of vocational education and training as part of offender rehabilitation offers those in conflict with the law opportunities to learn new skills that would help sustain them after serving their sentences. She said this would also increase the likelihood of successful reintegration into their communities and help reduce the risk of recidivism.

[Israel/Gaza] Several eminent Jewish jurists have written a moving piece on the Hamas attack on Israel, and the Israeli response which is ongoing. It is a clear moral statement. ----- Financial Times (www.ft.com:=:https://www.ft.com/) The laws of war must guide Israelâ€™s response to Hamas atrocity We write as Jews, many of us with family and friends directly affected by the tragedy that has befallen Israel. Like so many others, the vile crimes perpetrated by Hamas in Israel have shaken us to our core. We also write in our capacity as lawyers. We do so because, instilled with our Jewish values, we believe that law, and the adherence to the rule of law, provide an invaluable guide to begin to make sense of what we are witnessing and to provide a path to govern responses to it. In these darkest of days, we write to emphasise the importance of international law as a guide to all. Three points bear emphasis. First, the despicable actions of Hamas are not simply a moral outrage but an egregious violation of all norms of international law. The murder of hundreds of civilians in cold blood, and the range of other atrocities committed are, without doubt, crimes against humanity. They are also war crimes, indeed they amount to the most grave form of breaches of the Geneva Conventions. So too, the taking of hostages â€” it will surprise no one that grabbing terrified young children, holding them in captivity and using them as pawns in a gruesome form of negotiation is a gross violation of all applicable legal standards. To be clear, there are no possible defences to these crimes â€” whatever the context, there is no room for legal, let alone moral, equivocation when it comes to (for example) the slaughter of hundreds of young people enjoying a party. Second, Israel has a clear right in international law to respond in self-defence, indeed like all states it has a duty to defend its citizens. Its international borders have been breached by a paramilitary force and its civilians brutally murdered and subjected to severe atrocities. It also has a clear right to seek justice for the crimes that have been committed on its soil, not simply against those captured by Israeli forces but against the Hamas organisation itself and those who enable its military operations. Third, just as international law provides the means for categorising and criminalising the barbaric acts of Hamas, so too does it provide a framework for governing how Israel must respond. Any nation, conducting any armed conflict, no matter what the provocation, is bound in law to comply with all the â€œlaws of warâ€. The laws of war are not pacifist. Rather, they are the opposite â€” they are an admission that there are occasions when war is necessary. They are designed to ensure that when war must be conducted, there are limits on what harm can be done to other human beings. As the leading Israeli lawyer Michael Sfard describes it, they represent humanityâ€™s renunciation of the pacifist idea of a complete prohibition on the use of force in exchange for rules protecting basic humanity. These laws apply irrespective of the level of outrageous conduct of an enemy and no exceptions to those rules can be derived from the level of suffering caused by Hamasâ€™s actions. There are some aspects of Israelâ€™s response that already cause significant concern. International law forbids sieges of civilian populations. Gaza is home to some 2mn fellow human beings (almost half of whom are children) and it would be a grave violation of international law to hold them under siege and while doing so deprive them of basic necessities such as food and water. To be clear, collective punishment is prohibited by the laws of war. Equally, international law requires combatants to ensure minimum destruction to civilian life and infrastructure. An intent to cause indiscriminate damage, rather than behaving in a precise manner to minimise damage would, if established, constitute a grave violation of international law. In the conduct of any military campaign, politicians and commanders alike must be careful to ensure that their words do not imply to their troops that the laws of war can be disregarded, nor employ language whose effect is to dehumanise a civilian population. In these early days when emotions are so understandably raw, many might be reluctant to remind Israel of its international law obligations, considering to do so insensitive or inappropriate. However, we disagree. In these times of pain and terror the notion that there are laws that we must all live by is challenging but essential. Jewish history teaches us that we cannot give up on them. Lord Neuberger, Former President of the UK Supreme Court Professor Philippe Sands KC Professor Sandra Fredman, University of Oxford Richard Hermer KC Danny Friedman KC Anthony Metzer KC Jon Turner KC Adam Wagner -----

In remarks at a press conference with his German counterpart, Ayman Safadi said the war would have "catastrophic repercussions" and urged "protecting the region from the danger of its expansion". "All the indications are that the worst is coming.. The catastrophe will have painful consequences in coming periods," Safadi said, adding that diplomatic efforts were not yielding any results in ending the conflict. Fears of a widening war also cast a shadow on a meeting between Jordan's King Abdullah and Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on Thursday in Cairo. In a statement after the meeting, the two leaders said they rejected forcibly displacing Palestinians and that Israel was "imposing collective punishment" on the inhabitants of Gaza by bombing civilians after the Hamas attack. The conflict has stirred long-standing fears in Jordan, home to a large population of Palestinian refugees and their descendants, that a wider conflagration would give Israel the chance to implement a transfer policy to expel Palestinians en masse from the West Bank. Jordan, which shares a border with the West Bank, absorbed the bulk of Palestinians who fled or were driven out of their homes when Israel was created. | via Reuters

HARDEST DECISION Hi PSF, sana mapili mo tong sulat ko hehe, itago mo na lang ako sa pangalan na (Stella) at sana makakuha ako ng advice sa lahat ng makakabasa neto at pati na rin sayo. Ako po ay 18 yrs old na, first yr college sa kursong marketing management. Maayos ang aking pag aaral kahit nagbboyfriend ako, 1yr and 7 months na kmi, sya yung tipo ng lalake na kung magmahal ay todo kumbaga 'B4LIW' sakin lg daw sya naging ganon, and ako lang din kasi ang tumagal sa kanya kaya siguro ganon na lang sya magmahal sakin. Same kaming nag aaral pero sa hirap ng buhay ng pamilya nya nakatigil sya, kaya high school pa lang sya ngayon dahil ilang taon syang tumigil sa pag aaral para lang mas piliin magtrabaho para may makain ang pamilya nya, sya yung tipo ng tao na mas uunahin ang iba bago ang sarili. So yung conflict dito sa loob at tagal ng relasyon namin dumadating kami sa point na pag maghihiwalay, at sasabihin nya sa akin na mag ssuicid3 sya, kaya imbes na makikipag hiwalay ako hindi na lang. Paulit ulit ang sinario nmin na ganon, kaya habang tumatagal nafefell out of love ako sa mga ganon nyang pananalita sakin, lalo na pag may kasalanan sya or may matindi kaming pag aaway gusto nya mapagbibigyan yung gusto nya, kaya di ko alam kung tama paba to. Enopen ko nman sa knya na ayoko ng ganon, kaya sana pakinggan at erespeto nya rin yung desisyon ko. pede po ba hihingi ng advice ano ba ang dapat kong gawin para ma solve ko ang suliranin ko/namin sa relasyon namin, sobrang hirap na rin po kase ako parang pinipilit ko na lang na mag stay sa kanya, pero wala nakong nararamdaman haha, nakakagawa na po kasi sya ng mga bagay na nakakaturn off sakin tulad ng paninigarilyo na pinaka ayoko sa lahat which is alam nya yon.
