View of the gate of the Rafah crossing as humanitarian aid is expected to enter Gaza. Rafah is the only crossing out of Gaza not controlled by Israel but has been out of operation for nearly two weeks since Palestinian Islamist group Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7. Israel has bombarded the enclave in retaliation, worsening conditions for the 2.3 million people living there under a blockade by Israel and Egypt since Hamas took control of Gaza in 2007. Most of Gaza's residents depended on aid before the current conflict started and about 100 trucks daily were providing humanitarian relief to the enclave, according to the United Nations. #Rafah #aid #Israel #Hamas #Gaza #Palestinian #IsraelHamasWar #GazaWar #live #Reuters #News Keep up with the latest news from around the world: https://www.reuters.com/

My October Newsletter has been released this week: Dear Friends, Cultural Creatives and Seekers Everywhere, War does not determine who is right, it determines who is left ~ On September 11, 2001, before the smoke from the collapsed Twin Towers had even cleared, the worldâ€™s leaders came knocking on the White House door. They were seeking George Bushâ€™s support to create a global coalition that once and for all would strive to eliminate planetary terrorism. Unfortunately, Bush declined the invitation so that he could attack Iraq and end a family feud by eliminating Saddam Hussein, who was not even involved in the attack on the twin towers. The world is currently trying to come to terms with the inhumane atrocities carried out by both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Around the globe, citizens are rallying in a concerted effort to bring an end to the barbaric nature of planetary violence and war in todayâ€™s modern world. On the horizon, I see a second opportunity is now arising wherein global civilization is once again coalescing and demanding an end to war. War, violence, and division only perpetuate a cycle of suffering. We must now begin to emphasize that it is not our differences, but our common humanity that must come to the forefront. Through nurturing compassion and empathy, we will come to recognize the notion that the well-being of one is intrinsically linked to the well-being of all. This is the first step towards healing the world. In times of crisis, we come together to support one another, regardless of our backgrounds. This ability to unite must extend beyond moments of crisis to become a way of life. It is my fervent hope that we can create a world where differences are celebrated, where conflicts are resolved through dialogue and understanding, and where the power of our shared humanity prevails. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is a painful reminder of the work that lies ahead, but it is not an insurmountable challenge. Let us commit to educating ourselves about the complexities of this issue, to supporting peace initiatives, and to spreading the message of unity. By doing so, we can honor our shared humanity and work toward a future where conflicts no longer define our world. With Peace, Love, and Light, Bruce

Bart De Wever, jullie voorzitter, heeft het recht om IsraÃ«l "de kant van het licht" te noemen. Fysiek misselijk word ik van die uitspraken, maar hij heeft het recht om ze te doen. 

Ook hebben jullie het recht om tot vervelens toe in de media te komen klagen over 'woke' en 'cancel culture', ookal zijn er weinig mensen wiens meningen zo dominant aanwezig zijn in het maatschappelijke debat als die van jullie. 

Het probleem, beste N-VA, is dat jullie graag ook het recht zouden willen hebben om jullie mening te uiten zonder tegengesproken te worden. Wel, dat recht heb je in een goed functionerende democratie nu eenmaal nooit. 

In een goed functionerende democratie heb je te maken met kritische middenveldsorganisaties. En goede democraten gaan die niet intimideren omdat ze een andere mening aan bod laten komen dan de hunne. 

Dus ja, die screening voelt best wel intimiderend aan. Maar neen, wij gaan absoluut niet stoppen met wijzen op de oorlogsmisdaden van IsraÃ«l. 

Natuurlijk kiezen wij kant in dit conflict. Dat is, zoals steeds, de kant van de mensenrechten en het internationaal recht. Iemand moet het doen, beste N-VA, want op jullie kunnen we daarvoor jammer genoeg niet rekenen.

Groeten,

Today Daisy was spayed. It was necessary, but a scary experience for her, as she wss fearful and snappy. But it is done now, very tired. Hopefully feeling better soon. Thank you all for your kind and supportive words and for the knowledge that so many of you have. Most rescues in my area do not take dogs like this, or donâ€™t give them time in rescue before adoption. Medical dogs attract donations, and these dogs do not, so I think itâ€™s financial and about the time needed for these dogs. The time involved makes it hard to rescue many fearful dogs. It is nearly impossible to find any fosters who would do this for a fearful dog, so I encourage any of you that are able to offer your patience and knowledge, to foster a fearful dog, even if itâ€™s once every other year. It also takes extra effort to place a fearful dog, and I have to disappoint more people to do it well. My only rehab fosters eventually adopted two fearful dogs from me, over several years. So their home is full up. And they took dogs that would have been hard or impossible to place. Now she is cuddling and giving kisses: a very fast turnaround, after sleeping for the better part of three days, and still sleeping a lot. It does appear that her home may have involved domestic conflict. Though she loves Dave and happily sits on his lap, if he approaches me in a way that seems like heâ€™s leaning over me or reaches towards me, she growls. It does not fit with my experience of resource guarding. Any tips? My book should be here any day! Update: sheâ€™s decided to join us in the same room! I have a new dog in my home non-profit rescue that is very fearful, cannot be touched or will try to nip. She is a 4.5 pound Pomeranian mix, unspayed. She was rehomed twice in the past two and a half weeks. I do have experience rehabilitating fearful/abused dogs but I know thereâ€™s much more to learn. I am not touching or looking directly at her. The last home was an apt. with children who tried to touch her and pick her up. She was very nippy by the time they surrendered her to me. The previous home allegedly had her since 8 weeks old. They said that they were rehoming because her owner went away to college. However Iâ€™ve since learned that this dog was very fearful and nippy at the vets, with the first owners. Both rehomings took place via Craigslist. I have had her just 48 plus hours. She has a drag line on and I can take her out to potty, but she otherwise chooses to stay in the crate and looks very fearful. She will actively try to nip if any effort is made to exchange her drag line for a longer one. I've just purchased the Do No Harm Book! Hasn't yet arrived. Thanks!!

IN RESPONSE to the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas in the Gaza Strip, a total of 77 Zambians, including 72 students and five other individuals, have been successfully evacuated and returned to Zambia. https://www.facebook.com/100064560977290/posts/728973465931346/ Currently, there are 172 Zambians living in Israel, with 143 being students and the remainder consisting of diplomats and other residents. The conflict in the Gaza Strip has resulted in the loss of approximately 3,000 lives. Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Stanley Kakubo has Parliament that no Zambian has been killed in the conflict. Mr Kakubo said the Ministry is still in talks with the embassy there to ensure the welfare and safety of those who have chosen to stay back in the conflict zone. The Minister was responding to a question raised by Pambashe Member of Parliament, Ronald Chitotela regarding the conflict in the Gaza Strip. "I would like to highlight that Government has facilitated the voluntary, temporary relocation of all Zambians who have expressed a desire to return to our homeland for the time being. So far number totalling to 77 Zambians arrived safely in Lusaka as of October 18th, 2023, these include 72 students and five others. For those who have chosen to remain in Israel, be rest assured that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation will maintain close collaboration with the Embassy and the Israeli Foreign Ministry, and stands ready to take any necessary actions that will ensure their continued welfare and safety," he said. Mr Kakubo said President Hakainde Hichilema has reiterated the importance of Peace, Security and Stability and it is in this vein that Zambia reaffirms its commitment to ensuring peace, stability and security. â€œThe loss of lives in both Israel and the Gaza Strip is regrettable and we wish to extend our heartfelt condolences and sympathies to all the affected individuals and families. Madam Speaker, the international response to these unsettling developments has been resolute. The Chair of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) issued a strong condemnation of the violence, urging all parties to exercise restraint to prevent further escalation, understanding that such an outcome would undermine the extensive global efforts for peace and security in the Middle East,â€ he said. (Mwebantu, Friday, 20th October, 2023)

An estimated 5,000 worshippers gathered at Parry Park Lakemba earlier this afternoon to offer their Jumu'ah prayer for the people of Palestine. The event was put together by the LMA in collaboration with a number of other masjids and religious organisations in light of the recent conflict in Gaza. The LMA took the almost unprecedented step of moving Jumuâ€™ah from our iconic Lakemba Mosque to nearby Parry Park to cater for the anticipated huge crowd and our expectations were well and truly met. Lakemba Mosque Imam Sheikh Yahya Safi (Arabic) and Sheikh Wesam Charkawi (English) delivered the khutbahs and spoke passionately about the oppression being suffered by our Palestinian brothers and sisters at the hands of the tyrants. Their words were eloquently supported by our other speakers Abraham Zoabi, Sheikh Ahmed Abdo and Siddiq Buckley. A sincere thank you to our community for their attendance today and for their exceptional generosity as a substantial amount was raised by our charity arm Feed The World. We give our absolute commitment that all funds raised will go towards this most worthy of causes: our beautiful brothers and sisters in Gaza.

Fix My Marriage 3 In the morningâ€“after a night of sleeplessness and tearsâ€“I gathered my things and got ready to leave. I didn't take much of anything; most of my clothes were bought with Chima's moneyâ€“those ones, I didn't take. The jewellery and shoes too were left behind. I figured that if I was leaving, I should at least leave with some chunk of my dignity intact. When I pulled my little box out to the living room, Chima was surprised. "You didn't take everything?" He asked. I scoffed. "Are you desperately trying to get rid of me and every bit of memory of me?" I shot back. He sat back, uneasy, then scratched his greying beards. "That's not what I meant, Celine. You have ten times more stuff than what you're taking so I'm just surprised you didn't take more." I dipped my head. Maybe it was too late to try and be nice or something, but I still went with my instincts. "Chima, thank you, but those things are yours. Keep them or better yet, burn them once I'm gone!" He was silent for a long while, and that treatment made me feel foolish. Here I was hoping he'd change his mind. But to hell with that. I wasn't going to force him to keep me around. My lies were catching up with me, and I had to bear the consequences. But the past seven years hurt! I gave everything to this union. He was older than I was by maybe two times, but I still stayed with him. Yeah, at first it was for the money, but later his dedication and care had won me over completely. "I'll go now!" I said. "Wait!" He said, and I turned to face him. "Where does your mother live?" I took a deep breath. I'd informed him that I'd go visit her, but I had no idea why he was asking. Regardless, I told him the village and the house location. "You want to visit?" I asked. "Maybe. I don't know." Chima's cold treatment said it all. I left. After leaving, I didn't go to the village immediately. No, I stopped by to see my hired mother. When the woman saw me alight from the keke, she smiled and came out to greet me. "Ah, you didn't come with chief? Where are the bags of rice and wrappers?" She asked in one breath. God, I was enraged. This woman didn't even feel any pity for exploiting me! But then again, could I complain? I gave her the power to exploit me, so I had to either endure her or put a stop to it. Right then, I knew exactly which option I was ticking. "There are no bags of rice or any more money! I came to tell you that your services are no longer needed, madam!" She paused for a while, then laughed. "You don't mean it!" "Oh, I mean every single word!" I said, squeezing the words out through my gritted teeth. The woman studied me for a while, then shrugged. "But you can't just ask me to stop being your mother. Chief will find out and you will be finished. It's better to pay me and keep me happy. A happy mother-in-law is a happy family!" I glared at the woman for her audacious words. I felt like slapping her so hard that she'd run and hide in the sands! If only she knew that at that moment, I had nothing to lose! "Just stay away. You will no longer get any money or benefits. Don't ever come near me again!" I turned to leave, but she called me back and poured every colourful threat she knew. "I'll tell Chima. You will be sorry. He will know what a lying idiot you are!" I ignored her and left. My next stop was the village. I was nervous. Ten years of absence wasn't a joke. When I arrived, my little sister hissed and went inside. I couldn't blame her much. She looked so thin and underfed that her bones were showing through. I swallowed the guilt and went in. My mother saw me and fell on her knees. When I saw this, my heart skipped. Just like ten years ago when I'd fallen on my knees before her. But this time, there was no anger. Not from me nor from her. .... Chima. I was still wallowing in my internal conflict when the doorbell rang. I didn't feel like meeting anyoneâ€“and I wasn't expecting anyone. I felt that maybe Celine had come back! I rushed to the door and opened, but instead of Celine, I saw her fake mother standing there with a deep scowl on her face. She went on to tell me all the lies Celine had been telling. The only thing she didn't know was that I already knew. As she talked, I realised one crucial fact. Celine really did love me. Why then would she go to lengths of lying just to keep me with her? When has she exploited me for money or favours aside from the times she asked for a new phone and hand bag? When? I smiled at the woman for waking me up. "Thank you!" I said and pushed her out. I changed, grabbed my car keys and left the house. It was time I dumped my judgemental character. Follow Saviouribokauthor1 for updates.

text: IN NUMBERS:The ANC has taken a stand in support of Palestine by organising a picket outside the Israeli embassy in Pretoria. The demonstration is a show of solidarity with the people of Palestine as the conflict in the Middle East intensifies.

Vice President Sara Duterte on Thursday urged Filipinos to call for a ceasefire as war rages in the Middle East. Duterte, who's also the education secretary, said Filipinos should not take sides because everyone loses in a war, especially children. "Ako ay nananawagan sa aking kapwa Pilipino na ipahayag ang isang tigil putukan at dalhin ang usapin ng kapayapaan sa mesa," she said in a video posted on Facebook. "Ating ipanawagan ang pagkakaisa ng mga partido upang maglabas ng kolektibong pananawagan para sa pangmatagalang kapayapaan," she added. The vice president said the war inflicts harm not only those Filipinos living in affected areas but also their families left in the Philippines who are relying on them for financial support. She also warned of possible hardships caused by the unrest including food security. Duterte did not specifically mention Israel and Palestinian militant group Hamas â€“ who have been fighting in Gaza for several days already. As of Thursday, the Department of Foreign Affairs confirmed that at least four Filipinos have died in the escalating conflict. | via CNN Philippines #PanayNews

Museum London celebrates artist Jamelie Hassan, who will be receiving an Honorary Degree from Western University during Convocation today (October 20, 2023). This accolade acknowledges Hassanâ€™s decades-long community activism and her profound artistic innovations. From the 1970s to today, she has exhibited throughout Canada and internationally, making important contributions to Canadian and global culture as a multimedia artist, lecturer, writer, and independent curator. Hassan is renowned for her socially based practice. Her art engages with issues of human rights, political conflict, and cultural displacement, and her emphasis on collaboration and support led her to co-found Londonâ€™s Forest City Gallery and Embassy Cultural House. This honourary degree adds to the many awards Hassan has earned. In 2001, she received a Governor General's Award in Visual and Media Arts. Her works can be found in the collections of the National Gallery of Canada and the Art Gallery of Ontario, Museum London, and many other institutions. Please visit her website for more information - www.jameliehassan.ca:=:http://www.jameliehassan.ca/

FEATURE FRIDAY Post 3 of 3 Tee O'Fallon Author I just had a new book release on Monday â€“ Above â€™Nâ€™ Beyond, the seventh and final book in my Federal K-9 series. For this one, I took a really deep dive into conflict and emotional wounds that drive characters to do what they do, make the decisions they make. It added so many layers to the story. Thatâ€™s why I think this is one of the best books Iâ€™ve ever written. Thereâ€™s so much juicy angst and meat to Jamieâ€™s and Bellaâ€™s fears, hopes and dreams, and especially, their character arcs. Hereâ€™s the back cover blurb to whet your appetite. I do hope youâ€™ll check out this book! Deep secrets. Deadly truths. Getting locked up had been easy. But for K-9 Sergeant Jamie Pataglio, going undercover at a maximum-security prisonâ€”and infiltrating the Mancusco crime familyâ€”was the hard part. Now, six months later, Jamieâ€™s been accepted as one of the mobâ€™s own, and heâ€™s walking out of the gates as a free manâ€¦and stepping into the criminal underworld. Thereâ€™s only one small, gorgeous problem: Bella Bianco. The Italian bistro used to be Bellaâ€™s pride and joy. Now itâ€™s become a nightmare, where her violent family uses her restaurant as its criminal home base. Guilty by association. She needs to find a way out, and fast. The last thing Bella needs is an attraction to their newest â€œassociateâ€â€”even if every moment alone with him leaves her breathless. Itâ€™s almost enough to make her reconsider her â€œno mobstersâ€ policyâ€¦ They canâ€™t trust each other. But if either of them ever wants to break free of their circumstances, they donâ€™t have a choice. Theyâ€™ll have to take down her family. And if anyone finds out theyâ€™re working togetherâ€¦theyâ€™re both dead. https://teeofallon.com/above-n-beyond/ Have a great weekend, everyone!

On the night of October 19, 2023, the complex of the Greek Orthodox Church of Saint-Porphyre in Gaza was hit by the bombings of Israeli forces. It served as a refuge for about 400 people. According to AED - Aid to the Church in Need, 16 Christians are believed to have died, 10 from the same family, and 15 others are still trapped under the rubble. Despite the bombings and repeated evacuation requests to the South, Christian families in the Gaza Strip will not leave. "We have nowhere else to flee. Our house was bombed, my house was destroyed, where am I going now?"; "We refuse to be forcibly displaced to Sinai. They told us to evacuate to the south of Gaza. We said we won't leave. We want to die here." ğŸ™More than ever, SOS ChrÃ©tiens d'Orient invites you to intensify your prayers for peace, for the Palestinian Christian families of the Saint-Porphyre church, and for all Christians in the Holy Land, but also for the hostages still being held captive and for the repose of the souls of the thousands of Palestinian and Israeli victims in this conflict.

The black bear has risen in stature to one of our stateâ€™s most valued animals â€“ by wildlife watchers and hunters alike. Maineâ€™s expansive northern, eastern, and western forest supports the largest population of black bears in the eastern United States, and MDIFWâ€™s black bear monitoring program is one of the most extensive and longest-running programs of its type in the U.S. Our bear management program strives to balance biological and social needs and uses long-term monitoring of black bears, harvest data, and conflict data to inform management decisions. Maineâ€™s 10-year big game management plan includes goals, objectives, and a series of management strategies designed to ensure continued enjoyment of black bears without too many conflicts in backyards and neighborhoods. To learn more about Maine black bear monitoring, management, harvest, conflict prevention, and research, take a look through the Game Species Conservation & Management Section of the 2022-2023 Research + Management Report at mefishwildlife.com/wildlifereport:=:https://www.maine.gov/ifw/fish-wildlife/wildlife/reports-publications/research-management.html. #BlackBear #Maine #WildlifeManagement #AllInForTheMaineOutdoors #MaineWildlife #HuntME

A few months after The Treaty is put before the DÃ¡il to vote on, an election in June 1922 is put before the Irish people. Here are some results and impartial analysis: In June 1922 an Irish general election was held for the Irish population. Sinn Fein were campaigning as Pro-Treaty (Collins side) and Anti-Treaty (De Valeraâ€™s side). Here are the results. (Iâ€™ve seen discrepancies of 2-300 votes in various history books). SF Pro-Treaty: Popular vote - 239,193 38.1% 58 seats SF Anti-Treaty: Popular vote - 135,864 21.8% 36 seats Many had voted for other parties. Labour made huge gains nearly on a par with the anti-Treaty side. This also showed signs of a general population growing tired of conflict after 1916 and the 1919-21 War of Independence. Labour Party Popular vote: 132,565 21.3% 17 seats Interestingly Labour, Farmers Party, Businessmenâ€™s Party and Independents all supported the Treaty and secured 247,080 votes, more than both SF Pro-Treaty and Anti-Treaty 75% of the Irish electorate were in favor of The Treaty just before the Irish Civil War 1922-23 was to break out. Also non Sinn Fein parties (pro or anti-Treaty) had support from over 40% of the Irish electorate. Of the 22 seats in Dublin spread over 5 constituencies only 1 of 6 anti-Treaty Sinn Fein candidates had won. Margaret Pearse mother of Patrick Pearse, Kathleen Clarke, widow of Tom Clarke and Constance Markievicz all lost their seats. Margaret Pearse failed to be elected because of the lack of second preference votes. Another interesting point is that Sinn Fein anti-Treaty had taken part in an election in line with Article 11 of The Treaty even though it was seen as partitionist in nature. Article 11 had limited the election to only 26 counties excluding Northern Ireland. Within 12 days the Irish Civil War would break out when the Pro-Treaty government bombarded the Four Courts.

text: Facts about Israel and Palestine: 1. Palestinians living in Israel enjoy more rights than Palestinians in the Gaza . This includes women's rights, property ownership, political participation,voting rights, access to abortions and civil rights protections including affirmative action. 2. Israel is a diverse country, not an "ethnostate." Jews make up approximately 70% of the population, Arabs about 20%, with the remaining composed of various ethnicities. 3. Palestinian" does not represent a single ethnicity. Palestine was historically a territory, not a nation-state, consisting of diverse ethnic groups, including Jewish people. 4. The Israeli government is not monolithic; it consists of a politically diverse parliament (Knesset) with different ethnicities and political parties. Socialistic parties have held office. 5. Prior to the establishment of Israel, Palestine was not a recognized state; it was a sparsely populated territory inhabited by both Jews and Arabs, with a total population of under 2 million. This includes Holocaust survivors. 6. Since the establishment of Israel, the population of Gaza and the Palestinian territories has grown significantly and ranks 13th in the world. 7. Israel withdrew its military from Gaza in 2005, after which Hamas suspended elections and ruled with strict enforcement of Islamic law. 8. The United Nations, which created the legal framework for addressing genocide, does not classify the Israel-Palestine conflict as genocide or ethnic cleansing 9. Early Jewish settlers were not "colonists"; they were refugees , Holocaust survivors and migrants fleeing persecution. 10. The estimated population of early Israel was about 800,000, including both Jews and Arabs. 11. There is no â€œfree Palestine â€œ with Hamas in control 12. Israel has policies that require critical examination, especially concerning human rights issues in Gaza. However, as mentioned earlier, Israel's political landscape is not monolithic. There are diverse viewpoints, including both right-wing and left-wing perspectives, on civil rights and foreign policy, as seen in other industrialized nations. And like other democratic nations , these divisions produce mixed results , some good , others bad , and never ideal. Criticizing Israeli policies and holding the government accountable for its actions is not inherently antisemitic, but reducing jewish Israelis to a singular entity and calling for the complete destruction of the state absolutely is

The World Health Organization said Thursday that five trucks full of medical supplies are ready at the Rafah border crossing between Egypt and the Gaza Strip, with hopes that the aid could be delivered to Palestinian hospitals as early as Friday. "Our trucks are loaded and ready to go," WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told reporters. The delivery of aid would be the first since Israel imposed a complete blockade on the Gaza Strip, following the October 7 attack by Hamas militants that killed over 1,400 Israelis. Health authorities in the Gaza Strip said Thursday that at least 3,785 Palestinians had been killed by Israeli bombardment since the latest conflict erupted. While aid continues to build up on the Egyptian side of the crossing, Egypt is not allowing Palestinians to cross from Gaza into the Egyptian Sinai peninsula. Following a meeting on Wednesday with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi said such an exodus of people from Gaza would jeopardize Palestinian aspirations of statehood. Hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were forced from their land in past conflicts with Israel, with many settling in Egypt and other neighboring states. Many refugees have never been allowed to return â€” and the regions fear the wider implications of Palestinians being forced to flee Gaza, said analyst Chris Doyle, director of the London-based Council for Arab-British Understanding. https://www.voanews.com/a/egypt-wary-of-opening-gaza-border-to-palestinian-refugees/7318041.html

Cloaked in stillness, the Poppy Man stands, A somber sentinel on hallowed ground. His presence evokes memories profound, Of valiant souls who gave their all, In a conflict that left the world enthralled. Near Banbury Cross, he takes his stand, A poignant reminder of those who fell, Their sacrifices etched upon our land. The poppy he bears, a symbol of rest, For those who now eternally rest. Linked to Armistice Day, that day of yore, When the guns fell silent, and hope was reborn, The poppy stands as a beacon, forevermore, A reminder of the price that was paid, For the freedoms we so often take for granted. As we pass by, let us pause and reflect, On the sacrifices made, and the lives that were wrecked. Let us honour their memory, with reverence and grace, And vow to never forget, the fallen of that fateful place. For in their silence, they speak volumes untold, Of courage and valor, of duty and pride. Let their stories inspire us, as we grow old, To cherish the peace, for which they died. So as you see the Poppy Man stand, Remember the fallen, and lend a helping hand. For in their memory, we must all strive, To build a world where peace will forever thrive. Pictured. The new installation next to Banbury Cross. Remembering the fallen.

Unearthed in Germany, DNA extracted from bones and teeth within a 4,600-year-old Stone Age burial site has yielded the earliest proof of the nuclear family system as a societal structure. Within this discovery, a poignant narrative unfolds: Two parents and their two sons, laid to rest together, their lives cut short by a tragic conflict over highly coveted fertile farmland in Europe. These collective burials, seemingly interwoven, provide a window into the past, revealing a tale of violent endings. The individuals belonged to the Corded Ware culture, named after their distinctive pottery decoration technique involving twisted cord patterns.

It signifies not only the absence of conflict but the presence of safety, respect for the precious gift of life, and the power of cooperation and unity. Dear BSHAA, Thank you for your latest communication. I would like to commence by publicly stating my intentions of terminating my BSHAA membership. I would have like to have done so with immediate effect; however, prior to doing so I would need to ensure all BSHAA logos and associated acronyms are removed entirely from my website etc. I do not wish to be affiliated with a membership body like yourselves who hold little or no regard to the genuine concerns of itâ€™s own membership and the health and safety of the general public. In direct response to your latest mailing, I can confirm that any comments made by myself are non-defamatory and non-libellous. They are based on facts. For example, some BSHAA accredited ear wax removal courses ARE training lay-people when it comes to ears (i.e. people with no previous ear experience or qualifications). In addition, there is a clear UNDECLARED conflict of interest, with certain individuals on the BSHAA Council affiliated with national high-street chains that actively train their receptionists to perform ear wax removal. Furthermore, one of the abovementioned individuals is a â€˜Key Authorâ€™ on the proposed â€˜Aural Care Registerâ€™ (ACR). All other statements of mine are opinions and redacted statements from various individuals. On the contrary, I am aware of certain BSHAA Council Members who have made defamatory and libellous comments about myself through direct messages sent to other members. These messages have been forwarded to me and which I now hold in my safe possession. It is great that you have finally provided a further definition of an Associate Wax Member to your membership. It is now clear that any individual who has successfully completed a BSHAA-accredited aural care (wax removal) course (and we know there are such courses who train quite literally anybody) and meet the requirements outlined for both initial and continuing registration is eligible to become an Associate Wax Member. This could therefore include beauticians, electricians, plumbers, tattooists and of course, receptionists at high-street hearing centres. With regards to the 3-month reflective post-training period and the current internal discussions you seem to be having about what it may include, you seem to be getting a bit ahead of yourselves I feel on this, donâ€™t you think? I thought the ACR is still out for public consultation and if it is the will of the membership you wonâ€™t proceed with it? Interestingly, you make reference to the BSA Minimum Training Guidelines first drafted in August 2020 and which is due for review in August 2025. You may have missed a very important point when you did, in such that these minimal guidelines are for â€˜Aural Care delivered by Hearing Health Care Professionalsâ€™. This is in bold and enlarged font on the front cover of the document. I donâ€™t believe beauticians, electricians, plumbers, tattooists and of course receptionists at high-street hearing centres qualify as â€˜Hearing Health Care Professionalsâ€™, do you? You claim that BSHAAâ€™s development of the ACR is â€˜entirely altruisticâ€™ and BSHAA makes no profit from accrediting training courses. Would you say this is also true of some of the high-street companies that a couple of BSHAA Council Members are affiliated with, one also being a Key Author in the ACR document? I should also advise that some of the potentially hundreds of poorly trained people you eluded to in our sector have attended BSHAA accredited courses, with many being employed by the very same high-street companies that some BSHAA Council Members are affiliated with. All the public criticism that BSHAA have encountered in recent weeks is well deserved and justified. You have published a proposed ACR documentation for public consultation not clearly defining the term â€˜Associate Wax Memberâ€™ and without providing members with all the poll and survey results (and have still yet to do so). I should add these results are now void because both members and the public up until now did not fully understand what an â€˜Associate Wax Memberâ€™ meant. Instead of re-conducting (and independently at that) the members poll and both members and public surveys like any respectable membership body would in light of this newly provided critical piece of information, BSHAA are once again doubling-down on their position and pursing the ACR proposal. With regards to the further wider private representation BSHAA is seeking onto The National Dewax Access Group, could you advise who these representations are? They are not a particular BSHAA accredited private ear wax removal training course provider that train quite literally anybody such as receptionists at high-street hearing chains, are they? If so, this would be a CLEAR CONFLICT OF INTEREST. Yes, I know... To conclude, please be aware that I shall be continuing to strongly oppose your ACR proposal even if not within BSHAA. I shall also continue to educate the public about the potential risks to their healthy and (truncated)

Day 13 of the #Israel-#Hamas conflict witnessed a surge in casualties due to Israel's intense bombardment of #Gaza. The Israeli airstrikes have resulted in the deaths of approximately 3,785 #Palestinians, with a third of the victims being children. The majority of those killed are civilians. Additionally, around 1,500 Hamas militants have been reported killed by the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF). An airstrike on a Gaza hospital, which claimed the lives of over 500 people, triggered outrage in the Middle East, leading to criticism from Arab leaders. Israel denied the allegations, citing a misfire by Islamic Jihad, and provided video and audio evidence to support its claims. Both U.S. President Biden and UK Prime Minister Sunak reaffirmed their support for Israel during recent visits. Gazans are eagerly awaiting aid promised in a deal brokered by the U.S. These events followed a Hamas militant attack on October 7, which prompted Israel's retaliation.

FREE ADVICE FRIDAY I am currently in a relationship going on 5 months now. I have been single for many, many years because I was not looking for anything serious, and he has been divorced for approximately 3 years. I never intended on falling for this man but here we are. I am finally in a situation where I could see long term. Here's the issue, I have no idea what his deal is. When we are together, he is loving and attentive and makes it very clear we are in a relationship. In the days between we see one another, we keep in contact and we could be going well for several days or even a week and then bam, he's ready to tuck tail and run, but then when I ask him why, he says he doesn't think he can give me what I want (yet he's never asked me what I want) and doesn't want to keep me from dating others...then the latest kicker- he says if he didn't cause some conflict from time to time than I would lose interest. I have never heard this before! Do you need drama in your relationship to keep the spark? -Kelly

An Indian-origin doctor working at a hospital in Bahrain was sacked from his job for posting anti-Palestinians comments on social media. Royal Bahrain Hospital announced on Thursday that it terminated Dr Sunil Rao's employment because of his tweets that were "offensive to our society". Dr Rao posted a series of tweets seemingly supporting Israel amid its deadly conflict with Hamas. His tweets went viral after an X user posted them, asking Bahraini authorities to take notice. Soon after, Royal Bahrain Hospital decided to fire Dr Rao. In a statement posted on social media, the hospital said that it took legal actions and removed him from the job. "It has come to our attention that Dr Sunil Rao who is working as a Specialist in Internal Medicine has posted tweets on social media that are offensive to our society," the hospital's statement read. "We would like to confirm that his tweets and ideology are personal and do not reflect the opinion and values of the hospital. This is a violation of our code of conduct and we have taken the necessary legal actions and his service has been terminated with immediate effect". Before the hospital released its statement, Dr Rao posted an apology on X calling his comments "insensitive". Arlene Brosas has condemned the Philippine governmentâ€™s expression of support to Israel amid the ongoing armed conflict over the Middle East as thousands of innocent Palestinians have been killed. In a statement on Thursday, Brosas said that President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. should not have made an outright support for Israelâ€™s actions, and similarly, should have refrained from calling Hamas militants a terrorist group. Last October 11, Marcos said the Philippines stands with Israel, which suffered an all-out attack from Hamas last October 7. â€œWe strongly condemn President Marcos Jr.â€™s outright support to Israel at a time when thousands of Palestinians are being slaughtered and driven out of their land,â€ Brosas said. â€œExpressing sadness is not enough. While it was Hamas that brought the fight to Israel through an aerial, land, and sea attack, the militant group soon found itself hammered after Israeli forces fought back though missile strikes. Estimates from the United Nations (UN) show that the death toll due to the conflict is already around 4,300 â€” of which 1,300 are Israeli nationals and the remaining 3,000 are Palestinians. Goddess of Strength and Justice who brings compassion, peace, calm and order to the chaos, destruction and conflict in any situation. She appears to us on Her tiger, looking completely serene and composed, dressed in a red silk sari and carrying various weapons and tools in her eight to eighteen arms. In the Hindu traditions Mata Durga is the Divine Mother Goddess who presides over the seasons of life, death, and birth. To many, She is simply DEVI, which means â€˜Goddessâ€™ and comes from the sanskrit â€˜Devaâ€™, which means â€˜to shineâ€™. She is the Great Mother who helps us removing the limitations and emotional and mental obscurations that prevent us from shining the Divine Light we all carry within our hearts. Durga, which means the invincible, unconquerable and unassailable one, is the name this powerful and courageous Goddess takes after Her defeat of the buffalo-headed demon Durgama. She teaches us that the divine light of truth and wisdom will always prevail over disorder and pain. The Devi Mahatmya is a dramatic narration of the different battles the Great Goddess fights to stop all that is threatening the balance and harmony between humans and nature. Its various chapters describe how only the Great Goddess can stop the asuras (demons) that are causing so much bloodshed, violence and destruction on the earth. The demons represent the afflicted ego qualities in humans and Devi confronts the demons of arrogance, pride, hypocrisy, greed, rage, discrimination, injustice and more. à¬¶à­à¬°à­€à¬¦à¬¶à¬®à¬¹à¬¾à¬¬à¬¿à¬¦à­à­Ÿà¬¾à¬•à¬¬à¬šà¬®à­ à¬¬à¬¿à¬¨à¬¿à¬¯à­‹à¬—à¬ƒ - text: ğŸš¨STATEMENT OF FC BAYERN MUNICH REGARDING NOUSSAIR MAZRAOUI FC Bayern Munich held a detailed and clarifying conversation with Noussair Mazraoui this week. The reason for the discussion was Mazraoui's Instagram posts in connection with the terror against Israel almost two weeks ago, which led to irritation and criticism. "Noussair Mazraoui has credibly assured us that as a peace-loving person he resolutely rejects terror and war and he never meant to cause any irritation with his posts", said Jan-Christian Dreesen, CEO of FC Bayern explaining, "FC Bayern condemns Hamas' attack on Israel" - "Furthermore, Noussair Mazraoui declares, "I condemn all terrorism and terrorist organizations." FC Bayern and Noussair Mazraoui strongly oppose the transfer of the Middle East conflict and its violence to Germany, which is committed to peace. Hate and violence of any kind have no place in the political culture of Germany. FC Bayern stands by Germany's Jewish community and by Israel's side; nothing justifies the murder of children and families. FC Bayern believes that football should unleash its power of reconciliation between different cultures, especially in the most difficult moments. Noussair Mazraoui will remain in the FC Bayern squad, but is out of action due to an injury he sustained. [FCB]

Malaysian cave paintings: ancient depictions of conflict and courage Researchers have made a significant discovery by dating the drawings found in Gua Sireh Cave in Sarawak, shedding light on a story of conflict. This limestone cave in western Sarawak, Malaysian Borneo, is renowned for its charcoal drawings adorning its chambers, attracting numerous visitors. The drawings depict Indigenous resistance to frontier violence in the 1600s and 1800s CE. Radiocarbon dating of the drawings has revealed their age to be between 280 and 120 cal BP (CE 1670 to 1830), aligning with a period of escalating conflict as Malay elites, who controlled the region, imposed heavy tolls on Indigenous hill tribes, including the Bidayuh. Continue Reading: https://archaeologymag.com/2023/08/malaysian-cave-paintings-ancient-depictions-of-conflict-and-courage/ . . Archaeology News #archaeology #ancienthistory #rockart #cavepainting #guasirehcave

Three NATO warships from the Standing NATO Mine Countermeasures Group 1 (SNMCMG1) have docked in Cardiff after operating in UK waters. Lead Mine Counter measure ship, ORP Czernicki from the Polish Navy came in first followed by HNLMS Zierikzee from The Royal Netherlandâ€™s Navy and the German Navyâ€™s FGS Bad Bevensen. The Standing NATO Mine Countermeasures Group typically consists of several mine hunting vessels supported by a frigate, with the various participating NATO member states taking it in turns to contribute ships and personnel. The group provide NATO with a continuous maritime capability for operations and other activities, both in peacetime and in periods of crisis and conflict. They also carry out a more general role, conducting routine diplomatic visits to different countries, and providing maritime military capabilities to ongoing missions.

REVIVED GLORIOUS WORD SERIES

TITLE : THE SADDUCEES

SCRIPTURE REFERENCE : ACTS 5:17, ACTS 23:8, MARK 12:18-27

Beloved welcome to today's lesson. In our lesson today we shall be discussing something about the Sadducees.

The Sadduccees were the party of high priests, aristocratic families, and merchants. They were the wealthy elements of population and they belong to a Jewish priestly sect that flourished for about two centuries before the destruction of the second Temple of Jerusalem in 70CE.

Not much is known about the Sadduccees' origin and early history but their name may be derived from that of Zadok who was a high priest in the time of King David and King Solomon. Ezekiel later selected this family as worthy of being entrusted with control of the Temple, and Zadokites formed the Temple hierarchy down to the 2nd Century BCE.

The Sadducees came under the influence of Hellenism, tended to have good relations with the Roman rulers of Palestine, and generally represented the conservative view within Judaism. While their rivals, the Pharisees, claimed the authority of piety and learning, the Sadducees claimed that of birth and social/economic position.

During the long period of the two parties' struggle which lasted until the Roman's destruction of Jerusalem in 70CE, the Sadducees dominated the Temple and it's Priesthood.

The Sadducees and Pharisees were in constant conflict with each other, not only over numerous details of ritual and the Law but most importantly over the content and extent of God's revelation to the Jewish people. 

The Sadducees refused to go beyond the written Torah ( first five books of the Old Testament) and thus, unlike the Pharisees, denied the immortality of the soul, bodily resurrection after death and according to the Acts Of The Apostles (23:8), the existence of angelic spirits.

Though the Sadducees were conservative in religious matters, their wealth, their haughty bearing and their willingness to compromise with the Roman rulers aroused the hatred of the common people. Their lives and political authority were so intimately bound up with the Temple worship that after Roman legions destroyed the Temple, the Sadducees ceased to exist as a group, and mention of them quickly disappeared from history.

Beloved this brings us to the end of today's lesson. We shall continue with our discussion in our next lesson.

God Richly Bless You All For Your Time In JESUS'NAME. Amen.

Embark on a journey through the intriguing history of tank design, from the experimental days of World War I to the formidable war machines of World War II. In the early stages of tank warfare during WWI, these steel behemoths were experimental, often unreliable, and had limited mobility. Nonetheless, the experiences of this era laid the groundwork for groundbreaking innovations. As we advanced into WWII, tanks became swifter, heavily armoured, and better equipped for both offensive and defensive roles. They played a pivotal role in determining the outcomes of battles and campaigns. Join us at Armourgeddon Military Museum to delve into the history of tank evolution, from the Great War to the global conflict of WWII. #TankEvolution #MilitaryTech #HistoryLesson

Israel is finalising the closure of Al Jazeera over its coverage of the ongoing conflict in Gaza, which it says is helping Hamas. The Qatar-based network is the biggest Arabic language news outlet providing televised and online updates on the situation in Gaza, within Israel and in other occupied Palestinian territories. On Friday, a number of Israeli media outlets, including i24 News and Times of Israel, said that the Israeli government had approved "emergency regulations" that would shutter broadcasters that are deemed to be acting against the "security of the state". The Times of Israel quoted Israeli Communications Minister Shlomo Karhi who said Israel was at war on "land, in the air, at sea, and on the public diplomacy front".

On 20th October 1496, the second daughter of Ferdinand of Aragon and Isabella of Castile married Philip, Duke of Burgundy. The marriage was part of a double treaty. The brideâ€™s brother, Juan, Prince of the Asturias (Crown Prince) was married to the groomâ€™s sister, Marguerite of Austria. At the time of the marriage, Juana, as well as a brother, had an older sister living, so it was not anticipated that she would bring anything to the marriage other than her dowry. Philip, Duke of Burgundy since the death of his mother, Mary, when he was a small child, was the son of the Emperor Maximilian, and was likely to be Emperor himself in due course. The marriage, passionate at first, descended into utter misery, as Philipâ€™s philandering enraged his wife, and her reaction, seen as hysterical and unseemly, become the talk of Europe. Both the siblings ahead of Juana in the succession died, leaving her as Queen of Castile in 1504. Philip tried to dominate the government of Castile, and came into conflict with Juanaâ€™s father, Ferdinand, who did not want to cede control. Philip died suddenly, and Juana spent most of the rest of her life held under restraint, first by her father, then her son, the Emperor Charles. There is an excellent book on Juana and her sister Katharine, by Julia Fox, read our review here. http://bit.ly/18urEhn:=:https://tudortimes.co.uk/books/book-reviews/sister-queens Pic shows altarpiece in Royal Museum of Fine Arts in Belgium.

Tonight, President Biden is expected to announce billions of dollars in funding for Israel, after announcing millions of dollars in relief funding for the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. When will the two parties that control this country learn? For nearly one hundred years, Israel and her neighbors have been at war. Hardly a day goes by that there is not some kind of violence, or conflict, in the Gaza Strip. And we fund both sides. Now we are paying to bomb and destroy and paying to build it back up. Itâ€™s time to stop funding war, and start funding peace. My heart aches for those killed in Israel. I have two daughters who regularly go to concerts, and I couldnâ€™t bear to lose either of them in the way those in Israel have lost their loved ones. But we cannot make a problem better by doing what has made it worse over and over again. From Syria to Iraq to Libya to Afghanistan, the American record of choosing sides in a war is dismalâ€“ for civilians on either side, for our service members, and for our citizens here at home. Many of my fellow Libertarians would argue that we should spend nothing, and they may be right, as doing so may cause more harm than good. However, if we are to take taxpayer dollars from hard working Americans and send it to a foreign conflict it should be directed towards peace instead of war. Funding one or both sides of a conflict directly is pouring fuel on an already raging fire. Our billions, and our military might, should be used to support peace either directly, as we did with the Camp David Accords, or through a neutral country like Switzerland, who has remained neutral in two world wars. Our billions should be a bounty for peace instead of bombs. I am on the side of less wars. I am on the side of less death. And I believe funding warring governments has never led to either.
Plus: theyâ€™re expensive as all hell!!!

Iâ€™ve found it hard to express the collective trauma, depression, rage, grief and helplessness that myself and so many Sudanese people wrestle with on the daily since April 15, 2023. 

I find it hard just BEING of the diaspora, because Iâ€™m privileged enough to be spared the most horrid realities of the conflict thatâ€™s engulfed my motherland, while so many suffer an unjust fate. 

I find it hard to look at these pictures, they remind me of a lifetimeâ€™s worth of stories and lessons my parents,  as well as the local community, imparted on me. Stories of our traditions, our heritage, our lineage, and our pride lays here in the lands of our forefathers. The sacrifices our elders made to give us a chance at a better life, the selfless  acts my parents undertook to insure I would always know where Iâ€™m from and the lands to which I must return. To understand that weâ€™ve been granted a more bountiful life but all those roads lead home. To aid, to uplift, to use what powers Allah has granted us for the betterment of our people. 

Today,  I feel like Iâ€™ve failed. This same house whose roof we stand upon is no longer ours. It was stormed by rebel militia and taken over, with our family expelled from the premises. The home my father grew up in lays in rubble after an army air strike. 

I find it heartbreaking  to see my parents and our elders in this way. Lost, disconnected, depressed. The country theyâ€™ve served a lifetime uplifting is now one which they cannot even return to. These homes that have bound us to the land for generations have been uprooted and decimated all in the name of war criminals vying for power, funded and supported by various foreign nations with their own interests. 

Fuck the politics of it all, I find it hard just to pickup the phone and hear the next horror story. With many of my friends and family amongst the 7 million displaced, and close to 10,000 dead, with no end in sight. 

I find it hard to express the feeling of loss, the sorrow of losing our beloved city, losing our beloved country. 

On 10/24, I will try.

Israel is finalising the closure of Al Jazeera over its coverage of the ongoing conflict in Gaza, which it says is helping Hamas.

The Qatar-based network is the biggest Arabic language news outlet providing televised and online updates on the situation in Gaza, within Israel and in other occupied Palestinian territories.

On Friday, a number of Israeli media outlets, including i24 News and Times of Israel, said that the Israeli government had approved â€œemergency regulationsâ€ that would shutter broadcasters that are deemed to be acting against the â€œsecurity of the stateâ€.

The Times of Israel quoted Israeli Communications Minister Shlomo Karhi who said Israel was at war on â€œland, in the air, at sea, and on the public diplomacy frontâ€.

Before the ban on the network is enacted, it will need approval from Israelâ€™s Defence Minister Yoav Gallant, who is expected to sign the regulation.

Although floated as temporary, the ban can be renewed at 30-day intervals.

The move against Al Jazeera comes amid a wider crackdown on opposing views within Israel.

Karhi has also proposed targeting any journalist, including Israelis, who are deemed to be â€œharming national moraleâ€.

Journalists and other citizens could have their homes searched, property seized and could be placed under arrest for speech the government deems undesirable.

On the international front, Israeli public diplomacy accounts have condemned media outlets for getting their news from â€œterrorist organisationsâ€.

Al Jazeera has a vast operation within Gaza, which will likely continue to broadcast out of the besieged territory.

The network has a frosty relationship with Israel despite being one of the first in the region to interview Israeli figures on-air.

In 2022, Palestinian-American Al Jazeera journalist Shireen Abu Akleh was shot dead by an Israeli soldier while reporting in Jenin.

The network most recently condemned Israel for a missile attack on a group of journalists in Lebanon, which included its own reporters.

World News:
Two American hostages - a mother and her daughter - were released from Gaza by the Izz el-Deen al-Qassam Brigades, Hamas' armed wing.

The group's spokesman, Abu Ubaida, announced the release of the US citizens on Friday, stating it was done "for humanitarian reasons, and to prove to the American people and the world that the claims made by Biden and his fascist administration are false and baseless." Ubaida noted that Qatar made this release possible. 

In a statement, an IDF Spokesman said, "Hamas presents itself to the world at this hour as one who releases hostages for humanitarian reasons, but in reality, we are talking about a murderous terror group, which at this hour is holding babies, children, women, and elderly captive."

According to Israeli officials, the two Americans released by Hamas are 59-year-old Judith Ra'anan and her 18-year-old daughter, Nathalie. They both are from the suburbs of Chicago and were abducted by Hamas while visiting their grandmother in the town of Nahal Oz near the Gaza Strip. 

According to Israeli officials, the attack on Nahal Oz resulted in 130 out of the 471 Israeli civilians living in the city being shot or taken hostage. 

This development comes as the death toll from the conflict between Israel and Hamas continues to rise. According to Israeli officials, 1,400 people, including civilians and foreigners, died after Hamas launched attacks on October 7. Officials in Gaza have reported that over 4,000 people have died due to Israeli airstrikes, a significant number of them being women and children.

In healthier, assertive communication, the focus is on expressing feelings and needs while also showing a willingness to listen, understand, and work collaboratively to improve the relationship.

1ï¸âƒ£ Respect: Both partners show respect for each otherâ€™s opinions, feelings, and boundaries.
2ï¸âƒ£ Active Listening: They actively listen to each other without interrupting and make an effort to understand each otherâ€™s perspectives.
 3ï¸âƒ£ Open and Honest: They are open and honest about their thoughts and feelings, even when discussing difficult topics.
4ï¸âƒ£ I-Statements: They use â€œIâ€ statements to express their feelings and needs, rather than using accusatory â€œyouâ€ statements.
5ï¸âƒ£ Empathy: They show empathy and understanding towards each otherâ€™s emotions and experiences.
5ï¸âƒ£ Problem Solving: They work together to find solutions to issues, rather than resorting to blame or criticism.
7ï¸âƒ£ Setting Boundaries: They establish and respect personal boundaries and understand each otherâ€™s limits.
8ï¸âƒ£ Non-Verbal Communication: They pay attention to non-verbal cues, such as body language and tone of voice.
9ï¸âƒ£ Validation: They validate each otherâ€™s feelings and experiences, even if they donâ€™t necessarily agree with them.
ğŸ”Ÿ Conflict Resolution: They approach conflicts in a constructive manner, seeking compromise and resolution rather than escalation.
â€Œ
This approach promotes empathy, cooperation, and conflict resolution, ultimately leading to stronger and more balanced connections.

Until this week, Josh Paul wasnâ€™t well known beyond diplomatic and military circles. Heâ€™d worked at the State Department for more than 11 years, focusing heavily on the issue of arms transfers to other countries. Heâ€™d watched as the U.S. sent weapons to many troublesome regimes, but he thought his input helped keep the system from thoughtless overreach.

The U.S. rush to arm Israel in its battle against Hamas militants was a breaking point for Paul. The 45-year-old made waves when he quit his job in the Bureau of Political-Military Affairs and posted a resignation letter that he said resonated with many inside the State Department. In it, he condemned the Hamas attack as a â€œmonstrosityâ€ but wrote that he believes Israelâ€™s military response will only lead to more and greater suffering.

We interviewed Paul, who studied the Israeli-Palestinian conflict academically â€“ he wrote his masterâ€™s thesis on Israeli counterterrorism and civil rights. He has also lived in the West Bank. 

In a conversation with @politicomag, Paul laid out why he thinks the U.S. approach to this war is wrongheaded and why Israel should pursue options beyond an invasion of the Gaza Strip. He even read some excerpts of the emails he sent to his former superiors.

Read the full Q&A at the link in our bio. https://politi.co/3MbojZU

Londonâ€™s Metropolitan Police on Friday said they will not be arresting anyone chanting a popular slogan used by Palestinian activists during demonstrations.

The slogan in question, â€œFrom the river to the sea, Palestine will be freeâ€, is commonly heard at solidarity marches and refers to the area of historic Palestine between the River Tiberias and the Mediterranean Sea.

Pro-Israel groups claim it is antisemitic because it is an implicit call for the destruction of Israel, a charge rejected by Palestinian activists.

The police forceâ€™s guidance comes ahead of what are expected to be large demonstrations in support of Palestinians on Saturday.

Passions have been running high in the UK as the conflict in Gaza rages on. Palestinian activists have previously expressed concerns about the criminalisation of political expression and free speech when it comes to criticising Israel.

Earlier in October, British Home Secretary Suella Braverman advised police forces across the country to look into the possibility of whether the waving of Palestinian flags amounted to a criminal offence.

â€œBehaviours that are legitimate in some circumstances, for example, the waving of a Palestinian flag, may not be legitimate such as when intended to glorify acts of terrorism,â€ she wrote in a letter to police chiefs.

As things stand, under British law, expressions of support for proscribed groups, such as Hamas or Hezbollah, can lead to arrest with the possibility of fines and prison sentences for those convicted of an offence.

The civil rights group Liberty has condemned what it calls the governmentâ€™s attack on â€œthe ability to stand up for what we believe in is our fundamental rightâ€.

â€œRecent government responses to protests relating to Israel and Palestine are an attack on that right, and an attempt to erode the way we can make our voices heard,â€ the group said in a statement on X, formerly known as Twitter.

A 50-year-old Indian-origin doctor working at a hospital in Bahrain was arrested on Thursday, October 19, for anti-Palestine posts on social media.

Dr Sunil J Rao, a specialist in internal medicine at Royal Bahrain Hospital, was terminated immediately before his arrest.

In a series of posts on X, formerly Twitter, Rao supported Israel amid its conflict with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.

â€œIsraelFightsBack will do a scorched earth attack, plenty will be killed, displaced, Hamas will be destroyed (rightly so), then what? If I may ask? #Israel #Gaza #IsraelPalestineConflict. Occupy under military force? one of the posts reads.

Rao was arrested by the Anti-Cyber Crimes Directorate of the General Directorate of Anti-Corruption and Economic and Electronic Security for violations of civil peace and social stability that could affect societyâ€™s security and safety.

In a statement, Royal Bahrain Hospital said, â€œIt has come to our attention that Dr Sunil Rao who is working as a Specialist in Internal Medicine has posted tweets on social media that are offensive to our society.â€

It added, â€œWe would like to confirm that his tweets and ideology are personal and do not reflect the opinion and values of the hospital.â€

â€œThis is a violation of our code of conduct and we have taken the necessary legal actions and his service has been terminated with immediate effect.â€

Before the hospitalâ€™s response, Rao took to X and wrote, â€œI profoundly regret my words & actions.â€

He added, â€œI would like to apologized about the statement that I posted on this platform. It was insensitive in the context of the current event. As a doctor all lives matter. I respect this country its people and its religion deeply as I have been here for past 10 years.â€

Dr Sunil J Rao, who hails from the Indian state of Karnataka, is a graduate of Andhra Medical College in Visakhapatnam, India and completed his MD from Kasturba Medical College in Mangaluru, Karnataka.

The population of the Gaza Strip is 2.2 million.

The narrow slice of land covering 140 square miles â€” roughly the size of Las Vegas â€” is one of the most densely populated places on earth.

Two-thirds of the Palestinians living in Gaza are refugees or their descendants from the 1948 war, and most of the population is Muslim. There is also a small native Palestinian Christian population.

Since 2007, Gaza has been under a strict land and sea blockade by Israel that prevents civilians, along with goods like food and medicine, from easily moving across the border, contributing to harsh economic conditions and high poverty levels.

Culturally, education has remained a top priority. More than 95% of children aged 6-12 in Gaza attend school, and most graduate from high school. Additionally, 57% of students at the Islamic University of Gaza are female.

The drive for attaining education is part cultural, part pride, and it all goes back to the 1948 displacement, says Maha Nassar, an associate professor in the School of Middle Eastern and North African Studies at the University of Arizona.

Many Palestinians simply don't get the chance to grow old â€” dying in their early adulthood either in conflicts or due to a struggling healthcare system â€” which drags the averages down.

The 16-year blockade has hampered fast access to medical care and caused shortages of essential supplies like gauze and I.V. bags, says Yara Asi â€” an assistant professor of global health management and informatics at the University of Central Florida, and the author of the upcoming book, How War Kills.

"They're constantly dealing with short-term health issues, and those that need chronic care either don't get it or have to leave."

Hell on Earth, 1968

The Vietnam War changed the traditional American attitudes to war, as war became more televised and the average citizen witnessed the true horrors and challenging circumstances of a conflict zone. Soldiers became more vocal in their opinions on war and the army. Designing their lighters was one of these ways of self-expression. 

Lighters were popular as army food rations had a daily pack of cigarettes (usually four cigarettes per pack). Marijuana also grew in the wild in Vietnam. Many US troops (over 50 per cent) smoked Marijuana at least once to deal with the stress, trauma, and pain of fighting a jungle war they were unprepared for.

Lighters symbolised temporary peace, addiction, and the psychological traumas that the Vietnam War caused many soldiers.

The voting age during this time in America was 21, while the age to enlist (or get drafted) was 18. In 1971, President Nixon passed the 26th Amendment, which lowered the voting age to 18. 

These lighters show the attitudes that many of the US soldiers had towards politics, serving in Vietnam, and their opinions on killing and death, and what it took to be a man, thousands of miles away from home, in the green inferno that was the Vietnam War. 

Source: BBC

Nearly two weeks after the deadliest conflict between Israel and Palestine in recent memory broke out, killing thousands of civilians on both sides, Indian PM Modi spoke to Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and assured him that New Delhi will continue to send humanitarian assistance for the Palestinian people.

PM Modi also conveyed his condolences over the deaths of around 500 civilians in an explosion at the Al Ahli Hospital in Gaza. Palestinian authorities blamed Israeli air strikes for the explosion at the hospital, while Israel said it was caused by a misfired rocket launched from Gaza by the militant group Palestinian Islamic Jihad.

PM also shared with Abbas India's "deep concern" over terrorism, violence, and the deteriorating security situation in the region.

"Spoke to the President of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas. Conveyed my condolences at the loss of civilian lives at the Al Ahli Hospital in Gaza," Modi said on X.

"We will continue to send humanitarian assistance for the Palestinian people. Shared our deep concern at the terrorism, violence and deteriorating security situation in the region," he said. "Reiterated India's long-standing principled position on the Israel-Palestine issue," the prime minister added.

Palestinian news agency Wafa reported that in the telephonic conversation with Abbas, PM Modi reaffirmed India's unwavering support for peace based on international law and expressed his solidarity with the Palestinian people during these trying times.

He emphasised the importance of returning to negotiations and dialogues to achieve a lasting peace in the region, it said. Ministry of External Affairs spokesperson Arindam Bagchi has said that India's position concerning the Palestine issue has been "longstanding and consistent".

"India has always advocated the resumption of direct negotiations towards establishing a sovereign, independent & viable state of Palestine living within secure and recognised borders side by side at peace with Israel. That position remains the same," he said.

According to the MEA, India's support for the Palestinian cause is integral to the nation's foreign policy.

So many people are looking for â€˜peace' in others while neglecting to live peaceful lives to foster peaceful relationships ğŸ¤”

There are many problems with this, first things first: this tendency to rely on others for â€œinner peaceâ€

This idea that peace can be found in another person leads to codependency. You should not be emotionally reliant on someone to be your â€œpeaceâ€ in order for you to be happy, this will inevitably strain the relationship and create more conflict (the same conflict that youâ€™re trying to avoid)

Many desire peace until they're asked to take responsibility for their actions that cause chaos

At times, someone may avoid a relationship with you because you hold them accountable and express your feelings, which they interpret as 'stress.' 

They then seek someone new who is â€˜stress-free' to evade introspection. This behavior results in a pattern of shallow connections, as they prioritize avoiding conflict over building genuine intimacy.

They often enjoy the initial infatuation stage with someone new but shy away from the deeper, more intimate aspects of a relationship. This infatuation can be thrilling, but sustaining a meaningful connection requires going beyond surface-level attraction and doing some of the hard work

True intimacy is built on trust, vulnerability, and open communication, and it's only in these deeper layers of a relationship that lasting peace and fulfillment can be found.

There are many collective shadows that we are being asked to illuminate and transmute at the moment. 

And this is one of them.

This is most likely one of the hardest the look at and Illuminate.

Over the last few days I sat with all the ways I have done that.

I've explored the ways I have done things that deep down I knew would hurt someone else, yet I still did it.

Underneath, there was often helplessness, powerlessness, deep hurt, fear and despair that I was running away from.

I've had to look at my own capacity for evil. And this is something I work on keeping in check regularly, especially in heightened times.

There is an energetic bigger game that is at play.

In order to anchor peace on the planet, we need to look at and integrate the consciousness that would be responsible for total destruction. We are asked to do that right now.

If you think of evil as a spirit that gives us the false impression that we have power over someone else's life... That is what I am talking about. 

Artificial power, that is disconnected from our true source of power. Our inner divinity.

We get to transcend that consciousness and all the ways we rationalize using that.

This consciousness is at the core of the conflict we are witnessing in the middle east at the moment, if not all wars.

It uses our pain and despair to hijack our capacity for discernment, wisdom and love.

My prayer is that we get to a place where honoring other people's sovereignty as much as we honor our own becomes common sense. That's the space where peace exists.

In gratitude, X.

The recent conflict in Israel and Palestine is, for me, a stark reminder of the fragility of peaceful social and religious relationships, and how we should strive to keep politics separate from these as much as possible. I do not take the socioreligious harmony we have here for granted, so when I can, I try to do my very small part by participating in various religious festivals and celebrations.

So I was honored last week to attend Zhun Ti Tangâ€™s Nine Emperor Godsâ€™ Ceremony, held at #Rivervale, in lieu of my colleague @chuakhengwee (who was traveling). The proceedings lasted a good few hours, during which I learned about the origins of the various practices, including the lighting of nine lamps (one for each deity), the invitation to visit from the water, and the prop that accompanies the sedan procession.

I am neither Taoist nor Buddhist, the two groups that (in Singapore) celebrate the festival. Nevertheless, I believe that the respect we confer on othersâ€™ exercise of their faithâ€”especially when they take the effort to invite you to partake in something so special to themâ€”is more important than the need to strictly adhere to oneâ€™s own religious norms. It is for this reason that, when I visit a wake, I am willing to light incense; I believe, after all, that I am honoring those not only those that have passed, but also those who remain and are in mourning.

My thanks to the organizers for the invitation, and I wish them and all devotees a meaningful period of prayer and reflection for the remainder of the festival.

Breaking up from a long-term relationship and then returning to it has probably been my most requested experience to write about. And I have! A lot. But Iâ€™ve sat on everything since because it has all felt too present to examine in public. â€˜Write about scars, not the woundâ€™ the saying goes, and so despite writing being the best kind of catharsis for me and against the will of my internal voice which was desperate to share and connect, I lent into instinct and decided to wait.

I think you naturally start craving more privacy as you grow older. I certainly feel more protective over my sense of self and my relationship than I used to. I knew if I was going to write about the experience, I didnâ€™t want it to be about the mechanics of what happened Ã  la reality TV, but rather what it was like for me to not be someoneâ€™s partner for the first time in my adult life. 

Iâ€™d never lived by myself, never since my teenage years not had to consider compromising for the sake of harmony. But while I was slipping into new confidences to see how they fit, I was also trying to navigate how to make better a relationship which still, in so many ways, lit up my life. That confusion and conflict riding alongside an adolescent independence which mostly manifested in food, food, eating and food: thatâ€™s what I wanted to write about.

So thatâ€™s the part Iâ€™ve decided to share. I talk about indulging in dinners and staying up late like a teenager, luxuriating in the novelty of not sharing a routine and home with anyone. I talk about feeling disappointed with myself, peering round the corners of the ghost lives I didnâ€™t live and wondering â€˜what if?â€™. I talk about the feared judgement of reconciling, of wondering whether everyone will think Iâ€™m a coward. And of course I speak about love, big fat fully hearty stubborn love, and the crucial decision of actively deciding to be together rather than it being a default.

Hand on heart, that 6 month period last spring was my necessary cocoon moment; I needed to quit avoiding and face the truth of myself, and I came out of it feeling both happier in my identity and happier in my relationship. 

The link is in my bio/stories. I hope you enjoy.

Two weeks have passed since Iris Winnow returned home bruised and heartbroken from the front, but the war is far from over. Roman is missing, and the city of Oath continues to dwell in a state of disbelief and ignorance. When Iris and Attie are given another chance to report on Dacreâ€™s movements, they both take the opportunity and head westward once more despite the danger, knowing itâ€™s only a matter of time before the conflict reaches a city thatâ€™s unprepared and fracturing beneath the chancellorâ€™s reign.

Since waking below in Dacreâ€™s realm, Roman cannot remember his past. But given the reassurance that his memories will return in time, Roman begins to write articles for Dacre, uncertain of his place in the greater scheme of the war. When a strange letter arrives by wardrobe door, Roman is first suspicious, then intrigued. As he strikes up a correspondence with his mysterious pen pal, Roman will soon have to make a decision: to stand with Dacre or betray the god who healed him. And as the days grow darker, inevitably drawing Roman and Iris closer togetherâ€¦the two of them will risk their very hearts and futures to change the tides of the war.

ğŸš¨STATEMENT OF FC BAYERN MUNICH REGARDING NOUSSAIR MAZRAOUI

FC Bayern Munich held a detailed and clarifying conversation with Noussair Mazraoui this week. The reason for the discussion was Mazraoui's Instagram posts in connection with the terror against Israel almost two weeks ago, which led to irritation and criticism.

"Noussair Mazraoui has credibly assured us that as a peace-loving person he resolutely rejects terror and war and he never meant to cause any irritation with his posts", said Jan-Christian Dreesen, CEO of FC Bayern explaining, "FC Bayern condemns Hamas' attack on Israel" - "Furthermore, Noussair Mazraoui declares, "I condemn all terrorism and terrorist organizations."

FC Bayern and Noussair Mazraoui strongly oppose the transfer of the Middle East conflict and its violence to Germany, which is committed to peace. Hate and violence of any kind have no place in the political culture of Germany.

FC Bayern stands by Germany's Jewish community and by Israel's side; nothing justifies the murder of children and families.

FC Bayern believes that football should unleash its power of reconciliation between different cultures, especially in the most difficult moments. Noussair Mazraoui will remain in the FC Bayern squad, but is out of action due to an injury he sustained. [FCB]

Amid ongoing Israel-Hamas war, Nobel Laureate Kailash Satyarthi, with other nobel laureates has appealed for compassion for all children in the war reminding the world that all the children in Israel and Gaza are â€œour childrenâ€ and need protection and immediate humanitarian aid.

In a joint statement, in a rare initiative, 29 Nobel Laureates joined Indian Nobel Laureate Satyarthi in signing a statement today reminding the world that all the children in Israel and Gaza are â€œour childrenâ€ and need protection and immediate humanitarian aid.

The Nobel Laureates from all the six Nobel fields called for urgent release of the kidnapped children and a safe passage for all the children away from the conflict.

The statement jointly said that all children and vulnerable persons must receive humanitarian aid immediately, and "compassion should not be reserved for only one group of children in the war-torn zone" as shown by many protests and leaders.
