Even knowing all that I know about Islamophobia and Anti Semitism, about racism and colonialism and the history of this conflict, having been to the region, knowing what I know about intergenerational trauma and how it perpetuates cycles of violence, none of it wraps me in that raging confidence I used to speak from in my 20â€™s. Now I feel like a child in the corner, paralyzed, pleading, please stop hurting each other. Here are some words from @artforum and a group of artists about the immediately unfolding humanitarian crisis. Sharing this is not intended to support Hamas, nor to ignore the awful atrocities that Israel has faced. It is a response from a world who is afraid they are witnessing a genocide in real time. It is not a complete statement, and does not begin to speak to the level of grief and loss that every person affected by this conflict is facing. More is needed, more empathy, more willingness to see the heartbreaking complexity, but it is a start. The letter is closed but they list more ways to help through its link. â€œCultural leaders including Nan Goldin, Judith Butler, Laura Poitras, Barbara Kruger, Kara Walker, Saidiya Hartman, and Emily Jacir have signed an open letter calling for an immediate ceasefire and the opening of Gazaâ€™s crossings to allow humanitarian aid to enter unhindered.

From the open letter:
â€œWe support Palestinian liberation and call for an end to the killing and harming of all civilians, an immediate ceasefire, the passage of humanitarian aid into Gaza, and the end of the complicity of our governing bodies in grave human rights violations and war crimes.â€

â€œWe, the undersigned, reject violence against all civilians, regardless of their identity, and we call for ending the root cause of violence: oppression, and the occupation.â€

â€œWe call on you to refuse inhumanity, which has no place in life or art, and make a public demand from our governments to call for a ceasefire.â€
â 
Image: Emily Jacir, Memorial to 418 Palestinian Villages Which Were Destroyed, Depopulated, and Occupied by Israel in 1948, 2021, refugee tent, embroidery thread, record book.â€

For one day, just one day, ask yourself this question before everything you do:

ğŸ‘‰ Is it easy?

If the answer is â€œyes,â€ itâ€™s the wrong project, activity, path, etc. 

Here are few examples:

- Watching TV is easy; reading a book hard.
- Coming home from work and plopping on the couch is easy; going to gym or even a 45 minute walk is hard.
- Staying quiet during your work meeting when you know the answer is easy; speaking up and owning the solution to the problem is hard.

If you want to grow as a leader, salesperson, parent, lover, etc. â€œeasyâ€ should be a negative filter. 

Nothing worth doing is easy, not over the long termâ€¦

- Purpose. 
- Happiness. 
- Satisfaction. 
- Meaning. 
- Connection.

These are the result of struggle and the associated conflict and pain which accompany it.

All Iâ€™m asking is that you choose hard for one day.

Shitâ€¦ make ONE hard choose today.

Make one hard choice in which you normally would have picked the easy option.

Then HIT REPLY and tell me about it.

I will happily share that victory with you! 

Easy is for the ordinary.

This is the way. 

#findingpeak

A Coral Gables dentist was fired after a viral video showed him tearing down posters of kidnapped Israelis. Now, he's telling his side of the story. Dr. Ahmed ElKoussa and another man were caught on camera taking down the flyers in Brickell on Tuesday night, and the video was quickly posted all over social media.
By Wednesday morning, ElKoussa had been fired by his employer, CG Smile. On Thursday, ElKoussa spoke to reporters alongside his attorney Hassan Shibly to explain that he feels the video was widely misinterpreted. 

"Unfortunately my video of four seconds got taken way out of context as well as the way that my former employer had portrayed it, that it's an act of supporting terrorism," ElKoussa told reporters Thursday. "It's the very very very contrary, it's to promote peace, it's to deescalate the situation that we're going through and make sure that our communities are safe."

The fliers are part of a nationwide project by Israeli artists that show photos of missing civilians in Israel who have been kidnapped by the Hamas terrorist group after the attack on Israel nearly two weeks ago. The fliers are also posted to trees and other utility poles throughout South Florida. ElKoussa's attorney told NBC6 that the dentist was afraid the posters would spark conflict and talked to police before taking them down.

ElKoussa has received hateful messages and death threats since the video went viral, his attorney said. Shibly said ElKoussa didn't mean to offend anyone and that he stands for peace and unity. He said the website that posted the video incorrectly assumed ElKoussa's intentions. Shibly said he's demanding an apology and for ElKoussa to be reinstated.

Cild, the wish that came true

With the war between the Cosmic King and those who opposed his reign continuing, legendary beings have spawned left and right to defend their sides. And while this is all occurring, many tend to forget the innocent. Countless casualties have already been reported for the fight of the galaxy, and still, it doesn't end. And with each loss, a whisper is being muttered, a wish for the galactic conflict to stop. And through these wishes, Cild was born. He is an anomaly, a creature made from people's hope. The oddity resembles that of a child, a happy one, accompanied by two mysterious hand-like beings. His powers are currently unknown, but reports of war zones suddenly being abandoned, and when the soldiers were asked why, they all felt an overwhelming warmth that stopped them from causing harm to anyone. Cild was last seen making his way to the center of the war, the place where Jacketman and his team landed to fight against the forces of Garrant.

With a lot of hurt in the world, most of us are trying to process this global grief. 

Combining the state of the world, the change of seasons and the holidays fast approaching, grief enters its way into our hearts and minds. 

Grief is unfortunately unavoidable in life. It is the natural response to loss. Often grief is associated with death, but we can grieve lots of losses: unemployment, ill health, relocating, end of relationships and war and conflict in the world.

Conventionally grief is focused on emotional responses but it can also impact us physically, cognitively, behaviorally, socially, culturally and spiritually.

We all grieve differently.
There is no right or wrong. 
There is no timeframe or finish line.
There is no set pattern or predictability. 
There is not a time when grief
is completed. 
We find ways to live inside the grief and in doing so, it finds its own place within us.

Due to their impact on the limbic system, essential oils can help facilitate release of these common emotions that result from grieving. They can help shift perspective and allow us to process our emotions in a healthy manner. We can also use past memory scent associations of our loved ones to comfort us during challenging times. A map of Israel after the Six-Day War in 1967.

After World War I, the British created the Mandate Of Palestine in an attempt to give Jews a "national home" in Palestine.

As more and more Jews arrived, the tensions between Israelis and Palestinians grew larger. Israeli and native Arab tensions exploded after Israeli independence, culminating in many Arab-Israeli wars. The final war in 1967 resulted in the Israeli occupation of the Palestinian territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

The dispute between Israel and Palestine still persists today, and is one of the most controversial issues in the world.

What is your opinion of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict?

â€œWe share in the relief that their families, friends and loved ones are feeling,â€ he says in a statement to the press. â€œBut there are still 10 additional Americans who remain unaccounted for in this conflict. We know that some of them are being held hostage by Hamas, along with an estimated 200 other hostages held in Gaza.â€

â€œThey include men women, young boys, young girls, elderly people from many nations. Every single one of them should be released,â€ Blinken states.

â€œSince the earliest hours of this crisis, the president has made clear that he will do everything possible to secure the release of every hostage. During my own recent travels in the region, I emphasized the urgency and importance of this is to the United States and pressed our partners to do everything they can to help us secure their release,â€ he says.

â€œI canâ€™t speak publicly about the details of these efforts. I know you understand that, but the urgent work to free every single American, to free all their hostages continues, as is our work to secure the safe passage out of Gaza for the Americans who are trapped there,â€ Blinken asserts.

It was a long journey last night and Iâ€™ve never come closer to missing a connecting flight but miraculously Laura and I and even our gear has reached Tbilisi! Playing tonight with new material and a whole new format geared towards the club ğŸ–¤

Images by @laxdoela from our performance in Munich. 

Also just want to add that these last few days have led to the sharpest uptick of really nasty messages in my DMs that Iâ€™ve ever seen. Standing up for human rights means standing up for humans EVERYWHERE to live in peace. My passion on this subject is derived from having visited Auschwitz at 15 and truly internalised the message â€˜never againâ€™. It is starkly clear to me that violence against civilians is never the conflict resolution technique that those in power think it is. Trauma remains in our bodies and hearts for generations, and the trauma in the eyes of every child in Gaza and Israel shatters my heart because I know it will remain with them forever. This is not an issue that should be considered controversial. Please take a moment to imagine that those of us taking a stand are doing so because we care about HUMANS and wish to stand on a side of history that allows us to sleep at night. 

That said, the messages of support have been even more plentiful. And tend to be from those with far more at stake in the conflict, Palestinians and Israelis alike. Many have expressed that they donâ€™t feel like they can be outspoken for fear of consequences and thatâ€™s really alarming. 

So please, if you have a platform and a voice, and the only thing youâ€™re afraid of is losing a few followers, donâ€™t remain quiet. The reward to your conscience will outweigh the pushback from those who donâ€™t yet understand what weâ€™re fighting for.

Lokesh Kanagarajâ€™s Leo starts with an acknowledgment that itâ€™s inspired by A History of Violence (2005), the David Cronenberg action thriller based on John Wagnerâ€™s graphic novel of the same title. A History of Violence is about a man who wants his past self dead. He is devastated when he finds him still alive. Leoâ€™s Parthiban seems caught between wanting to pay homage to this hero and pandering to the fans who want Vijay to be a remorseless badass.

The conflict, therefore, is just your regular masala film conflict â€“ itâ€™s external and rooted in all the bad people who have to be killed one after the other. Lokesh seems unsure of what he wants Parthiban to be â€“ is he regretful or ashamed of his past, or does he revel in living under a stolen identity?

Read the full review by @sowmyarajen by clicking the link in bio/stories

The world is never entirely up or down at the same time. This past weekend, I was lucky enough to find myself standing in the center of an â€œup.â€ I married my best friend, and loveâ€™s gravity revealed itself through our family and friends. Iâ€™m grateful for that, and it really put some things into perspective that I refuse to take for granted. These sort of moments are made through love itself. Through kindness. Consideration. Unity. Love is, and will never not be complicated, but itâ€™s always worth it. It is the strongest foundation we can build our lives on, and it starts one brick at a time. One moment at a time. One good deed at a time. It exists in ebb and flow, and weâ€™re unable to receive it without giving it first, unconditionally. Thatâ€™s not always easy, as the past two weeks of conflict in particular have shown. Wherever you are at the moment (up, down, or somewhere in the middle), I wish love upon you, and I hope you share it â¤ï¸ğŸ™ğŸ»

Over 150 Berkeley High students walked out of class Wednesday in a pro-Palestine rally to call for a ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war after the surprise deadly attack by Hamas almost two weeks ago and the retaliatory airstrikes by Israelis.

The protest is part of a larger day of action organized by the Arab Resource Organizing Center of San Francisco. The attack by Hamas on Israeli soil left at least 1,400 Israelis dead. More than 3,300 people in Gaza have died since Israel began retaliatory air strikes in the territory, according to the BBC, and a ground offensive is expected.

â€œWe refuse to stay silent while so many families are being massacred and millions are being forcibly displaced,â€ one Berkeley High student said at the protest.

â€œWe are calling for an end to the occupation that Palestinians have endured for 75 years,â€ said another.

Marching from Civic Center Park to UC Berkeley, students chanted, â€œStop bombing Gazaâ€ and â€œFrom the river to the sea, Palestine will be free.â€

Students at the rally drew attention to the plight of Palestinians over several decades of armed conflict in the region, describing Israelâ€™s hand in creating an apartheid state that they said operates like an open-air prison. Since Hamas seized power in 2007, Israel has blockaded the Gaza Strip, home to more than 2 million Palestinians, controlling trade and restricting residentsâ€™ movement in and out of Gaza.

#flashbackfriday At times, as a door gunner, I was fortunate enough to witness glimpses of the serenity that Afghanistan had to offer from a birds eye view.
Looking at it, sometimes could be so breathtaking that you are so wrapped up in it, you donâ€™t even think to take a picture. For brief moments, you forget about the chaos, your take off and LZ hard times, fuel checks, your purpose for even being thereâ€¦youâ€™re just a human, in awe at the magnitude of the landscape.
The landscape that has stood the test of time and countless attempts at invasion by foreigners from a far away â€œmore civilizedâ€ placeâ€¦
The result in the end? The same. Forever a barrier, forever a fortress to those who have lived there for thousands of years, forever wild and ruthlessâ€¦BUT, forever breathtaking.
As it was, as it is, as it will be.
Whatever feelings I have about the â€œconflictâ€ are irrelevant. In those moments where we were pulled out of it for even a second, and just existed so very vividlyâ€¦is where I learned to simply just â€œbeâ€.
-
-
-

PCRF has delivered fifty cartons of water and essential food parcels to our Dr. Musa and Suhaila Pediatric Cancer Department in Gaza. These supplies are not mere provisions; they are life-saving lifelines for our Pediatric Cancer Department. Gaza is in the throes of an unprecedented shortage of drinking water, food, and medicine, a crisis pushed to catastrophic levels due to the ongoing conflict. In this extremely dire situation, the children in our Pediatric Cancer Department, already battling cancer, face an additional challenge. The war has made it impossible for them to receive their crucial chemotherapy treatments.
In the face of this extreme adversity, your support is their lifeline, a glimmer of hope amidst the overwhelming darkness they face. We extend our deepest gratitude to everyone who made this life-saving initiative possible.

Charges laid following officer-involved shooting

One man has been arrested and charged in relation to a shooting incident that occurred in September 2023, on Glenmore Trail and in the southeast community of Seton. One man was transported to hospital in serious condition as a result of the September shooting. It is believed that both the offenders and victim are associated to rival organized crime groups in Calgary, and that the victim was targeted due to this conflict.

Investigators identified several potential suspects, and given their demonstrated violence and history of court-ordered firearm prohibitions, investigators engaged the Tactical Unit to conduct the arrests of the suspects.

ğŸ“ On Wednesday, Oct. 18, 2023, while attempting to arrest two suspects, an officer-involved shooting occurred at approximately 2:40 p.m., in the 5700 block of Falsbridge Drive N.E. One suspect was pronounced deceased and one police officer was transported to hospital in stable condition. A second suspect was taken into custody, and upon his arrest, officers located a loaded handgun in his possession. The Alberta Serious Incident Response Team (ASIRT) continues to investigate the circumstances surrounding the officer-involved shooting and no additional details can be released about this incident.

Today, Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023, officers executed a search warrant on the suspectâ€™s vehicle, which resulted in the seizure of two additional loaded handguns. Photos of these firearms are included in this post. 

ğŸ“ŒThanh NGUYEN, 25, of Calgary, has been charged with one count each of attempted murder, discharge a firearm with intent, possession of stolen property over $5,000, unlawful possession of a firearm in a vehicle, unlawful possession of a restricted firearm with ammunition, possession of a weapon obtained by crime and possession of a restricted firearm contrary to a prohibition order. NGUYEN will next appear in court on Friday, Oct. 27, 2023.

This investigation remains ongoing.

Iâ€™m half Palestinian. One of my best friends is half Jewish (top left) We both have relatives in the conflict zone. I care about the safety of his family. He cares about the safety of mine. Both of us were born in the United States and grew up without a deep connection to this part of our heritage. I was adopted and only just a few years ago found out my biological father and that whole side of my family is Palestinian. It led me to meet blood relatives for the very first time. I think this conflict is difficult for both of us in the sense of identity. On one hand, we were not raised with the deep cultures of our people...and yet in recent years, we have embarked on our own separate journeys to connect with the culture and history of our ancestors. He would take a bullet for me and I would take a bullet for him. But we wonder how things would be if our upbringings were different. Would we be able to get along during this time? Maybe in a different world, we might even see each other on opposite sides of a battlefield? The point of this post is not about â€œtaking sidesâ€. I see many people putting a spotlight on the violence and bloodshed that has taken place and continues to take place. I think the point is maybe hope?... hope of co-existing? Itâ€™s so hard to see all this death. There are aunties, uncles and even siblings Iâ€™ve never met yet who I worry I might never get a chance to meet. I wonâ€™t pretend to be an expert on the Middle East. But what I do know is this...when you take away the titles. â€œPalestinianâ€ â€œJewishâ€....thatâ€™s what me and Sam are. Thatâ€™s a truth. But our other truth is that we consider each other brothers...not by blood...but by the love and respect we have for each other as HUMAN BEINGSâ€¦and I just feel like thatâ€™s getting lost in all of this.

The United States using its veto power to block a UN Security Council Resolution for a 'humanitarian pause' in Gaza has once again ignited debates about the efficacy of the United Nations, particularly in times of conflict. The Security Council is the UN organ primarily tasked with maintaining international peace and security. It can issue ceasefire directives, deploy peacekeeping troops, and impose economic sanctions â€“ the only UN body with the power to take tangible measures as opposed to recommendations. In 2005, UN member states affirmed their responsibility to collectively protect their populations from genocide. The World Summit Outcome Document states: â€œThe international community, through the United Nations, also has the responsibility to use appropriate diplomatic, humanitarian and other peaceful means, in accordance with Chapters VI and VIII of the Charter, to help protect populations from genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanityâ€¦in a timely and decisive manner, through the Security Councilâ€¦â€â 
â 
However, the notion of the UN's "neutrality" comes under scrutiny â€“ raising questions about whether it is a mere tool for powerful nations to exert geopolitical dominance rather than being an agent of peace and change. Despite the UN proclaiming the sovereign equality of its members, its Security Council â€“ somewhat paradoxically â€“ grants permanent membership and veto power to the five victors of the Second World War, making it inherently undemocratic to many member states.â 
â 
Further, the organizationâ€™s commitment to neutrality, too â€“ often obscured by ideas of impartiality â€“ fosters a "white savior" lens, implying that Western actors are uniquely qualified to intervene in conflicts when it aligns with their objectives, undermining the agency of local actors and perpetuating power imbalances. This raises valid concerns about the organization's ability to act as a true global force for positive change, particularly when powerful nations exert influence through mechanisms like veto power in the Security Council.

Day 17 (albeit a little late), and piece 7/8 of my Inktober prompt inspired collection: demon ğŸ˜ˆ

This design is one of my personal favorites from this collection. The detail of the blood/tears are something Iâ€™m especially pleased with.  It represents two sides to a storyâ€” is the creature bleeding or crying? And if so, why? Itâ€™s easy to misinterpret things we donâ€™t fully understand. I could come up with examples but it would be an infinite list.

I find that misunderstandings are the source of much conflict that could otherwise be avoided or worked through. Itâ€™s easy to reach for a conclusion based on the bias of what we *do* know and how we feel, but that leaves out truths we arenâ€™t aware of. 

Perspective is everything. And oftentimes, weâ€™re only privy to a single one: our own. Imagine thatâ€¦ one perspective, trying to interpret a world made of billions. It makes sense that there would be a lot of misunderstandingâ€¦

Palestinians eagerly await the first international aid delivery to Gaza, on Friday, as Israeli forces pounded the enclave and warned of a ground invasion "soon", continuing its relentless air strikes for more than 13 days.

The US Special Envoy for Middle East Humanitarian Issues, David Satterfield, is negotiating aid delivery modalities with Israeli and Egyptian officials.

The United Nations (UN) has called for aid to return to pre-conflict levels of 100 trucks a day. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres planned to visit the Rafah border crossing from Egypt to Gaza on Friday, a move that Israel's ambassador to the UN, Gilad Erdan, told a rally in New York City showed that "his top priority is giving aid to the terrorists."

â€œRaffy is currently in Egypt, covering the expected repatriation of Filipinos who were caught in the Israel-Hamas conflict in Gaza,â€ she added, extending her support to Raffy. 

â€œIngat ka diyan, mahal! Youâ€™re doing an exceptional job covering everything on your own,â€ she continued.

The black bear has risen in stature to one of our stateâ€™s most valued animals â€“ by wildlife watchers and hunters alike. Maineâ€™s expansive northern, eastern, and western forest supports the largest population of black bears in the eastern United States, and MDIFWâ€™s black bear monitoring program is one of the most extensive and longest-running programs of its type in the U.S.

Our bear management program strives to balance biological and social needs and uses long-term monitoring of black bears, harvest data, and conflict data to inform management decisions. Maineâ€™s 10-year big game management plan includes goals, objectives, and a series of management strategies designed to ensure continued enjoyment of black bears without too many conflicts in backyards and neighborhoods.

To learn more about Maine black bear monitoring, management, harvest, conflict prevention, and research, take a look through the Game Species Conservation & Management Section of the 2022-2023 Research + Management Report by following the link in our bio.

New Delhi: At least 21 journalists were among the more than 4,000 dead in Israel and Palestine since the war started on October 7, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists.

As of Thursday, the committee reported that of the 21 confirmed dead, 17 journalists were Palestinian, three Israeli and one Lebanese. Eight journalists were also reported injured and three were reported missing or detained.

â€œCPJ emphasizes that journalists are civilians doing important work during times of crisis and must not be targeted by warring parties,â€ said Sherif Mansour, CPJâ€™s Middle East and North Africa program coordinator. â€œJournalists across the region are making great sacrifices to cover this heartbreaking conflict. All parties must take steps to ensure their safety.â€

More journalists have been killed in Gaza during the past two weeks than since 2001 in the territory, Mansour told AP. Reporters in Gaza face power and internet outages under Israeli siege, and many have lost their offices, homes and family members.

Gaza health officials said as of Thursday, Israelâ€™s airstrikes have killed 3,785 people and wounded more than 12,000. These airstrikes came after the Hamas militant group attacked Israel on October 7, killing more than 1,400 people. Israel said at least 203 people are being held hostage in Gaza.

CPJ published descriptions of the journalists killed, injured, detained and missing so far.

Of the reporters killed is Ahmed Shehab, a journalist for Sowt Al-Asra Radio (Radio Voice of the Prisoners). Shehab was killed in an Israeli airstrike on October 12 that struck his house in the northern Gaza Strip, along with his wife and three children, according to The New Arab.

Read more at thewire.in

JANM condemns the recent anti-Muslim hate crime in Plainfield, Illinois. Six-year-old Wadea Al-Fayoume and his mother, Hanaan Shahin, were stabbed multiple times by their landlord, killing Wadea and seriously injuring Hanaan. When the landlord expressed that he was angry at her for what was happening in Israel and she responded by saying â€œletâ€™s pray for peace,â€ he attacked her and her son with a military-style knife. The hate crime was motivated by the landlordâ€™s anti-Muslim bias and his anger about the Israel-Hamas war. He was charged with three counts of murder, one count of attempted murder, two counts of aggravated battery, and two counts of committing a hate crime. 

â€œWe are deeply saddened by this hateful act and by the rise of anti-Muslim and antisemitic rhetoric that has erupted in the US in the wake of the conflict in the Middle East. We grieve for the loss of life in the conflict and for the life of this child who was so brutally murdered. When fear and insecurity bind together, they create a dangerous poison that can inflict grave harm on individuals, heaping ongoing trauma onto communities, and etching deep wounds into humanity that fuels hate speech and violence. Hate crimes are not acceptable under any circumstances. We stand with our friends in communities across the country whose families are affected by this conflict, particularly with our friends in the Jewish American, Palestinian American, and Muslim American communities,â€ said Ann Burroughs, President and CEO of JANM.

The report of an investigation committee formed by the Dar es Salaam regional commissioner, Mr. Albert Chalamila, following a recent fire outbreak in Kariakoo at the auction mart area on October 1, this year, has revealed that the fire incident did not occur by accident but was planned by some traders from the area.

Speaking in his office today, after being handed the report from the committee that conducted an investigation for seven days, from October 7 to October 13, this year, Mr. Chalamila said the fire was an act of sabotage fueled by a conflict between the businessmen of the area and their leadership.

"The narratives of the traders and security guard who were interviewed after the incident seemed to have been rehearsed because they did not match what was on the CCTV footage," he said.

He continued, "The generator was not the source of the fire as it was initially claimed; the fire was started in the auction market."

The committee's report confirmed that the fire burned and consumed the entire area of the Kariakoo auction market, including 550 business stalls, 10 shops, and seven tall buildings, including those surrounding the area, while six people were injured by the fire.

Why She Doesn't Lust For You Anymore â¤ï¸â€ğŸ”¥

A couple years ago, the s/x started to dry up in my relationship.

Obviously this was extremely frustrating to me, because I'm supposed to be "the S/xual Kung Fu guy".

This was when I realized that it's one thing to have mastery in s/xual skills, but the dynamic of s/xual attraction and polarity is a separate factor - one I actually realized I didn't know much about. I was just trying to do what came naturally to me.

This lead me on a journey to understand the dynamics of sexual attraction, and this was when I realized I had been a feminized "nice guy". 

I had the tendency to avoid conflict with my woman at all costs, to initiate sex in indirect ways, and to suppress some of my deepest primal sexual desires.

I was not in my masculine strength, I was hiding it beneath a fake smile and a tendency to act nice and avoid speaking my true thoughts to please others.

I began to step into my assertive strength and leadership.

I started being very direct with my woman, expressing exactly what I wanted. I began to lead in our relationship.

I stopped hiding my resentments and using passive-aggressive unconscious behaviors.

I learned how to hold strong masculine presence - rather than trying to be my woman's 'friend' or 'therapist', I became her man. 

And I noticed a night-and-day difference in my relationship.

The sexual attraction became reignited, and I started having some of the most passionate and fulfilling sex of my life, with a woman I've lived in the same home with for 5 years. 

I'm seeing a lot of other men stuck in the same dynamics of people pleasing, nice guy syndrome, and settling for passionless sexless relationships.

As men, we were set up to fail in the modern world, never taught how to manage our sexual energy, how to manage our emotions, or how to sustain a passionate and balanced relationship.

This is why I created my new Sex God course - to guide you on the same transformation I went through ğŸ’¥

text:
DIFFICULT CONVERSATIONS. â£
â£
so many of them are happening right now. And Iâ€™ve been hearing from lots of people that they are paralyzed, stuck in the conflict over authenticity and attachment. â£
â£
We are born with a natural need for attachment. To our parents, our families, our communities. But we are also born with a fire of authenticity inside of us. We burn with the desire to be who we are, feel how we feel, think how we think. â£
â£
These two things can find themselves in direct conflict with one another. â£
â£
So, how do we stay attached to the people we love while still maintaining some level of our authenticity? The answer is, we tell the truth. When something is hard to say, instead of concocting a narrative that will convince somebody of your position, just say: I donâ€™t know how to do this. Iâ€™m lost. This is so hard to say.â£
â£
If you find yourself at an impasse, tell the truth. Not â€œthe truthâ€ that is the opposite of a lie. The truth that is the slow, mindful translation of your heart. Whatever that may be.â£
â£
You can do this. I send you big love.â£ğŸ’«

What a fun, magical grump/sunshine read Wolf Gone Wild is! Matteo is hexed, unable to shift and his wolf is constantly taunting him, so he finds a witch to help break this curse. Evie is one of the best hex-breakers out there, and seeing how Matteo is struggling, she agrees to help him, and spend four hours a day with him, since it seems being around her calms not only Matteo, but the wolfâ€”Alphaâ€”too, and once he seems Evie, heâ€™s decided sheâ€™s his. This is a slow burn read, a grump/sunshine, friends to lover, and just has a lot of sexy tension. These two have amazing chemistry and I loved the balance and struggle of Matteo and his wolf. The magic in this story is captivating and the magical community is so fleshed out. Alpha is so sexy and I loved his forwardness. I loved the banter of Alpha and Matteo but also the banter of Matteo and Evie. Matteo is so sweet and endearing, and Evie is just a nerdy burst of sunshine. Theyâ€™re so fun and I loved watching the two bloom and grow with each other. Their chemistry is so sweet and sexy, and I love the magical conflict so much. I always love a witchy read and this one didnâ€™t disappoint!

New Story By @musukn : The Language of Bones

20 years after Peruâ€™s Truth and Reconciliation Commission, exhumations continue. Conflict between Shining Path and the Peruvian government in the 1980s/90s led to almost 70,000 deaths and 15,000 people missing. 

For over 10 years Musuk Nolte has been documenting the process of grieving and the search for justice.

1.  Residents of Pujas accompany the remains of friends and relatives for burial.

2. Relatives of Arquimides Rua Gamboa watch the reconstruction of the remains of their father's body as it is returned to them.

3. Relatives gather at a wake after the bodies of those who were kidnapped and then murdered by a Peruvian army patrol in 1983 were returned by the Peruvian public ministry. 

4. A man wipes a portrait of Claudio Morales, killed by the terrorist group Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) in 1984. On 17 January, at around 4am, a squad entered the Morales family house while they slept. Without a known motive, they killed the four adults including Claudio, leaving 5 children who witnessed the murders and lived with the bodies for four days due to the isolation of their home.

5. Alejandrina Valenzuela cries as she stands in front of the coffins of her parents.

6. Burning candles at a mass wake for more than 100 victims of the Accomarca massacre. On 14 August 1985, a military patrol under the command of Telmo Hurtado killed almost all the residents of Accomarca, alleging they were members of Shining Path. Hurtado, nicknamed 'the butcher of the Andes', is now in prison after being extradited from the United States.

7. A wake in Pujas.

8. Urbano Huamani Vegara (47) during a burial service for his brother. 

9. On 16 July 1984 40 members of Shining Path commandeered a local bus travelling. Stopping in various towns, the guerrillas murdered over one hundred people who refused to join their ranks. The remains of 14 of those killed are finally put to rest in the Soras cemetery.

10. Zosimo Hilario whose father was murdered in 1991 along with 12 other family members by an army patrol.

Graduation ceremony at Nehale lyaMpingana Barracks celebrates military excellence

Staff Reporter

THE Army Battle School at Nehale lyaMpingana Barracks was a scene of celebration and achievement on the 13th of October as it hosted a joint graduation ceremony for four significant military courses.

These courses, the 11th Company Group Commanders Course, the 14th Platoon Commanders Course, the Platoon Sergeant Course, and the Section Commander's Course, aimed to equip students with essential knowledge in both Conventional Warfare and Low-Intensity Conflict Operations.

The ceremony was officiated by Brigadier General Andreas Diyeve, the Deputy Army Commander, and he extended his heartfelt congratulations to the graduates for their outstanding performances throughout the demanding training. General Diyeve emphasized the vital role these programs play in developing a highly trained military force.

In his address, the Deputy Army Commander stressed the cornerstone of success for all armed forces: training. He encouraged graduates at all levels and soldiers alike to cultivate a culture of continuous learning. He underlined the significance of prioritizing training to ensure that the defence force remains fully prepared to fulfil its national mandate in accordance with the laws of the Republic of Namibia. General Diyeve noted, "It is, therefore, of paramount importance that all commanders and uniformed personnel prioritize training."

Expressing his gratitude, the General acknowledged the Course Officers, Instructors, and all supporting staff for their unwavering dedication and commitment to imparting valuable knowledge and innovations to the members. Their contributions played a pivotal role in the success of the graduates.

Notably, the students who completed these courses came from all branches of the Namibian Defence Force (NDF): The Army, Air Force, and Namibian Navy. This joint graduation ceremony symbolized the unity and shared commitment of the entire NDF to empower the next generation of military leaders.

What feminism has taught me about nuance, grief, and loving across hard lines: A note from Charis Circle on Israel and Palestine. â 
â 
â€œFeminism taught me that power changes all who possess it. Feminism taught me that often where we begin telling the story of a conflict determines who the enemy is, as does the person telling the tale. Feminism taught me that â€œwar crimeâ€ is redundant because war is always a crime. Feminism taught me to fear fundamentalism of all kinds, and to fear theocratic fundamentalism the most, because women, children, queers, and trans people rarely thrive under conditions of religious fundamentalism. Feminism taught me that as long as we believe that only some children are â€œourâ€ children, no children will be safe and free. Feminism taught me that a human life destroyed by state violenceâ€“whether by bomb or famine or lack of electricityâ€“is not substantively different from a human life destroyed by more direct human hands. Feminism taught me that violence begets violence and vengeance is not justice. Feminism taught me that resistance often goes unvalued and unnoticed when it is led by women, when it is not sensational, when it is generative and collaborative. Feminism taught me that people seeking freedom from violence will sometimes use violence when it is the language that finally makes them heard. Feminism taught me that language, all language, is power. Feminism taught me that we must not abandon our radical imaginations. Feminism taught me it is possible to be in enormous pain and rage and not abandon each other.â€ â 
â

Reposted @copelandadventures The intractable Israeli-Palestinian conflict and its latest unimaginable horrors has shaken us all to the core. The pain from the brutality of the circumstances, like a vice around our hearts, is inescapable, no matter the affiliation. It is hard to contain emotions. 

Muhammad Deif and his Hamas butchers can only be qualified as inhuman. Who else would inflict such indiscriminate loss of life simply on the basis of religion? To call them animals is an insult to all species. 

As we collectively mourn this ongoing tragedy, we must also try to understand the source of this dehumanized indoctrination in order to correct it. A few things come to mind. 

People rarely turn into killing machines in a vacuum. The Hamas leadership must be eradicated, sure, but what does that mean? Without a change in policy and a philosophical commitment to humanizing relationships on both sides, despite the historical hardships, is it reasonable to expect a different outcome? 

Netanyahu has been in power for 16 years and his myopic leadership is at least in part responsible for the utter failure to prevent this tragedy. 

Hamas, on the other hand, has been ruling Gaza since the last elections, 18 years ago. In a survey conducted in 2021, the authoritarian government received merely 30% approval from its population. It is hard to imagine that number not plummeting given the scope of this ongoing destruction, inclusive of innocent Palestinians. 

To imagine peace we must refrain from retributive impulses; we must wipe the slate clean. Mandela and Gandhi taught us the value of forgiveness in the spirit of humanizing the peace process. 

Let us see in this tragedy an opportunity to usher in new leadershipâ€”on both sidesâ€”and reinvent a diplomatic coexistence based on shared values of peace and prosperity for all. Concessions must be made and a commitment to teach love rather than hate. Because the guttural pain of loss hurts universally. And we must forgive before more deaths escalate. 

As Buddha teaches, holding onto anger Is like drinking poison and expecting the other person to die. We stand with Israel and innocent Palestinians. We stand with peace. 
#isra

Death is political. Death is always political. Who dies, where they die, how they die, and whose bodies are respected, possible, and grievable are political questions of belonging and exclusion. Those buried within the manicured lawn of the cemetery, and those thrown into mass pits belong to different points along the same political continuum. 

The TD staff (and frankly, the majority of people you follow on social media) are not qualified to offer the proper historical analysis to current world events. But we do know who benefits and who does not from the violence facing us today. Those who benefit are those who want to keep us separated and polarized, those who try to convince us that we have incompatible stakes in this world, and those who benefit from the racist framing of contemporary violence. They are the weapons manufacturers, social media companies, political actors, nation-states, and fascists who refuse us all the possibility of a better world. 

In the fog of humanitarian crisis, war and violence, we can forget that, as the feminist scholar Judith Butler recently wrote, â€œThe question of whose lives are worth grieving is an integral part of the question of whose lives are worth valuing.â€ There should be no lives more grievable than others, especially when those who die are rarely those who hold positions of power. The â€œcollateral damageâ€ of this conflict are families, women, and children, and people who loved and were loved and whose lives are so passively and callously ended. The dead and those who are left to grieve their deaths are the ones who lose. We all lose.

We know that many of you are grieving just as we are grieving right now. Some of you may be personally impacted by this violence and there is little to say that can remove that pain. Returning once again to Butler, â€œâ€¦ hope no doubt seems naive, even impossible, to many. Nevertheless, some of us must rather wildly hold to it, refusing to believe that the structures that now exist will exist for ever.â€

To integrate the Ego is to understand why itâ€™s broken into pieces.

It is to ask yourself why one is in deep conflict within oneself.

When the Ego is hurt because of traumatic past, itâ€™s instinct is to self-protect.

It becomes essential to process this hurt. To rise above that insecurity and fear.

No matter how long it takes to keep walking that path that leads to inward clarity and resolve that inner conflict. 

I want to stand out but I also want to belong. I want to be free of fear but I am also attached. I want to discover, but I also presume to know. I want to teach but I am unwilling to learn. I want to trust myself, but I also doubt. I want to know who I am, yet I also compare.

To have an integrated ego to resolve all of this and to discover that this inward clarity and freedom is indeed possible.

A US Navy warship in the Red Sea intercepted several missiles and drones launched from Yemen yesterday.

IN RESPONSE to the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas in the Gaza Strip, a total of 77 Zambians, including 72 students and five other individuals, have been successfully evacuated and returned to Zambia.

https://www.facebook.com/100064560977290/posts/728973465931346/

Currently, there are 172 Zambians living in Israel, with 143 being students and the remainder consisting of diplomats and other residents. 

The conflict in the Gaza Strip has resulted in the loss of approximately 3,000 lives.

Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Stanley Kakubo has Parliament that no Zambian has been killed in the conflict. 

Mr Kakubo said the Ministry is still in talks with the embassy there to ensure the welfare and safety of those who have chosen to stay back in the conflict zone.

The Minister was responding to a question raised by Pambashe Member of Parliament, Ronald Chitotela regarding the conflict in the Gaza Strip.

"I would like to highlight that Government has facilitated the voluntary, temporary relocation of all Zambians who have expressed a desire to return to our homeland for the time being. So far number totalling to 77 Zambians arrived safely in Lusaka as of October 18th, 2023, these include 72 students and five others. For those who have chosen to remain in Israel, be rest assured that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation will maintain close collaboration with the Embassy and the Israeli Foreign Ministry, and stands ready to take any necessary actions that will ensure their continued welfare and safety," he said. 

Mr Kakubo said President Hakainde Hichilema has reiterated the importance of Peace, Security and Stability and it is in this vein that Zambia reaffirms its commitment to ensuring peace, stability and security.

â€œThe loss of lives in both Israel and the Gaza Strip is regrettable and we wish to extend our heartfelt condolences and sympathies to all the affected individuals and families. Madam Speaker, the international response to these unsettling developments has been resolute. Ik geloof dat 'wereldvrede' een taak is voor ons allemaal.â 
â 
Vrede is mÃ©Ã©r dan de afwezigheid van oorlog. â 
Het is elkaar vinden waar verschil is. â 
Het is liefde durven kiezen boven angst.â 
â 
Ieder mens draagt de kans op vrede in zich. â 
Je kunt elk moment beginnen.â 
â 
Door vrede te sluiten met wie je zelf ten diepste bent. â 
Door vrede te sluiten met je verleden en je systeem, je angsten en je pijn, je vergissingen en je verlangens.â 
â 
Door liefdevol te kijken, naar jezelf en anderen. â 
Geen conflict toe te voegen waar het niet is.â 
Te vergeven waar het wel is.â 
â 
Vrede betekent niet dat we allemaal hetzelfde moeten zijn; het betekent met liefde kijken naar het verschil.â 
â 
Ik geloof dat we dat kunnen.â 
Misschien wel dat we het verplicht zijn aan onze kinderen om het in elk geval te proberen.â 
â 
Als ieder mens in vrede leeft met zichzelf, zal er vanzelf wereldvrede zal zijn.â 
â 
Wees lief voor elkaar.â

Shulamit Nazarian is pleased to present â€œSweet Discipline from Koreatownâ€ an exhibition of new works by Ken Gun Min. In the artistâ€™s newest paintings, lush, floral landscapes and sensitively rendered, imaginative portraits are adorned with beads and embroidery. 
 
The paintings in this exhibition exemplify Min's intersectional engagement with the nuances of queer experience as an Asian man and his deeply personal approach to often unexplored social spaces and histories. Yet even as he mines his own feelings and experiences, Min pulls a wide range of references and associations into the work to consider the ways that power, race, and sexuality play into both local and global geopolitics. Certain works reference the history of conflict between Asia and Europe, the dynamic history of relations between different minority groups in urban conflicts, and the intersection of sexual and racial prejudice. By exploring stories that span contemporary reality and earlier historical moments, the paintings expand outward from Min's personal journey through Los Angeles to address the sublime encounter of splendor and darkness in the human experience.

ğŸ¨Ken Gun Min
13 Missing Ladies, 2023
Oil, Korean pigment, silk embroidery thread, beads, crystals

STATEMENT ON ISRAEL AIRSTRIKE AT GREEK ORTHODOX CHURCH IN GAZA

I have been notably silent on the current Israeli-Palestinian conflict as of late. I've done this because I did not want to distract from the current siege of Artsakh by the occupying Azerbaijani forces. As a Greek American, I consider the Armenian diaspora here in LA County to be my people because of our shared history and culture. 

Earlier tonight, IDF fighter jets launched an airstrike causing a Greek Orthodox church in central Gaza City to collapse, injuring many civilians. The violence we have witnessed in the last few weeks is not unlike the horrors coming out of Artsakh. The willingness to pick sides in a brutal conflict is beyond me. The awesome power of the United States must be used to negotiate a cease fire and support the victims and refugees of these horrendous wars, not provide weapons to authoritarian governments that we consider our allies.

Once the dust has settled and the injured are cared for and the dead have been buried, we must take a long, hard look how we, the wealthiest nation in the world, support imperialist occupation around the globe and recognize our role in those historic conflicts while working to undo the generational trauma it has caused.

"Until we are all free, we are none of us free." - Emma Lazarus

The amount of flat out incorrect or uselessly out of context information that is shared by people with night vision to people who are looking to get into night vision on the internet remains staggering. 

Opinions are opinions - they're worth what you pay for them, and everyone is entitled to one. What you then do with those opinions, in terms of how much they influence what you then pursue in terms of NV solutions, is the tricky part. 

The defining issue in the NV community today has to do with authoritative advice and sources, and being able to differentiate what sources are authoritative versus noise. 

Authoritative sources in the NV world will have experience both in terms of depth and breadth. Depth meaning significant time/repetitions in evaluating solutions or performance and breadth in terms of evaluating many devices, tube types, and in many varied use cases. Notice that this does not automatically make military or law enforcement authoritative sources (though a number of them are). For example, specific to advising new buyers, users who have lots of time using one device and tube type professionally may be of some help, but generally would not be an authoritative source on which of the many types of devices or tubes might be a good fit for a certain other user. 

On the flip side, nonprofessional enthusiast users have big limitations on how much they can realistically use night vision to build up a base of experience that is both broad and deep. It's not easy to just spend hours and hours out at night using this stuff all the time, and it's also not easy to be able to accurately compare tons of solutions side by side. But it is relatively easy to consume information online to then regurgitate as an enthusiast of something. 

We recommend professionals such as @mochabear_actual who have expanded on their professional use with their own testing and research, and especially those on this side of the industry who do not have the typical limitations on breadth of experience with NV. You need many perspectives to avoid conflict of interest, and ultimately you should be seeking firsthand experience more than secondhand.

Art is a portal. But only when you step into it with your heart. Art and Heart go together~ you see how theyâ€™re spelt. Creating is an act of inner love, expressing itself outwards from itself. The output might be the only visible part for everyone else, but itâ€™s the entire inner world that creates it. To make art, you have to first learn to love, no? (Not asking rhetorically- pls do share your opinion!)
Sometimes the hardest part of making art is the part where you have to dive deep into your head- or heart- or soul?- deep enough to get to the right place to express purely, without anything but flow and expression. The time is takes to keep your mental state in a place of creative flow, is part of the artâ€™workâ€™ too.

Our inner world is our own natural world. And itâ€™s our most precious place. 

If weâ€™re lucky enough to have peace, to have the time to cultivate our inner world because all other factors are already in place -and that we won some luck in the birth lottery- then may this be sent out as a beacon of hope to those who dont have this luxury - alongside protests, and other support. 
Despite the horrors of the world happening, I will still share art. The more suffering in the world, the more that Art, music, poetry, and peace- has a place. My heart goes to all those in Gaza, caught in conflict, caught in the fight of other men, whose fights mean that others lose their lives, or that the living lose their peace. This horrific genocide shows our broken patriachal systems. May change come soon. And may the UK and US governments step up soon. 

I will not close my eyes to whats happening in Gaza. But also, i will not close my eyes to the beauty and peace that still exists in the world. Thereâ€™s so much unbearable pain and so much unbelievable awe. Some photos of recent awe.

Bayern Munich on Friday said defender Noussair Mazraoui would not be suspended, after a probe into the Moroccan player over his social media posts on the Israel-Hamas conflict.

In the wake of the Hamas attack on Israel, Mazraoui had put up several pro-Palestinian posts, including one that called for "victory" for "our oppressed brothers in Palestine".

Bayern said they held a "detailed and clarifying conversation" with the player due to his "Instagram posts in connection with the terror against Israel almost two weeks ago which led to irritation and criticism".

But the club's chief executive Jan-Christian Dreesen said Mazraoui "credibly assured us he rejects terror and war" and "regrets if his posts caused irritation".

In the statement issued by Bayern, the Morocco player was quoted saying: "I condemn every kind of terrorism and every terrorist organisation."

Mazraoui will remain with the squad but is currently "out of action" due to an injury he sustained on international duty with Morocco, the club said.

On Oct. 19, #DOC Commissioner Louis A. Molina swore-in a new class of #CorrectionOfficer recruits at the @nypd Academy in College Point. The departmentâ€™s ongoing partnership with the #NYPD will allow these new recruits to train at their state-of-the-art facility for 12 weeks.

â€œWe are proud to welcome these new recruits to our Boldest family,â€ said Commissioner Molina. â€œThis is just the beginning, but this is a major step forward in their careers, for this department, and for public safety in our city. We look forward to seeing these new recruits flourish in our training program.â€

During the Correction Academy, recruits receive rigorous training from two dozen veteran DOC instructors in law, conflict resolution, de-escalation tactics, jail procedures, suicide prevention, physical conditioning, programming, firearms and report writing.

At the completion of their 12 weeks of training, the recruits will advance to facilities on Rikers Island for an 8-week field training program, where they will receive hands-on experience from veteran field training officers. This fully immersed training model is how the department is instilling proper correctional practices, improving training, and making its jails safer for our officers, staff, and people in custody.

Not only has my family been caught in the crossfire of a brutal conflict, but they recently experienced a devastating attack on the city Al-ailafoun where they were seeking shelter. Members of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) stormed the area, causing widespread destruction and tragically taking the life of a family member. During this horrifying event, my sick cousins life was also put in jeopardy, as one of the armed assailants held a gun to their head.

Their life is not only threatened by the violence surrounding them but also by a debilitating neurological disease that has left my cousin in desperate need of medical attention. The lack of resources in Sudan has made it nearly impossible for them to receive the necessary treatment, worsening their condition day by day.

Time is of the essence, as the routes out of Sudan are rapidly closing, leaving them with limited options for escape. We are urgently seeking donations to cover the costs of their evacuation and provide my cousin with the medical care she so desperately needs

Our immediate financial needs include funds for visas, flight tickets via Port Sudan, travel expenses from Madani to Port Sudan, and the essential medications required for my cousins neurological condition. Every little contribution will go a long way in helping secure their safety and access the medical attention they urgently require.

We understand that times are tough, and the world is facing numerous challenges. However, we firmly believe in the power of compassion and the collective strength of a caring community. By donating, no matter the amount, you can make a significant difference in their life and bring hope to our family during this difficult time.

Additionally, we kindly ask you to help spread the message far and wide. Share this appeal with your friends, family, and acquaintances, encouraging them to join us in our mission to bring our family to safety. Thank you.

A relationship means two sets of unconscious worlds colliding. History. Triggers. Unmet needs. Unconscious rules about how connections work.â£

There is going to be some conflict!

HOW we navigate those moments makes a huge difference to how happy & emotionally safe we feel in the relationship long-term. 

A lot of damage can be done in those moments of rupture. But a lot of healing can happen too.

If you learn how to understand whatâ€™s going on in a new way, & develop ways of listening & speaking that foster connection instead of distance, those hard moments will become transformative.

Of course, itâ€™s not all on you. There are two people in the relationship. But as ever we canâ€™t control other people or make them change or reflectâ€¦.

But we CAN have a massive impact of the trajectory of the dynamics we participate in. You are a powerful part of your relationships. The learning you do & the changes you make will make a difference.

ğŸ’¡ The Healthy Relationships Roadmap will give you the tools to better navigate your relationship. 

Module 1: Connect the dots between your childhood relationships & your relationships now

Module 2: Awareness. Learn how you show up in relationships & why. Get clear on your relationship patterns.

Module 3: Making changes: communication, better dynamics, boundaries, codependency, healthy conflict.

Module 4: Healing your relationship with yourself. Reparenting, inner child work, self-regulation.

Module 5: Healthy family relationships. Create an interdependent home environment & have healthy relationships with your children & partners.

Module 6: Develop a personalised blueprint to help you keep up the relationship awareness & habits youâ€™ve formed

That was one of a number of chants at the group's â€œCall for Anti-Imperialist Actionâ€ demonstration in which it protested the escalating war in Israel, particularly Israelâ€™s bombing of Gaza following attacks by Hamas â€” and the taking of an estimated minimum of 200 hostages â€” that left Israel and the world reeling.

Activists aimed their wrath at the second largest employer in the Berkshires and its business of developing technology to support the U.S. Navy, which the demonstrators say are used to harm and oppress people â€” including Palestinians.

Facebook-owner Meta Platforms on Wednesday introduced temporary measures to limit â€œpotentially unwelcome or unwanted commentsâ€ on posts about the conflict between Israel and Hamas.

Meta said it will change the default setting for people who can comment on new and public Facebook posts created by users â€œin the regionâ€ to only their friends and followers, Meta said in an updated blog post.

A Meta spokesperson declined to specify how the company defined the region. Users can opt-out and change the setting at any time, Meta said.

Hawa, 7, grieves her motherâ€™s death, on her grave in the cemetary were the loved ones killed in the earthquake in Seyad Aab village are now buried. With 340 dead for a village of 160 families, no one has escaped the harrowing pain. 
Habibullah, 72, has lost two sons, a daughter, and two nephews. He stands near graves that had been dug in anticipation of more deads arriving from other villages.
Younes and Sayed, two cousins, are still finishing to make the graves of their loved ones, including Younesâ€™ parents, and Saidâ€™s parents and four siblings.
Hawa has also lost three aunts. 
No home still stands, and itâ€™s getting cold. Itâ€™s hard to imagine how hard the future will be for those families who face not only the incommensurable pain but also who lost homes, and all they had, when they already had so little.
Like most of Zendajan district, the community of Seyad Aab village was already after decades of conflict and repetitive droughts.Â 
The village is one of the worst hit but not an exception, thousands havdied across several districts of Herat Province this month in the many earthquakes that hit in the span of now almost two weeks, and the loved ones who survived are left with nothing. Earthquakes continue. Dozens of thousands of people have been directly affected in Herat province and many more need support. 
Although it wasnâ€™t hit like the districts, in Herat city, people were sleeping in tents for fear another earthquakes would make their homes fall. Hospitals are overwhelmed. Humanitarian aid insufficient while thousands have no more home and the winter cold is settling.

Seyad Aab, Zenda jan, Herat. 10.14.23. With @iomafghanistan 

#earthquake #afghanistan #humanitariancrisis #herat

As the Israel-Hamas war escalates, its effects are being felt around the world, including in the Twin Citiesâ€™ Palestinian and Jewish communities.

Several Palestinian and Jewish community members who spoke to Sahan Journal expressed diverse opinions on the long-standing conflict, but shared a common feelingâ€”fear for family members who live in or near the combat zones in the Gaza Strip and Israel.

Despite the hum of worry that now runs through their daily lives, some community members expressed empathy for each other, and hope that the local communities could work towards understanding.

Read the full story at the link in our bio. Reporting by Cole Miska and Joey Peters. Photos by @aaronnesheim.

As you know, I decided to keep the #halloweencostume parade going in hopes to bring some light into the darkness (check out my previous posts). Itâ€™s been challenging w/recent events, both worldly & personally, as well as having promised myself to only use items I already own. Thankfully, I have yet to exhaust my hubbyâ€™s #horrormovie & memorabilia collection.

For the last couple years, Iâ€™ve wanted to do a costume w/these furry, flesh-eating #aliens, but I didnâ€™t know who I would pair w/them. Although the #Critters movie franchise is so recognizable, itâ€™s surprising how many people havenâ€™t actually seen the movies. Even if I dress like someone from the films, itâ€™s unlikely youâ€™d know who I was.

I guess I couldâ€™ve been one of the bounty hunters, especially because they can take on the form of whoever they see. Otherwise, itâ€™s just the average family/neighbors in a small rural community.

Did you know that @leonardodicaprio was one of those average everyday kids in a Crittters movie? Itâ€™s not his best work, but we all have to start somewhere.

So, back to the 6 degrees of Kevin Bacon inspiration, I thought Iâ€™d do the same thing w/ #LeonardoDicaprio & dress as someone recognizable from one of his other flicks.

Since my daughter is reading #Shakespeareâ€™s #RomeoandJuliet this year in her English class, I opted to dress as @clairedanes in #the90s @bazluhrmann movie version. I simply pulled out my old wedding dress, yet again, pairing it w/ #angelwings like the ones Juliet wears at the #costumeparty where she meets Romeo.

Romeo & Juliet fall in love (or infatuation) at first sight, despite their names. Their families were in conflict, but that didnâ€™t make them feel less for one another.

As Juliet says, â€œWhatâ€™s in a name? That which we call a rose. By any other word would smell as sweet.â€

Just like these Critters. Iâ€™d most likely stay away from the ones in the movie, but these are quite friendly.

Donâ€™t be so quick to judge people. Lead w/love â¤ï¸

Gaza in history: Gaza is no stranger to territorial conflict. 

Originally settled around 3000 bc as a fortress and trading post between Egypt and Canaan, the city of Gaza declined and was rebuilt several times during the Bronze Age. After serving as an administrative centre in ancient Egypt, it became one of five ports used by the Philistines. The Gaza Strip, incorporating a 25-mile stretch of coastline between Gaza City and Egypt, came into existence only after 1948 when the area was under Egyptian control.

Other political entities which have had control of Gaza over the centuries include: the Assyrian Empire, the Kingdom of Macedon, the Bedouins, the Seleucid Dynasty, the Nabataeans, the Roman Empire, Judea, the Fatimid caliphate, the Ottoman Empire and the British Empire.

From The Spectator barometer ğŸ“Š 

#thespectator

And second, that the â€œconflictâ€ in Palestine/Israel is not, and has not been, a â€œfightâ€, a â€œwarâ€, or a â€œstruggle.â€ There is a context, and the unavoidable context recognized by every significant human rights organization is simple: an illegal and immoral Occupation. The Cauvery River, which flows through the southern Indian states of Kerala, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, and the Union territory of Puducherry, has been a source of persistent and intricate water conflict. The dispute between Karnataka and Tamil Nadu over the Cauvery River is traced back to as early as 1890, with roots in the pre-independence era when the then princely states of Mysore (now Karnataka) and Madras (now Tamil Nadu) contended for control over the riverâ€™s waters. Even after independence, the issue has persisted, revolving around the judicious sharing and utilisation of water resources, and has resulted in numerous legal battles, protests, and political maneuvering.

The tussle between the lower riparian state of Tamil Nadu, with a share of 404.25 tmc (thousand million cubic feet) annually, and the upper riparian state of Karnataka, which has a share of 284.75 tmc, has aggravated today due to the failure of southwest monsoons in Karnataka this season. Judicial and quasi-judicial bodies formed to resolve the issues over the years have failed. Despite these efforts, a lasting resolution still needs to be achieved, with both states continually vying for their rightful share of the riverâ€™s water.

This article focuses on the key findings from research that must guide the dispute resolution mechanisms. It is high time to advocate not for the rightful share of water for each state but the reasonable share in water conservation mechanisms by both states given the climate crises.

As per the Nobel Laureate Ronald Coase, if there are low transaction costs and clear property rights, the two states could engage in voluntary negotiations to efficiently allocate the river water. However, the historical complexities of the dispute, high transaction costs, and political factors do not allow efficient bargaining.

Read more at thewire.in

#opinion #environment #cauveryriverdispute

What is happening in Gaza is neither a conflict, nor a clash, nor a crisis. We should use the right terminology. 
What is happening is #Urbicide, which as a term literally translates to â€œcity-killing.â€ The term has its roots in the Latin word â€œurbs,â€ meaning â€œcity,â€ and â€œoccido,â€ meaning â€œto massacre.â€ Urbicide is the deliberate murder of a city, premeditated and ordered. It involves the systematic and intentional destruction and organized violence against urban environments. Urbicide forms an important war tool, as it is a way to destroy collective memory, the lived space, and belonging, in addition to the direct killing of people.

Sources: 
Martin Coward, The Politics of Urban Destruction, 2009 
Fernando Mena, Urbicide, or the Cityâ€™s Liturgical Death, 2018

â€œa failure of imaginationâ€

I wrote these words months ago, not in response to anything happening in the worldâ€”but they mean something particular now.

I am convinced that the greatest accelerant to the conflict between Israel and Palestine is NOT ancient but modern: the most powerful, influential people in the world believe â€œit has to be this way.â€ Itâ€™s not that we overtly cheer when we see graphic images of slaughtered children. But if you bet on say the Celtics, then you â€œneedâ€ the Celtics to win. 

Christians in the west, who hold more sway than anyone as to how the world is actually shaped (despite all our protests to the contrary), are largely convinced that terror is an unfortunate but necessary part of the â€œscript.â€

We are told that the children of Abraham must be at war with each otherâ€”which isnâ€™t true. Isaac and Ishmael came together in peace when their father Abraham died, as I remember my beloved Sister Margaret Gaines showing me when she was still on this side of the veil. She considered herself no political radical, but she spent her life both immersed in the stories of Scripture and the stories of her neighbors in the Palestinian village of Aboud. 

It was also Sister Margaret that wrote that the suffering she saw in the land was â€œmanâ€™s idea not Godâ€™sâ€ and the product of â€œthe meddlesome zealotry of the churchâ€ attempting to force the end â€œbefore the time.â€ 

I donâ€™t believe that the stark images of Revelation give us an inevitable script for the end of the days. Misreading ancient texts is shockingly dangerous for our neighbors, and for ourselves. Contrary to popular opinion, the story of Scripture concludes by showing us how Love ultimately will overcome through self-sacrifice (I.e. the cross embraced by the lamb of God â€œloving not their own lives even unto deathâ€). Spoiler alert: itâ€™s not loving to wish war for your neighbors, to hasten your own cosmic salvation.

Christians coming out of the mass Ponzi scheme of toxic eschatology will make no small difference in the world. â€œBlessed are the peacemakers,â€ Jesus said. 

How tragic that many who claim to follow him are the greatest obstacle to peacemaking and, thus to peace, in our time.

Happy birthday, love! Whatever our souls are made of, yours and mine are the same. Your friendship is kind, undemanding, and empowering â€” it has carried me through storms and taught me that love is not without conflict, but one should always make space for those who matter. Iâ€™m grateful for this space that you create and hold for me. You inspire me and those around you way more than you realise. Hope you find your sky soon; Iâ€™ll always be in the front row to bring filter coffee and flowers and be your loudest cheerleader!

POLITICS ISRAEL CAPITOL HILL GAZA 400 Capitol Hill Staffers Call For Cease-Fire In Gaza The staffers signed a letter as bloodshed escalates and as elected members of Congress are largely in lockstep behind the Biden administration's approach to the conflict. By Rowaida Abdelaziz Oct 19, 2023, 06:47 PM EDT @ilhanmn

Last night, members of our campus community joined together for a Vigil for Peace to reflect on the ongoing conflict in Gaza and Israel. The event was held in collaboration with students from Jewish and Palestinian backgrounds to show support for one another and honor the lives lost. Those in attendance also had the opportunity to write messages that will be shared on campus. As Richard Smith, associate provost for equity and belonging, said during the vigil, â€œTonight, we stand together... our shared aspiration is a profound hope for humanity, a hope that one day peace will prevail.â€

On Thursday, I had my first chance to look across into Gaza from a vantage point in Israel. The view between the trees framed a mosque and minaret which, a few moments later, were surrounded by clouds of dust and smoke from an incoming strike. Minutes later, a column of smoke rose into the air from another. I hadn't picked a specific time of day to visit, and I was there for only twenty minutes before being forced to move due to outgoing rockets overhead but in those few moments, the regularity of the incoming shelling gave just the smallest glimpse into the hell that the population is going through within the border walls. I nearly made reference to "sides", but the suffering of innocent civilians is tragically universal.
.
.
.

William Sampson  Jordan was born in the state of Kentucky more than 195 years ago on January 7th, 1828 to his father Thomas and mother, Mary Jordan.

We know that he served in the military during the American Civil War. Whether he fought for the Union or (C)ondederacy is up for debate with mixed documentation / claims for both. Soldiers from Kentucky fought for both sides during the historic conflict. It's also possible that he ventured to the South and served in the Volunteer State of Tennessee. (A widows pension filed after his death offered no specifics whatsoever.)

At the age of 61, William Sampson married New Hampshire native, newly transplanted Florida resident,  mother of one, and the recently widowed, 45 year old, Henrietta "Etta" Duncklee Wade in Hernando County on September 10th, 1889. (We were unable to locate any previous marriages or children connected with tonight's subject.) It is unclear as to when and why Mr. Jordan relocated to the Sunshine State.

This evening's honoree supported his family as a grocery store merchant.

Regrettably, William Sampson would lose his life from the effects of  indigestion complications in conjunction with "senility" on April 7th, 1917. He was eighty nine.

â€¢â€¢ Surprisingly, according to William Sampson's death certificate Henrietta did not now much about his early life. This coincides with her lack of knowledge about his military service on her widows pension request Additionally, when "Etta" passed away in 1928 she was buried beside her first husband, Albert T. Wade who died in 1884 in an entirely different cemetery.

â—â— Imagine the incredible changes  he witessed firsthand in the form of history, technology, politics, and societal shifts !!

As Chicagoâ€™s Palestinian community mourned the loss of a 6-year-old boy who was stabbed 26 times by his landlord in a suspected hate crime fueled by the Israel-Hamas war, a group of rabbis attended the funeral to express their hope for peace.

Rabbi Ari Hart was one of several local Jewish leaders who came out to show their support for the family of Wadea Al-Fayoume, the Palestinian-American who was allegedly attacked with a 12-inch military-style knife by landlord Joseph Czuba, 71, as he shouted, â€œYou Muslims must die!â€

Hart said it was his duty to attend the funeral and help comfort the mourners as a means to condemn the bloody murder and advocate for peace.

â€œWe met with the Imam [muslim religious leader], heard from the father, and stood with the boyâ€™s community as they mourned this horrific loss,â€ Hart wrote in a Facebook post. â€œWe witnessed the pain.

â€œWe expressed our shock and condemnation of the attack. We wept,â€ he added.

Hart admitted that it was not easy for the group of rabbis to attend the funeral given the on-going conflict between Israel and Hamas, with Gaza resembling a war zone following unprecedented violence between Palestinians and Jews.

â€œBut the murder of a six year old because of his faith and his identity is not complicated. It is a heinous crime. And thatâ€™s why we went today,â€ Hart explained.

Despite the current divisions between their communities, Hart said he hoped the rabbisâ€™ attendance could serve as a reminder that peace is not out of reach for Jews and Palestinians.

â€œI canâ€™t give up on trying, yearning, dreaming, even right now, of finding the way to shalom,â€ he wrote. â€œThe way to salaam. The way to peace.â€

The rabbisâ€™ visit served as hope amid heartbreak for those in attendance of the boyâ€™s funeral, with father Oday El-Fayoume still in shock over the fate that befell his son and ex-wife, Hanaan Shahin, was stabbed more than a dozen times and remains in the hospital.

Via NPR: A State Department official has resigned from the bureau that oversees arms transfers to foreign nations, citing his objection to continued U.S. military assistance to Israel as its retaliatory bombardment and blockade of Gaza exacerbate a humanitarian crisis there.

Josh Paul was the director of congressional and public affairs at the Bureau of Political-Military Affairs. In a two-page letter posted on LinkedIn, he said he had made a promise to himself when he joined over a decade ago that he would stay â€œas long as I felt the harm I might do could be outweighed by the good I could do.â€

â€œI am leaving today because I believe that in our current course with regards to the continued â€” indeed, expanded and expedited â€” provision of lethal arms to Israel â€” I have reached the end of that bargain,â€ he wrote.

Paul tendered his resignation on Wednesday, the same day that President Biden visited Israel in a public show of support. The president pledged his commitment to its security and promised a congressional request for more defense funding, even as he urged Israelis not to be consumed by their rage and directed $100 million in humanitarian aid for Palestinians.

Paul wrote in his letter that he was heartened to see the administrationâ€™s efforts to temper Israelâ€™s response, including its advocacy for the provision of relief, supplies and safe passage for civilians in Gaza.

But he said he could not work in support of a set of major policy decisions â€” including â€œrushing more arms to one side of the conflictâ€ â€” that he believes to be â€œshortsighted, destructive, unjust, and contradictory to the very values that we publicly espouse.â€

The State Department declined to comment on personnel matters.

Paul said the first thing heâ€™d like the Biden administration to do is â€œsimply follow their own public commitments.â€

 Will link to full interview in our IG story.

Scotland's First Minister, Humza Yousaf, the first Muslim leader of a Western European country, has said Scotland was ready to offer asylum to the people of war-hit Gaza.
