Trinamool Congress MP Mahua Moitra's lawyer withdrew from a defamation case filed by her over allegations that she took bribes to ask questions in parliament after a dramatic 'conflict of interest' claim in court on Friday. The next hearing will be on October 31.

Supreme Court lawyer Jai Anant Dehadrai, who provided 'evidence' to BJP MP Nishikant Dubey against Moitra, told the Delhi High Court that senior advocate Gopal Sankaranarayanan, appearing for the Trinamool leader, had approached him to drop the CBI complaint against her.

â€œThe senior advocate called me yesterday and asked me to withdraw the CBI complaint in exchange for the return of the dog," said Dehadrai who is Mahua Moitra's estranged partner.

Moitra and Dehadrai have been fighting over their pet Rottweiler, Henry. In the last six months, the Trinamool MP has filed multiple police complaints against Dehadrai for alleged criminal trespass, theft, vulgar messages and abuse, news agency PTI reported, quoting Trinamool sources.

#CBI #MahuaMoitra #CashForQuery #CashForQueryScam #CBI #News

Did you know that a living trust can provide you and your family with peace of mind and protection for your assets?

Setting up a living trust allows you to retain control over your property while also ensuring that it is distributed according to your wishes after you pass away.

Without a living trust, your assets may be subject to probate, which can be a lengthy and costly process for your loved ones to navigate.

By creating a living trust, you can avoid probate and reduce the potential for conflict among your beneficiaries.

You can also protect your assets from creditors and minimize the tax burden on your estate.

Additionally, a living trust allows you to name a trustee to manage your affairs if you become incapacitated.

Don't leave your legacy to chance - take control of your future by setting up a living trust today.

Your loved ones will thank you for it.

Sri Lankan lawmakers express mixed views on Israel-Palestine conflict

Sri Lankan Parliament today called for a ceasefire in Gaza and called for a peaceful solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict.

SLPP MP Namal Rajapaksa who was speaking during the debate on the Israel-Palestine conflict said one road in Palestine is named after his father former President Mahinda Rajapaksa. â€œWe cannot condone violence unleashed by both sides involved in the conflict. What is needed is a peaceful situation,â€ he said.

Former President Maithirpala Sirisena said his party SLFP would continue with its traditional pro-Palestine line. â€œWe will stick to our traditional line but would stress for a peaceful solution to the conflict,â€ he said.

However MP Sarth Weerasekera who compared the situation in the Middle East with the civil in Sri Lanka said the two situations are different. â€œThere are no similarities between the Gaza conflict and the Sri Lankan civil war. It is ironical to see members of the Tamil Diaspora who opposed Sri Lankan government for confronting LTTE backing Israel who is engaged in killing innocent people. There should be a peaceful solution to the Gaza issue,â€ he said.

Tamil National Peopleâ€™s Front MP Gajendra Kumar Ponnambalam held an opposite view and said Sri Lankan government did the same thing in the North and the East which Israel is doing in Gaza today. â€œHospitals in the North were bombed during the Sri Lankan civil war just like what is done today in Gaza by Israel.

MP Rauff Hakeem questioned as to whether the Sri Lankan government is afraid of Israel. â€œWho told Israel that genocide is justifiable just because a terror group attacked its people. I wonder whether the Sri Lankan government is afraid of Israel."

JJB MP Vijitha Herath said what is needed is a universal call for a ceasefire in Gaza. â€œThis is not a time to find out who is right and who is wrong. What is needed is an amicable solution to the Israel and Palestine conflict. Nations such as USA should realize this situation and push for a peaceful solution,â€ he said.

â€˜A Constant Longingâ€™
10 stolen childhoods, 10 years of searching and reuniting
by AJAR and the Working Group on Timor-Lesteâ€™s Stolen Children

Hardback with exposed binding
16.5 x 23.3cm, 160 pages

Published by Asia Justice and Rights (AJAR) 
in association with SOKONG!
First edition, October 2023

â€”
Timor-Lesteâ€™s Truth Commission (CAVR) released a finding that thousands of children were taken, without consent, by Indonesian soldiers and institutions during the 1975-1999 conflict. In its 2005 Final Report, the Commission stated that â€œthe widespread practice of removing children displayed a mindset that by taking control of Timor-Lesteâ€™s territory, Indonesia also gained unfettered control over its children. ABRI (Indonesian military) members and other individuals with power in Timor-Leste felt that they were entitled to take an East Timorese child home without their parentsâ€™ permission.â€ 

For the past ten years Asia Justice and Rights (AJAR) and a working group for these â€œstolen childrenâ€ began its work to search for survivors, now adults living in Indonesia. 

To date, 171 survivors have been traced and 96 of them reunited with their families in Timor-Leste, with support from Indonesiaâ€™s National Human Rights Commission and Timor-Lesteâ€™s Centro Nacional Chega. 

Although hundreds have been traced, these efforts have only scratched the surface. Survivors and their families need long-term support to mend their broken lives. Their stories speak about a constant longing, through dark days of separation and uncertainty, and continue even after reunions, as each side resumes lives in different countries.

Some of the material for this photo-book came out of a series of workshops held by AJAR and the Stolen Children Working Group, in cooperation with Centro Nacional Chega and the Australian National University in July 2023.

Most of the photographs were taken during the family reunions which took place between 2015-2019 by members of the Labarik Lakon Working Group. 

â€”
For more information, contact @asiajusticerights or visit stolenchildren.asia-ajar.org

It takes 10 - 20 years to build a brand, a business, a Real Estate Company to trust. But it takes 1 second to ruin it and any 5 star google reviews - this highlights the fragility of reputation and the importance of maintaining a positive image and public trust.

We often receive screenshots or shares of REALTORÂ® Marketing asking for our opinion. From REALTORSÂ® and or Media Companies making fun of our profession, to REALTORSÂ® making fun of their culture and people, to peeing on walls and floors of properties & homes, to taking personal photos & poking fun of Seniors homes to the most recent disregard of the human life during war and conflict. 

Memes can be a fun and effective way to engage with audiences on social media platforms like Instagram. However, when it comes to using memes for REALTORÂ® marketing, there are several reasons why they are NOT the best choice. My question is - who should be policing this?

Real Estate is a serious and often high-stakes industry. Memes, which are typically humorous or light-hearted, may not convey the professionalism and trustworthiness that potential clients expect from real estate professionals. Using memes can make you appear less serious and incompetent, lacking professionalism.

Memes are typically short, image-based content that may not provide enough information about a property or the real estate services you offer. Real estate marketing often requires in-depth information about properties, their features, pricing, and location, which is difficult to convey effectively through memes.

In the wake of Israeli attacks on Gaza in response to 'Operation Al-Aqsa Flood,' initiated by Hamas, the response of Lebanon, Jordan, and Egypt reflects the contrasting dynamics of sovereign and captured states.

In Lebanon, the immediate spillover of the war to the southern Lebanese borders was met with an initial official silence. Iranâ€™s foreign minister made direct threats from Lebanon while the Secretary-General of Hezbollah refrained from commenting. Prime Minister Najib Mikati comically admitted that decisions regarding war and peace were beyond the government's authority. It is now 12 days into the war between Israel and Hamas, and Lebanese still donâ€™t know which fate awaits them.

On the other hand, Jordan, and Egypt, two nations with direct geographic connection to Israel and Palestinian territories, have not compromised their national interests while still committing to their unwavering support to Palestine. Jordan emphasizes the need to prevent spillover of the crisis into its territory, prohibiting protests in border regions. Egypt provides humanitarian aid to Gaza but refuses permanent relocation of Palestinians to Sinai due to security concerns. These nations maintain their sovereignty, with governments acting in the best interests of their citizens.

These three stances highlight how sovereign, independent nations assert control over their territories. However, Lebanon, facing unique challenges, struggles with the influence of non-state actors in crucial matters, potentially endangering its land and people in the face of an irreversible conflict.

India's delicate balancing act on the Gaza conflict saw PM Narendra Modi on Thursday speaking to Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and expressing condolences over the loss of civilian lives in the Gaza hospital bombing, which has outraged the world, while also announcing India will continue to provide humanitarian assistance to Palestinians.

Modi had last week expressed solidarity with Israel in a phone conversation with PM Benjamin Netanyahu and condemned the October 7 Hamas terror attacks that flared up into the present situation. Following the deadly hospital blast that reportedly left hundreds dead, the Prime Minister had for the first time on Wednesday expressed concern at mounting civilian casualties.

In his conversation with Abbas, Modi said he shared India's deep concern at "the terrorism, violence and deteriorating security situation in the region".

Friday started at Tel Aviv Museum of Art, and a "Shabbat Dinner" for the 203 people currently missing or held hostage by Hamas in Gaza. A powerful representation of the size of the group, the message was strengthened by the place settings with a handful of plastic plates and cutlery among the adult places. Again, words fail me as to how the families must be feeling.

Funerals have become a near-daily part of the coverage here, with families still burying their loved ones from the attacks of nearly two weeks ago. Today, it was two people from Kibbutz Kfar Aza. Both were deeply moving in their own ways; Omer Hermesh's love for Hapoel Tel Aviv F.C. meant his grave became a beacon of red. Mira Stahl's mourners reminded me so much of the friends I made in my 20's as I played music in Sheffield. Loving, close modern hippies who looked totally devastated to lose their friend in this violent way. During the traditional rush to fill the grave, one mourners bare feet against the earth galvanised that thought.
.
.
.

The key to peace? Women ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¿ 
 
â€œWomen play a crucial role in promoting peace. As mothers and wives, they are often listened to and respected within their communities. Women have a natural talent for promoting reconciliation and conflict resolution. 
Perhaps this is linked to their unique role in the creation and preservation of life, but they also have a unique ability to resolve issues when conflict arises. This highlights the importance of including women in peace and mediation processes, as their perspective and skills are invaluable in building a more peaceful future,â€ says Ibrahim Mariama Allassane, 70 years old, the coordinator of the Nigerian NGO RÃ©seau des Femmes pour la Paix au Niger (REFEPA Niger) which has acted as a trusted conflict mediator since 2006 and now focus more on women's rights and equal rights. 
In her experience, women donâ€™t play a sufficient role in building peace: â€œI would say that they have the potential and the necessary skills, but they are not always fully involved. In Niger, we have trained women mediators (â€¦) it would go a long way towards solving many problems and providing a better framework for the population through the mediation of women mediators.â€ 
Mariama and her colleagues at RÃ©seau des Femmes pour la Paix au Niger are the people inspiring change and peace on the frontlines of conflict â€“ and they will keep pushing: â€œOur main goal is to contribute, particularly through women's leadership, to influencing peace, working for its return and fighting for it. We want to be fully involved in conflict prevention and management issues at national level, while safeguarding women's rights. It is regrettable that during periods of crisis and war, women's rights are often neglected.â€ 

For the annual UN Security Council Open Debate on Women, Peace and Security, together with many other organisations, Oxfam is calling for the full, equal, meaningful and safe participation and leadership of women in all crises and conflicts and urge the Security Council, the UN, and Member States to uphold them. 
  #NoWomanNoPeace #WomenPeaceAndSecurity

â€œVoices of integrity, voices filled with conviction are a powerful force for good,â€ Daisaku Ikeda, the Japanese Buddhist philosopher, and nuclear disarmament advocate said. The ongoing battle between Palestine and Israel isnâ€™t just a war. It is a war on the mind and soul of every Israeli and Palestinian experiencing it, and the global audience watching it. Some with lament, and others with glee.

It is also destroying our trust in humanity. As much as we are made to believe that the conflict is about perpetual animosities, the truth is, it is all about land. What we are witnessing is an unending shrinking of a piece of land, an ongoing campaign to take it away from the people, and assemble them all in an untenable situation. It is a war where we are tuned to accept these mass atrocities, corroborated by an irresponsible media that has mobilised every racial trope of savagery that can be built on Islamophobia. The media has failed all these years to show the attacks on Palestinians shelters and refugee camps, ignoring their appeals to survive and somehow live together.

Traits of a Right-Brained Person

According to the left-brain, right-brain dominance theory, the right side of the brain is best at expressive and creative tasks. There are several abilities popularly associated with the right side of the brain. Based on these, a right-brained thinker is good at 2

Recognizing faces
Expressing emotions
Creating music
Reading emotions
Appreciating color
Using imagination
Being intuitive
Being creative

So what are so-called "right-brained people" like? They are often described as being more emotional, intuitive, and creative. They are often described as doing well in careers that involve creative expression and free-thinking, such as becoming an artist, psychologist, or writer.

Traits of a Left-Brained Person
The left side of the brain is adept at specific tasks. Characteristics of the left brain include those related to 1

Language
Logic
Critical thinking
Numbers
Reasoning

What are "left-brained" people like? They are described as logical, analytical, and orderly. The theory suggests that people who are left-brain dominant do well in careers that involve linear thinking, math, and verbal information. This includes careers such as accountant, scientist, or computer programmer. 
Have you ever heard people say they are more of a right-brain than a left-brain thinker? From books to television programs, you've probably heard the phrase mentioned numerous times. Or perhaps you've even taken an online test to determine whether you are right-brained or left-brained.

You've probably also spotted at least a few infographics on Pinterest or Facebook claiming to reveal your dominant brain hemisphere. Maybe you have come across a few articles or books suggesting you can unleash the hidden creativity of right-brain thinking or the deductive logic of left-brain thinking.

Given the popularity of the idea of "right-brained" and "left-brained" thinkers, it might surprise you to learn that this idea is just one of many myths about the brain.

Left Brain
Logical
Analytical
Linear
Verbal
Factual
Verbal
Sequential

Right Brain
Creative
Intuitive
Artistic
Non-verbal
Emotional
Musical
Imaginative

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡³ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§~ ğŸ‡¿ğŸ‡¼ğŸ‡¿ğŸ‡¦ â€¢ Soldiers from the Rhodesian (SAS), readying to board an AÃ©rospatiale Alouette III transport helicopter of the Rhodesian Air Force, for Operation Dingo, a Fire Force raid - against the Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army (ZANLA) headquarters at Chimoio, and a smaller camp at Tembue, in Mozambique, c. November 23th - 25th, 1977. 

Rhodesians, South Africans and the Congo Crisis â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸

__
It was one of the largest helicopter-borne raids conducted into Mozambique in the late years of the Rhodesian Bush War, an anti-insurgency conflict with similar complexity as the South African Border War fought by the South African Defense Forces in South West Africa and southern Angola, against Soviet-alined and supported enemy forces from the mid-1970s to the 1980s to January 1990, amidst the Angolan Civil War.

__
Photo source - militaryadvisorforfilmandtv.com/tag/warmovies/ 

__
The Rhodesian Bush War and South African Border War were not the only decolonization era conflicts that Rhodesians and South Africans fought in, many were mercenaries for the (breakaway and unrecognized) State of Katanga - during the Congo Crisis of July 5th, 1960 to November 25th, 1965. 

__
The Congo Crisis was one of many proxy conflicts in Africa - in which the Western Bloc (USA and NATO) opposed factions supported by the Soviet Union (Eastern Bloc and Warsaw Pact).

Flowers are absolutely not just decorative, but would it be such a bad thing if they were? This week on Their house, my garden, we cover the many reasons to let your garden bloom.

"Through summer in the northern hemisphere, hundreds of sunflower plants completely covered a terrace in the West Bank, Palestine. The green mass was tall and dense: they grew so thickly that you could not have passed through without damaging stems. At the top of it, yellow and orange sunflowers â€“ some bigger than your palm â€“ bloomed.

The sunflowers were not there to look pretty and joyful (though they did); they were there to repair the damaged and contaminated ground. The terrace has for decades been exposed to contaminants from armed conflict (like skunk-water) and urban pollution. Mohammed Saleh, a permaculture designer, educator and activist planted the sunflowers there to clean the soil.Â 

Bioremediation uses nature to heal contaminated and damaged lands and waters. It puts flowers to work, and sunflowers are particularly hard working. They can store radioactive elements like uranium and take up heavy metals like lead from the soil."

Read more about why to grow flowers at the link in bio.

This may not be for you.  And that's okay.
But this is my journal of journey, if nothing else. So if the words fit you, run with it.

I have spent so much of my life believing that being a peacemaker meant being the one who surrenders, the one who admits fault first, who sits at the table with palms up.

And those things are good.  I take pride in my ability to do them, and do them well. 

But taking joy in being the person who seeks resolution doesn't mean I sacrifice everything for everyone.  It doesn't mean I sacrifice every time, for someone either. I heard a speaker recently say that, at their core, all relationships personal and professional require three things: safety, vitality and repairability.  It caused me to realize, in conflict, I sacrifice my safety to seek repairability in order to bring out vitality.

And I have a feeling that quite a few of us have that.  We were taught to "take up our cross" and that everything would come out right.  We were taught to "turn the other cheek".

And those lessons aren't wrong--they just aren't absolute. You're allowed to draw the line in the sand to say "No, I deserve your attention. I deserve to know that you want me, that you see me." 

And if those needs aren't met, I can still acknowledge that I've been hurt, even if I've caused hurt.  But I'm tired of waiting for my reward for being a martyr.

I deserve love and attention and validation. 
And you do too.

Because we're human, and that's enough.

In 2009, I went to Rwanda to make a film about their national cycling team. It was the 15th anniversary of the jen-o-side. In 1994, the world watched idly as ONE MILLION  Tutsis and moderate Hutus were k*led in just 100 days. People were distracted (or more interested in) by that OJ Simpson car chase and Nelson Madella being elected as South Africa's president- how ironic. 

Conflict between the two tribes had history- agitated with help by the Belgians- ah yes hurrah for us fellow Europeans. In 1993, the Rwanda government, led by Hutu president Habyarimana, signed a peace deal with the rebel party composed of mostly Tutsis, in an effort to bring the confli*t to an end. In April, the following year, the president was as*asinated and the Hutu majority soldiers and police started the kil*ing spree.

People kil*ed their neighbours because the radio told them to. If you married into a Tutsi family, you were ordered to kil* them, or face being kil*ed yourself. 

This bright and colourful national cycling team, was born from the ashes of the jen-o-side. They were made up of both Hutu and Tutsi and a beacon of hope and inspiration, uniting the country. They were like beautiful kingfishers flashing down the mountains as they rode in their Peletons. One cyclist made the London Olympics. I was proper proud of him and the country to see him compete. 

Whilst spending time with them in Rwanda and learning about what happened, I wondered HOW could  what happen, happen and the world turn away?! Or be so slow to intervene.

If you've ever wondered the same, please take one minute of your day to fill in the petition (in my stories and bio) asking the UK a government to call for an immediate ceasefire. If it makes you feel uncomfortable, imagine how the Pale*tin*ans and Isra*lis are feeling right now. Parents carrying their children's body parts in bags is not the answer. 

Ps- I'm not making this about me, the algorithms prevent posts being seen about this.

The conflict in Israel and Gaza is deeply troubling and my heart goes out to the families of all those innocent lives lost on both sides.
 
Hamasâ€™s terror attack on Israel was absolutely barbaric and cannot be justified.
 
The indiscriminate bombing of civilians in Gaza is also barbaric and cannot be justified.
 
Israel has the right to defend itself. But that must be proportionate and in adherence with international law.
 
There has already been too much bloodshed during this conflict. I join calls for an immediate ceasefire and release of hostages.
 
It is also vital that there is continued humanitarian access to Gaza and sufficient supplies of food, water, electricity and medicines.
 
As humans, it is only natural that we would be affected by seeing such loss and suffering.
 
But here in West Yorkshire our diversity is our strength and we must pull together instead of apart during troubling times. We cannot allow the tragic events in the Middle East to divide our communities.
 
I am aware of a small increase in reports of both Antisemitic and Islamophobic hate crime since the conflict flared up two weeks ago.
 
And I want to be absolutely clear that we must not and we will not stand for any such threats and abuse in our communities. We are in touch with faith leaders and West Yorkshire Police and have been assured that there will be a robust response to any perpetrator of hate in our region.
 
I stand shoulder to shoulder with the Jewish and Muslim communities during this difficult time, as we think of the victims of this violent conflict.

The World Health Organization said Thursday that five trucks full of medical supplies are ready at the Rafah border crossing between Egypt and the Gaza Strip, with hopes that the aid could be delivered to Palestinian hospitals as early as Friday. â 
â 
"Our trucks are loaded and ready to go," WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told reporters. The delivery of aid would be the first since Israel imposed a complete blockade on the Gaza Strip, following the October 7 attack by Hamas militants that killed over 1,400 Israelis. â 
â 
Health authorities in the Gaza Strip said Thursday that at least 3,785 Palestinians had been killed by Israeli bombardment since the latest conflict erupted. â 
â 
While aid continues to build up on the Egyptian side of the crossing, Egypt is not allowing Palestinians to cross from Gaza into the Egyptian Sinai peninsula. â 
â 
Following a meeting on Wednesday with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi said such an exodus of people from Gaza would jeopardize Palestinian aspirations of statehood. â 
â 
Hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were forced from their land in past conflicts with Israel, with many settling in Egypt and other neighboring states. Many refugees have never been allowed to return â€” and the regions fear the wider implications of Palestinians being forced to flee Gaza, said analyst Chris Doyle, director of the London-based Council for Arab-British Understanding. â

To read translated literature is to give a voice to the marginalised.

Kashmir of India would find mention in every book written on the marginalised. But is Kashmir only about her conflict? No. It's also about the bustling streets, it is about the festivals they celebrate, about the ruins of temples that are going to resurrect in the future, it is about the school going kids, it is about her humans.

'For Now it is night' by Hari Krishna Kaul is one such humane collection of short stories of Kashmir and her people. It is a unique collaboration of translation by Kalpana Raina, Tanveer Ajsi, Gowhar Fazili, Gowhar Yaqoob from the Kashmiri into English. Picked from 4 of Kaul's books this book has 17 short stories based in Kashmir or at times on Kashmiri people living outside Kashmir.

So what are these stories about? There is a Kashmiri woman living in Delhi & her experience in her non-muslim neighborhood which she is happy about, there is Tara Chand a very noble man who has died & his ex-tenants are on their way to his funeral, there are 2 boys who are best friends and how things change in Kashmir while they remain in the same class year after year haha, and yes, there are stories about the political nature of the land. For Kashmiris - the political will always be personal.

My top pick is 'That We Cannot Speak Of,' exploring a Kashmiri Pandit's inner struggles pre 1990, dealing with his estranged Muslim friend's growing animosity, in silence. It reflects the challenges of a marginalized minority. Other favorites include 'One Sahib and the Other,' offering concise yet insightful political commentary through a conversation between two sahibs, 'A Song of Despair,' delving into the complex relationship of a rebel son and conservative father, and 'The Tongue and the Egg,' which uses a tale of a tongueless friend of a person to comment on power dynamics in the world.

I won't say these stories surpassed my expectations because I was barely expecting from them, but they are just so good, just so humane.

.

c/o @harpercollinsin

#kashmiri #translatedliterature #bookstagramindia #shortstorywriter

Yousaf's in-laws are trapped in Hamas-controlled Gaza. The First Minister of Scotland, Humza Yousaf, on Wednesday said his country was ready to offer asylum to the people of Gaza, who were displaced in the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas. Yousaf's announcement makes Scotland one of the first countries to welcome war-hit Palestinians. The First Minister of Scotland, who leads the cabinet, holds an office equivalent to that of the Prime Minister.

20 Stories High is an activist organisation and believes in speaking out when we see injustice, conflict, and oppression. We collaborate with young people from many different communities, locally, nationally, and internationally. We believe in building a better, safer, fairer world.

As the terrible violence in Gaza and Israel continues, as in most wars, children are paying the heaviest price.
 
We stand with Save the Children with as they call upon the UK Government to stand with children and call for: 
 
An urgent ceasefire agreed by all parties to the conflict. Humanitarian assistance must be allowed to be delivered to children in Gaza. 
All children affected by the violence in Gaza and Israel must be protected and supported to find safety.
All parties to the conflict must respect international humanitarian law, commit no further grave violations against children and ensure that there is accountability for those committed to date.
All children captured must be released immediately and unconditionally.
Humanitarian assistance must be scaled up to meet the demands of the crisis. Aid must not be withheld from children.â€¯

We also recognise that antisemitism and Islamophobia are at an all-time high as tensions mount around the globe. We urge communities to come together to talk and listen in the name of peace. 
 
To sign the @savechildrenuk petition to the UK Government

Junior and Middle Years students of Academus exhibited a profound sense of global responsibility and a nurturing empathy towards the enduring spirit of Palestine.

In a heartfelt expression of solidarity with Palestine, the students of Grades III and IV, delved into the themes of peace and harmony through "Colours of Peace and Harmony" - a march across the campus, adorned with insightful, impactful posters crafted by the young minds.

Grade Vs embarked on a reflective journey, exploring the historic 1967 UN charter advocating a two-state resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, under the banner "Our World, Our Promise." This theme fostered a deeper understanding of global diplomacy and the seeds of hope it sows amidst adversities.

Venturing into the current geopolitical landscape, Grades VI to VIII convened for a "Building Bridges" panel discussion. This engaging dialogue encompassed an exploration of the prevailing situation in Palestine, delving into avenues of external support, donor agency access, and potential conflict resolution strategies.

De Amerikaanse documentaire fotograaf Susan Meiselas deed jarenlang onafhankelijk verslag van oorlogen, humanitaire crises en andere relevante gebeurtenissen in Midden- en Zuid-Amerika, waaronder de Nicaraguaanse revolutie van 1978/1979. Haar fotoâ€™s brachten dit conflict onder wereldwijde aandacht en hadden een grote invloed op haar carriÃ¨re als fotograaf: in 1979 ontving ze de Robert Capa Gold Medal.

Het is een bewuste keuze van Susan Meiselas om haar beelden in kleur te schieten. Daarmee kon ze de vitaliteit van de mensen en het optimisme van de opstand in beeld vangen.

Meiselasâ€™ sociaal-documentaire projecten zijn gebaseerd op een langdurige en duurzame aanpak, waarbij ze vaak terugkeert naar de plekken en de mensen die ze heeft gefotografeerd. Door de fotoâ€™s steeds op andere manieren te tonen, zoals in films en in de openbare ruimte, reflecteert ze op de manier waarop fotografie impact kan hebben.

Fotoâ€™s van Meiselas zijn te zien in â€˜Vrouwen aan het front â€“ Van Lee Miller tot Anja Niedringhausâ€™, een tentoonstelling die afrekent met het beeld dat oorlogsfotografie uitsluitend een mannenzaak is. Te zien t/m 26 nov.

De tentoonstelling is mede mogelijk gemaakt door @ASNbank en @vfonds.

Arabs and Jews living in the Belgian capital Brussels came together Thursday to send a message of peace amid the Israel-Palestine conflict.

They gathered in Schuman Square, where European Union buildings are located, carrying banners saying "Peace now," "Arab-Jewish solidarity," "Our choice is unity" and "Political solution, not military."

Speaking to Anadolu, Wassim Allouka, who is of Moroccan origin, said Arab and Jewish communities should live together by understanding each other's point of view.

Avi Tawil, a member of the Jewish community, also emphasized the importance of peaceful coexistence.

"While I wear my kippah, a Muslim woman should be able to walk freely with her headscarf. No one should be discriminated against because of their religion," he said.

Tawil said he believes there will be a time when Israelis and Palestinians will live in peace in the region and children will focus on their bright futures instead of bombs.

Patrick Menache, a Jewish Belgian citizen, said that Arab-Jewish tensions are politically based and it is possible for the two peoples to live in peace.

The conflict in Gaza, which has been under Israeli bombardment and a blockade since Oct. 7, began when the Palestinian group Hamas initiated Operation Al-Aqsa Flood, a multi-pronged surprise attack that included a barrage of rocket launches and infiltrations into Israel by land, sea and air.

It said the incursion was in retaliation for the storming of Al-Aqsa Mosque and growing violence by Israeli settlers against Palestinians.

The Israeli military then launched Operation Swords of Iron against Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip.

Gaza is experiencing a dire humanitarian crisis with no electricity, while water, food, fuel and medical supplies are running out.

UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has called for an immediate humanitarian cease-fire to ease the â€œepic human suffering.â€

At least 3,785 Palestinians have been killed in Israeli attacks on Gaza, while more than 1,400 Israelis have been killed in the conflict.

"[Jo] Tanâ€™s complex, nuanced script switches between this tense, combative game and episodes from the coupleâ€™s past... In moments where the duoâ€™s energies match, shades of unresolved conflict come to a potent head â€“ built on the seemingly insurmountable differences between [Brendon Fernandez's] broody artistic character and [Jo Tan's] anxious contract lawyer.

"Appropriately, for a script about the balm of conjuring up oneâ€™s own fantasy, an austere set by Petrina Dawn Tan featuring a long white table and two chairs is a perfect step away from the naturalistic set design that Checkpointâ€™s shows favour.

"Checkpoint Theatre joint artistic director Huzir Sulaimanâ€™s direction and dramaturgy keeps the play brisk and intriguing, transitioning between states of fantasy and reality without so much as an exposed seam to take the audience into a similar world of immersive game and power play.

"Beneath the playâ€™s narrative is a universal story of how people give up their own agency in defining who they are when they only listen to the stories that others tell of them and play by othersâ€™ rules.

Ook bij de cosmetische kliniek van Samana Jamsheed in Rotterdam blijven de deuren dicht.

â€˜Closed for a day for humanityâ€™, valt te lezen op de Instagrampagina van de kliniek van cosmetisch arts Samana Jamsheed (34). Op een normale vrijdag verdient ze haar geld met het inbrengen van botox en fillers. Ze zou om 10.00 uur haar eerste cliÃ«nten ontvangen, maar voor vandaag is iedereen afgebeld. Alle werknemers van Drs. Samana Clinics aan het Weena leggen hun werk neer.

Ze zijn niet de enigen: ook in andere landen wordt er gestaakt. Op sociale media werd deze week opgeroepen vrijdag niet te gaan werken en geen geld uit te geven. Doel is de economie te raken en op die manier aandacht te vragen voor de situatie van de Gazanen. Ook elders in Rotterdam blijven winkels en ondernemingen dicht. Hoeveel mensen er precies gehoor geven aan de oproep, is niet duidelijk.

Josh Paul, a US State Department official, has resigned over President Joe Biden's handling of the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine.

The senior official, who has worked for over a decade on arms transfers in the State Department's Bureau of Political-Military Affairs, announced his retirement on October 18 in a two-page letter.

Explaining his reasons for resigning, he wrote: â€œI believe to the core of my soul that the response Israel is taking, and with it the American support both for that response and the status quo of the occupation, will only lead to more and deeper suffering for both the Israeli and Palestinian people - and is not in the long-term American interest".

Paul also expressed his desire to protect innocent people â€“ both Israeli and Palestinian.

â€œCollective punishment is an enemy to that desire, whether it involves demolishing one home or one thousand; as too is ethnic cleansing; as too is occupation; as too is apartheid," he said.

During a speech in Tel Aviv on October 17, US President Joe Biden voiced his complete support for Israel and its actions against Palestinian armed groups in Gaza.

Gaza is home to 2.3 million Palestinians (1.1 million children) and is one of the worldâ€™s most densely populated places. Israel has held it under siege for 17 years. In the last 11 days Israel has dropped thousands of bombs on the imprisoned population, estimated to be the equivalent force of a quarter of a nuclear bomb. Human rights experts have also confirmed the use of the internationally-banned weapon, white phosphorus.

On 15 October 2023, over 800 scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies signed a public statement warning of the possibility of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. Signatories include prominent Holocaust and genocide studies scholars.

â€œAs scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies, we are compelled to sound the alarm about the possibility of the crime of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. We do not do so lightly, recognising the weight of this crime, but the gravity of the current situation demands it.â€

Our mission has never been more critical: using the history and lessons of the Holocaust to build a just and caring community free of antisemitism and all forms of prejudice and bigotry. 

This is a difficult time for me personally, and I know it is difficult for many of us in the community and beyond. I believe it is a difficult moment for humanity. Our hearts are with the people of Israel as they bury and honor those who were brutally murdered, as well as with the citizens of Gaza whose lives are in danger daily.

While we can disagree about how to solve the decades-long Israeli-Palestinian conflict, we can all agree that loss of innocent lives is not going to advance the cause for peace in the Middle East. 

Many people wonder how we cope with the events happening around us every day. We manage by finding meaning in the present, remembering the strength of Holocaust survivor Tess Wise, who wanted us to learn about being strong and hopeful, and by teaching others important lessons from this time in history.

With Tessâ€™s legacy in mind, our Center will continue to welcome everyone who seeks to learn about the consequences of hatred and the power of hope and resilience.

In an effort to support our community, we are sharing resources at the link in our bio to assist you in discussing current events with your family, friends, and children. 

We are grateful for your support as we work on creating a society where we can engage in meaningful conservations and learn from one another.

Talli Dippold â€“ Chief Executive Officer

On Cazenove Road in north London, the mosque and synagogue are a few doors from each other.

Rabbi Hershel Gluck says the Jewish community welcomed Muslims into the area decades ago and they have lived peacefully together ever since. But can a war many miles away change that?

Outside the North London Muslim Community Centre, we meet a young woman called Salma. She fears events abroad are pulling at the seams of unity.

She says: "Of course everyone is worried about tensions flaring up. It's on everyone's mind. It weighs heavily on everyone's mind."

Rabbi Gluck says that's not the case in Stoke Newington.

"You walked round these streets this morning and you see terrific integration," he says.

"You don't see any conflict. You see people engaging with one another, smiling at one another, seeing each other as equal, friends and human beings."

We are both invited into the North London Muslim Community Centre by its secretary, Mohammed Gajia.

There's building work under way in several rooms but at the back is a pristine sports hall where community events are held, which the two men tell me often include people of other faiths.

Mohammed says of Rabbi Gluck: "We are friends. I have known him for over 30 years."

Of the demonstrations, he says: "A lot of people want to go on Saturday for the protest. I know my granddaughters go. I think it's only to support the people of Palestine, the people of Gaza - not any organisation."

As we are leaving, a police van pulls up and officers go into the centre. They tell me this is a "reassurance patrol," but there haven't been reports of any trouble.

Besides targeting hospitals, schools, apartment buildings, churches, refugee centers and other declared â€œsafe zones,â€ the Israel regime has bombed five bakeries, including one of the largest facilities that supplied bread to 100,000 Palestinians. A strategy with a specific outcome: to starve the people. 
 
Daily lines for bread have been congested with starving people waiting up to 5 hours for bread. Many Palestinians are down to one meal a day and continue drinking dirty water. 
 
All of these tactics align with the regimeâ€™s Dahiya Doctrine, designed to respond with â€œasymmetrical forceâ€ stressing that in a conflict with Hamas, the Israeli army should use "force that is disproportionate to the enemy's actions and the threat it poses."
 
Let me say this: after  seven decades of committing war crimes without impunity, Israel is facing an unexpected force it hadnâ€™t considered in the past: global outrage. 
 
Our voices have forced the regime to recant its gruesome â€œvictoriesâ€ and continue to dismantle their propaganda machine. 
 
Keep going, fellow misfits and noisemakers. We cannot stop resisting and naming this continued genocide of the Palestinian people until Palestine is free.

text:
Statement from Concern Worldwide on the situation in Occupied Palestinian Territory and Israel:

Concernâ€™s vision is a world where no one lives in poverty, fear or oppression; a world where everyone is treated with dignity and respect.

Although Concern does not work in the Occupied Palestinian Territory and Israel, we are deeply concerned by the escalation of violence and the deteriorating humanitarian situation.

Concern implores all parties to the conflict to ensure the protection of civilians and civilian infrastructure, humanitarian personnel and medical personnel and facilities, and guarantee immediate and safe access to humanitarian assistance.

Our team in Lebanon is closely monitoring the situation and we are ready to scale-up our interventions, if needed. Everything must be done to minimise the risks of violence spreading to other countries.

Now is the time for global leaders to prioritise the protection of civilians, uphold humanitarian principles and respect International Humanitarian Law.

It was such a wonderful evening filled with victory, hope and possibility of a brighter future for our industry even if it came just 3 days following conflict in the Middle East and in the digital world. A day laterâ€¦the AMPTP walked away from the table and negotiations with SAG-AFTRA stalled. â€¨â€¨It felt like yet another gut punch just when things were looking up. Is this upper-limiting (read The Big Leap by Gay Hendricks) or are the AMPTP really that dishonorable? I am choosing now to post these photos as a reminder of what the other side of strike looks like. Remembering that miracles can happen in the 11th hour. Actors if we band together, lean on each other and stay resolute for a fair deal that benefits ALL television and film performersâ€¦we. will. win. â€¨â€¨One day longer. One day stronger! 

As long as it takes. 
-V.

text:
Afghanistan earthquake response
 
On October 7th, the Herat region in Afghanistan was hit by an 6.3 earthquake. Three others followed in the very next week. 
 
Following these events, 2,000 persons were reported dead near the epicenter. It is estimated 270,000 are affected. People have lost their homes and are missing essential goods and services. They need shelter, safe water, food and other essential items such as hygiene kits or baby kits. The earthquake also came aggravating the living conditions of an already vulnerable population, experiencing a serious crisis linked to climate change, conflict and economic difficulties.
 
@actedngo was born in Afghanistan in 1993 and is, since then, committed to responding to the needs of the most vulnerable in the country, including in Herat province. Since 7th October, in response to the disaster, Acted ğŸ‘‡
âœ… Supported 5,700+ persons
âœ… Distributed 280 tents to families
âœ… Distributed almost 1,000 hygiene kits
 
Our next steps? Providing financial aid ğŸ’µ, distributing essential items for families to face the winter cold â„ï¸, and rehabilitating a water point, to ensure access to clean water ğŸš°

Following the ongoing conflict in the Middle East, cultural and generational aftershocks have been felt by families across the world. HPR spoke to three individuals with HawaiÊ»i roots who shared their stories about life during the Israel-Hamas war.â 
â 
The Conversation's Catherine Cruz reports:â 
â 
- Jenna Kirschner, a 2022 University of HawaiÊ»i graduate living in Israel, spoke on the phone from her apartment about 10 miles north of Tel Aviv. She has since made it safely to Barcelona on an El Al flight â€” and hopes to return to Israel one day. â 
â 
- Matti Gorodenchik is a special education teacher and football coach at Kaimuki High School. He was distraught not knowing if his loved ones were dead or alive as Hamas closed in. â 
â 
- Former HawaiÊ»i resident and humanitarian worker Ramona Okumura is one of about a million people in Gaza heading to the Egyptian border to flee the area before Israel unleashes a ground assault. Okumura's nieces have started a campaign called "Bring Auntie Ramona Home."â 
â 
Listen and read more stories from The Conversation by clicking the link in our bio.

The world is in a troubled state right now, and the horrible and heartbreaking outbreak of violence in the Middle East sees us in shock and disbelief.
 
The Circus has, a long time ago, made friends with the guys behind the @abrahamhostels in Israel, who have stayed with us often, who enjoyed Berlin as much as we do, and who have been â€“ and will be â€“ advocates for a peaceful, inclusive and non-nationalist future of the area. They have been for years organizing events, get togethers, cultural events meant to make a change for a cooperative way to live, based on compromise and understanding. They have been a force of good in a partly hostile environment with too many people that are not.
 
The parents of one of the founders of our friends hostels became victim of the conflict last week, and I am personally still struggling to understand and digest this news.
 
The Abraham hostels have opened their houses for all victims of the conflict, independent from their religious background, and are right now hosting refugees, feeding them, offering support, emotional and personal assistance. They do, what a hostel can do in its very best moment: give shelter and home to those in need.
 
We would like to let you know about an initiative through which you can help to relieve the burden for them and support these admirable guys in what they are doing. This request of support is not a political statement. It is the attempt to support individuals we really like and that are trying to make a difference, and that are trying to do the right thing. Please trust us when we reassure you that your support is used in the wisest way possible. Youâ€™ll find the link here: https://www.abraham.travel/group/donate/
 
Thank you very much, and we â€“ like you â€“ are so very very much looking forward to the day when the guns finally and for all time turn silent.
 
Andreas for the Circus

A Coroner's inquest has opened to unravel the circumstances surrounding the death of the 12 year old boy with the missing intestine , Adebola Akin-Bright, who died at the Lagos State University Teaching Hospital (LASUTH).

At the preliminary sitting, the presiding Coroner, Bola Folarin-Williams, sitting at Magistrate Court 4, Botanical Gardens, Ebute-Metta, heard opening statements from all the counsel involved with the case.

The state counsel from the Lagos Ministry of Justice, Ola Akinde told the court that necessary tests and examinations have been conducted on the corpse, and that the post-mortem report is ready. He added that the office of the Attorney General has received letters from the family's lawyers seeking the release of the corpse for burial and for the corpse to be preserved. 

Lawyer representing the father of the deceased, Ebun-Olu Adegboruwa (SAN) also requested to invite the medical director of Hobitox Medical Centre where the deceased was first admitted and treated, as well as the doctors that treated him at LASUTH and all policemen involved in the investigation, in order to have a proper understanding of what actually happened to the young boy.

Mr Adegboruwa also applied to the coroner for an independent examination of the corpse so as to avoid the likelihood of bias and conflict of interests.

Another counsel, Abiodun Kolawole, appeared as an interested party for the African Women Lawyers Association.

After hearing all the counsel, the coroner directed that the autopsy report and all other documents be made available to the parties involved.

The coroner also urged all the counsel to harmonise their positions and submit the list of their intended witnesses before the next date. 

The case was adjourned to 24th November 2023, for further proceedings.

Adebola died at LASUTH on September 19, following a plea by his mother to Governor Babajide Sanwo-Olu to probe the disappearance of her sonâ€™s small intestines, said to have occurred while he was receiving treatment at the state-run facility.

But, the hospital management, however, denied the allegation.

Hard to be Soft â€“ A Belfast Prayer is a detailed description of everyday life in Northern Ireland and a portrait of its working class, their toughness and their vulnerability. Using a direct narrative style, the dancer and choreographer Oona Doherty, Spotlight Artist at this yearâ€™s festival, explores machismo, the roles of women, class identity, religion, sexuality, anger and resistance â€“ based on memories of her own youth in Belfast, Northern Ireland. 

Dancing with a powerful combination of brutal defiance and restrained tenderness, Oona Doherty and her nine dancers are accompanied by a group of young dancers from Wiesbaden, that underlines the beauty and horror that persist as remnants of the Northern Ireland troubles, of a conflict between religions and identities. It is their attempt to overcome this legacy through their own movement and sweat.

I have so much empathy for our people and the damage religion has done to them.
Christians could face one year prison sentence for encouraging conversion to their faith, according to a new controversial legislation being introduced in Israel. The legislation which is being proposed by ultra-Orthodox members of Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s coalition would also proscribe Christians from engaging in religious discussion with Jews.
Titled Proposed Penal Law: Amendment â€“ Prohibition of Solicitation for Religious Conversion â€“ 2023, the legislation is introduced by United Torah Judaismâ€™s Moshe Gafni and Yaakov Asher. The law would apply to anyone who would attempt to persuade someone to change their religious beliefs, however the legislation specifically mentions the Christian faith, saying that â€œrecently, the attempts of missionary groups, mainly Christians, to solicit conversion of religion have increased.â€

.

Title: Metaerie: Wings Tip the Scales 

Genre: Thriller 

Review:
This is the second book of the series and trust me it will be an amazing read, might have better actions than the first one.and it continues to explore the magical realm of Metaerie. 

The plot revolves around a world where humans and their descendants now make up a significant portion of the population, alongside Dragons and Pixies. These beings wield ancient magic, but the Old World's traditions, which include deception and violence, continue to play a significant role in the characters' lives, making abrupt mortality a central theme.

The story unfolds as mages and warriors from different age groups come together to face a growing division within the realm. Witches, wyverns, dragons, and the undead are part of the mix, creating a diverse and perilous landscape. The question of whether the enemy of one's enemy is a friend or not adds depth to the character interactions and the overarching conflict.

It was a fantastic and an enjoyable read that will keep the readers on the edge of the chair. The book further delves into the intricate motivations of the characters. The story challenges readers to discern truth from deception and to understand the complex motives that guide individuals and groups in this magical world. The language is simple but I will recommend this book to the people above 16 years of age. The cover is simple with an apt title.

Go and order your copy now ! 

Review By Walk With A Book.

NIEUW: De geactualiseerde biografie van de eigenzinnige dichter en theoloog Huub Oosterhuis die met zijn kerkliederen het geloofsleven in Nederland diepgaand beÃ¯nvloedde. 'Intelligente biografie' - NRC

In Huub Oosterhuis. De biografie vertelt Marc van Dijk het levensverhaal van de invloedrijke theoloog en dichter. Van zijn kinderjaren in bezet Amsterdam tot zijn laatste uren. Oosterhuis las de Bijbel als een politiek manifest, schreef liederen die in meerdere talen gezongen worden en stichtte culturele podia als De Balie, De Rode Hoed en De Nieuwe Liefde. Hij verbond zich met de SP, maar ook met de koninklijke familie. Nadat hij met Rome in conflict raakte over het verplichte celibaat, zette hij zijn werk voort op eigen kracht. Hij wilde de grenzen tussen religie, politiek en poÃ«zie opheffen. Zijn taal oversteeg tegenstellingen en bracht nieuwe bezieling in een tijd van snelle secularisatie.

Marc van Dijk interviewde Huub Oosterhuis gedurende vele jaren voor deze biografie. Oosterhuis heeft zijn eigen woorden geautoriseerd. Ook de kroongetuigen uit zijn leven komen aan het woord; zijn kinderen Tjeerd en Trijntje, (oud-)collegaâ€™s en (ex-)geliefden. Zo ontstaat een veelzijdig beeld van 'de paus van Amsterdam'.

Best Interest of the Child Principle - An Explanation

The best interest of the child principle is an age-old concept that first emerged as an articulate standard in American adoption law in the mid-1800s.1. The best interest of the child is a dispositional standard, designed to guide judges when making decisions that concern children. Under traditional American family law such decisions only fall to a judge after a parent has been convicted of abuse or neglect, or in a divorce context when there is conflict between competing parents. The U.S. Supreme Court has consistently recognized â€œthat natural bonds of affection lead parents to act in the best interests of their children.â€2. American law has historically operated on the presumption that parents are fit to make decisions in the interest of their children unless proven otherwise. 

This new human rights application of the best interest of the child principle, as implemented in U.N. treaties such as the CRC and the CRPD, abolishes the presumption of parental fitness. Under this misapplication, judicial prerogative to determine the childâ€™s best interest becomes the default, rather than a last-resort reserved for when a parent has been proven unfit. Parentsâ€™ private choices for their children can be called into question any time government personnel disagree with them.

International law expert Geraldine Van Bueren clearly describes this emerging human rights application:

Best interests provides decision and policy makers with the authority to substitute their own decisions for either the child's or the parents', providing it is based on considerations of the best interests of the child. Thus, the Convention challenges the concept that family life is always in the best interests of children and that parents are always capable of deciding what is best for children. 3.

NOTES:

1. Lynne Marie Kohm, â€œTracing the Foundations of the Best Interests of the Child Standard in American Jurisprudence,â€ Regent University School of Law, 9 (2009).

2. Parham v. J. R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979). 

3. Geraldine Van Bueren, International Rights of the Child, Section D, University of London, 46 (2006).

On October 19, 2023 the U.S. State Department issued a Worldwide Caution in response to increased tensions in various locations around the world. This announcement indicates that U.S. Citizens should exercise increased caution by staying alert in tourist areas, enrolling in the STEP program, and following the Department of State social media outlets.

We understand that the violence in the Middle East related to the Israel-Hamas conflict is no doubt causing concern, and we want to assure you that student safety and well-being is our utmost priority. Please know that no one in the Arcadia Abroad community is alone.
Arcadia Abroad expresses our condolences and solace for all affected by this violence. We will continue to monitor the situation and maintain constant communication with our on-site staff, local authorities, and relevant organizations. Updates will be shared in a timely manner directly with students. We encourage students to take personal responsibility for their well-being. We strongly recommend that they follow the guidance of local authorities, avoid areas of unrest, and stay informed through reliable news sources. We will remain vigilant in our efforts to ensure a secure and positive study abroad experience for all.

Sincerely,

Andrew D Law, PhD

CEO, Arcadia Abroad
CAO, The College of Global Studies

The Michael C. Carlos Museum hosts Moving Still: A Night of Dance in the galleries in conjunction with the exhibition "You Belong Here: Place, People, and Purpose in Latinx Photography." Students in the Emory Dance Company will perform in the galleries alongside Assistant Professor of Dance Julio Medina, celebrating and reflecting on contemporary photography by Latinx artists across the United States. Medina's pedagogy draws from two philosophies: Knowledge of Self and Pedagogy of the Oppressed; as a result, his work is identity-based in nature, and his choreography is rooted in a deep curiosity about the complex layers of resilience, conflict, and connection as a Chicano. 
 
Admission is free, but space is limited, and registration is required. 
 
Doors open on  Thursday, November 2 at 6:30 p.m. with  performances at 7 p.m. and 8 p.m., Please register for your preferred showtime by visiting the link in our bio.  At 7:30 p.m., there will be a reception in Ackerman Hall with light refreshments.

text:
I am a theologian, and I am a mother. Those two things are inextricable.

In a time when many are arguing about the justice of war, it feels more important than ever to remember this name for God. It seems like on all sides of the conflict are people fighting in the name of their God, in the name of justice, or in the name of retribution.

Throughout history, so many have perished in the name of God, with Christians more often than not leading the charge. I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s who God is; I think thatâ€™s who humans have wanted God to be.

I donâ€™t have any of the answers to the conflict in the Middle East. Iâ€™m not a politician; Iâ€™m not a historian. Iâ€™m a theologian and I am a mother. I know that how we see God matters and I know that much of our theology till now has borne rotten fruit. This is what it looks like to explore fresh ideas about God. ğŸ’“

Comment below and Iâ€™ll send you the ğŸ”— to read more.

VICE ADMIRAL GAVAN IS THE 30TH PCG COMMANDANT ğŸ‡µğŸ‡­

Department of Transportation (DOTr) Secretary Jaime Bautista announces the appointment of CG VICE ADMIRAL RONNIE GIL LATORILLA GAVAN as the 30th Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) Commandant during the Change of Command Ceremony at the National Headquarters, Port Area, Manila, today, 19 October 2023. 

In his speech, the Transportation Secretary expressed his trust and confidence that CG Vice Admiral Gavan would efficiently lead the PCG in implementing the "White Hull Approach" towards upholding maritime security and safety in the country's exclusive economic zones.

"Admiral Art was hailed for his innate peace mindset that steered the country away from any deterioration in the volatile situation at the West Philippine Sea," DOTr Secretary Bautista said. 

"My belief that Vice Admiral Ronnie Gavan will do the same is anchored on his record of shifting to the 'White Hull Approach' when securing our maritime borders and his introduction of female radio operators, called 'Angels of the Sea,' as a way of diffusing tension during sea conflict," he furthered. 

Moreover, the Transportation Secretary emphasized President Ferdinand Bongbong Marcos Jr's directives to the PCG during its 122nd founding anniversary as it moved forward to provide better public service to the Filipino nation. 

"I expect the PCG to provide steadfast service and dedication to duty during times of calamity; uphold our country's maritime security and promote our maritime rights; do its part in fighting smuggling; protect our marine environment; and secure the safety of our fishermen when pursuing their means of livelihood," DOTr Secretary Bautista highlighted.

"The Department of Transportation firmly stands with you in your plans and efforts to improve, expand, and modernize your capabilities and services so you can level up your efforts at securing the welfare of our people and our nation," he concluded. 

The Chief Executive chose CG Vice Admiral Gavan among five recommended candidates to take over the Coast Guard helm following the retirement of CG Admiral Artemio Abu after over 35 years of public service on the same date.

Started my read of In Truth, Madness by Imran Khan as part of the tour for Love Books Tours. 

My tour date is the 27th October when I will be posting my review. 

Blurb

The perfect read for Neil Gaiman fans. 

Meet Malek Khalil, a brilliant reporter with decades of experience in the field, and a man on the edge. Where there is war, natural disaster or political crisis, Malek is in the midst of it, but years of conflict reporting have taken their toll and he is slowly unravelling. 
His colleagues, Neeka and Justin, have noticed a change in him, beyond even his usual vivid imagination. Neeka is especially sensitive, having been his friend and producer for many years, and perhaps knowing him better than he knows himself. Justin, a skilled and brave cameraman, has worked with them for just as long and the three make a formidable team - but they are only as strong as each other - and Malek is fast going down the rabbit hole.

Born a Muslim but an atheist to his core, Malek's voyage takes him around the world and back in time to ancient Babylon, as he finds himself arguing with a God in whom he does not believe. A keen reader, his 'madness' is heightened by a strange book that keeps appearing on his Kindle, telling the stories of people he has briefly encountered during his career.

In Truth, Madness takes place in the Middle East, South Asia and London against a backdrop of war, religion, political skullduggery and emerging love, taking the reader on a tumultuous journey through the most dangerous arenas of modern culture and the ancient world. 

Is Malek losing his mind, or is he experiencing an astonishing kind of truth?

TRANSFORMATIONâ€”This war is different.

That message, a drumbeat from Israeli leaders ever since the savage Hamas attack on Oct. 7, refers to the unprecedented scale of their intended military response.

But it is also true on a deeper personal, psychological, and emotional level â€“ not just for Israelis, but for Palestinians, too. The war is stripping back their conflict over a piece of land to its rawest essentials, leaving people on both sides feeling vulnerable and victimized, apprehensive and angry.

The central question is whether this different war ultimately produces a different outcome â€“ a path toward a political resolution of their conflict that Israelis and Palestinians alike will be able to embrace.

The depth of the parallel Israeli and Palestinian agonies at the moment is apt to make resetting Mideast politics a slow, difficult challenge, no matter how this war ends.

But a decade of diplomatic neglect of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has now ended. Those parallel agonies have focused U.S. and other Western minds â€“ along with those of more moderate Arab regimes â€“ on the urgent need to create a new narrative. If it addresses the interlocking fears of both sides, it might just lay the foundations for a lasting peace.

People without homes are often forced to live in â€œfight/flight/freezeâ€ mode which leads to long term challenges regulating when and how someone needs to react to provocation. Shelters often create a proximity problem by forcing a large number of traumatized people under one roof with very little privacy and limited access to bathrooms. In some cases this environment can lead to power dynamics and conflict that forces people to fight for their own autonomy which inevitably leads to punishment and sometimes banishment. People often choose to sleep outside because they do not feel safe in these environments.

The ultimate reward is a well-adjusted, safe, and secure child!

#MitchellHamline Professor Forrest Tahdooahnippah is presenting a CLE on Thursday (Oct. 26) at 4pm CST on the Law of Psychedelics

As drug policy and attitudes towards drug policy evolves, laws prohibiting the use of psychedelics are being reexamined. Several state and local governments have decriminalized the use of psychedelics. 

Industry is taking advantage of these shifting attitudes to apply for intellectual property protection for uses of psychedelics. However, the use of psychedelics implicates individual and religious freedoms in ways that have not previously been in conflict with intellectual property rights. 

Profs. Tahdooahnippah and Dustin Marlan of UNC School of Law will discuss these emerging issues and explore the ways that #psychedelics create new intersections in the law, not previously considered.

Hybrid format (online and in-person); register at https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/IPCLE.
